pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, August 3, 2018
shortDescription: TMAC awardUTA's TMAC was granted a $6.6 million federal award to accelerate growth and competitiveness of small and mid-sized manufacturing firms, Tec
body:
TMAC award

UTA's TMAC was granted a $6.6 million federal award to accelerate growth and competitiveness of small and mid-sized manufacturing firms, TechSite reported. “This award enables UTA to continue being a catalyst in the economic development of the metroplex and state through helping small and mid-sized manufacturing firms develop or improve products, processes and human capital to increase sales and profits, and create jobs,” UTA President Vistasp Karbhari said.

Cooling transistors

UTA technology could change the way computers dissipate heat, The World Industrial Reporter reported. “This novel transistor reduces power consumption, runs the devices cooler and allows smaller battery packs to operate the component,” said Seong Jin Koh, a Department of Materials Science and Engineering professor and the principal architect behind the research. 

New process

Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in the UTA Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, published an article in Chromatography Online about a new concept his laboratory has been working on called multipath liquid chromatography. He hopes the process could prove a powerful tool in the identification of biomarkers for disease as well as antibody–drug development.

Water quality questions

Christian Zlolniski, a UTA associate professor of sociology and anthropology, was cited in a hortibiz article about the decreasing quality of groundwater in the San Quintin Valley, an arid region 180 miles south of Tijuana, Mexico, where strawberries are grown for the American market. 

Study investigates political races

Brent Boyea, a UTA associate professor of political science, published a 2017 study that found partisan judicial races attract more money than nonpartisan races, Facing South reported. The article discussed the North Carolina Supreme Court seat up for election this year, which has become one of the most expensive in history.

Alumna running for office

UTA alumna Annette Hyde, a yoga teacher who previously ran for the 30th District House seat in the Virginia House of Delegates, said she will seek the Democratic nomination in 2019, The News Virginian reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, June 27, 2018
shortDescription: Particle experiments awardThe U.S. Department of Energy has awarded Benjamin Jones, UTA assistant professor of physics, $750,000 to develop a sensor f
body:
Particle experiments award

The U.S. Department of Energy has awarded Benjamin Jones, UTA assistant professor of physics, $750,000 to develop a sensor for particle experiments that focus on the neutrino, a subatomic particle that may offer an answer to the lingering mystery of the universe’s matter-antimatter imbalance, the U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Science reported.  

Changing experiences

George Siemens, executive director of UTA’s Learning Innovation and Networked Knowledge or LINK Lab, was interviewed by WebsEdgeEducation about his research into how learning and work experiences are changing in a very technology-guided world. 

Democrats could take over House

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by KLIF 570 AM about the upcoming November elections and the possibility that the Democrats may take control over the House of Representatives. Saxe said that should this happen, proposals for impeachment of President Trump would likely appear on the first day after the election results. 

Physics professor at conference

UTA physics Professor Wei Chen participated in the 2018 International Conference on Nanogeoscience in Guiyang, STdaily of China reported. 

ArlingCon returns

Arlington Public Library’s annual pop culture convention, ArlingCon, returns Saturday to UTA, ArlingtonTx reported. ArlingCon will take place at the E.H. Hereford University Center. It is held in conjunction with UTA Libraries and celebrates interests across many genres. 

Archosaur site

UTA students participated in the Arlington Archosaur Site, the Dallas Observer reported in an article about how to get your dinosaur fix in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. The archosaur site has produced more fossils than any other location in the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex. 

Community service award

UTA alumnus and social work professor Thanh Tran, whose longstanding commitment to the Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American community has been called “exemplary,” has been named the 2018 recipient of Boston College’s Community Service Award, Boston College reported. Tran received a doctorate from the School of Social Work at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, June 29, 2018
shortDescription: Neutrino researchUTA physicists are leading a global team to discover why the universe is full of matter, The Dallas Morning News reported. The UTA re
body:
Neutrino research

UTA physicists are leading a global team to discover why the universe is full of matter, The Dallas Morning News reported. The UTA researchers led by Professor Jaehoon Yu has completed a prototype detector focused on tiny particle called the neutrino, which may hold the answer to this question. 

DOE grant

The U.S. Department of Energy awarded Benjamin Jones, UTA assistant professor of physics, a $750,000 grant to develop a sensor for particle experiments focusing on the neutrino, Dallas Innovates reported. 

Venomous snakes

Seven types of venomous snakes, including three rattlesnake species, are common to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, according to UTA's Amphibian and Reptile Diversity Research Centers, the Star-Telegram reported. Earlier this week, a 1-year-old boy was bitten by a rattlesnake while playing with his toys in Abilene.

International student enrollment dips

UTA international student counts fell almost 5 percent from fall 2016 to fall 2017, The Dallas Morning News reported in an op-ed that suggested that President Trump’s immigration policies were having an effect on international student applications. 

EdCareer Expo

UTA representatives participated in EduCareer Expo in Fair Park, aldiadallas reported. 

New judges stand

The main judges' viewing stand for the Arlington 4th of July parade will move from its usual spot in front of Arlington City Hall south to College Park Center on the UTA campus, ArlingtonTx reported. 

UTA graduate

The son of Bangladesh’s Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, Sajeeb Wazed Joy, graduated from UTA with a degree in computer engineering, bdnews24 reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, August 6, 2018
shortDescription: Fellow electionMark Haykowsky, a UTA nursing professor and leading expert in exercise physiology and heart failure rehabilitation, has been elected a
body:
Fellow election

Mark Haykowsky, a UTA nursing professor and leading expert in exercise physiology and heart failure rehabilitation, has been elected a fellow of the American College of Cardiology, Scienmag reported.

Home economics

The educational system needs to bring back home economics classes, wrote Marti Harvey, a UTA communication lecturer, in an op-ed piece for The Dallas Morning News and the Belleville, Ill., News-Democrat. She says classes like home economics would better prepare students for the real world.

Alumna featured

Paralympic gold medalist Darlene Hunter, a UTA social work alumna, was featured in an ESPNW story about the Lady Movin’ Mavs’ wheelchair basketball development camp and the camp’s interaction with the Dallas Wings, the WNBA team that plays at UTA’s College Park Center.

Scenic City

The Texas Municipal League certified Duncanville as a Scenic City for the first time, Focus Daily News reported. Duncanville City Planner Chasidy Allen Benson received the award. Benson has a UTA master’s degree in city and regional planning.

New senior associate VP

Joe Carpenter, Radford University’s vice president for University Relations and chief communications officer, is leaving to become UTA’s senior associate vice president for Institutional Advancement and chief communications officer, The Roanoke Times in Virginia reported.

Student profiled

Ewin Tang, a former UTA student, was featured in China’s CNCaixun.CN in a profile about his work in quantum computing while a student. While at UTA and at UT Austin, Tang also published four papers on biological materials. The story was about several college students and their research projects.

Soften language

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said in a KLIF 570 AM interview that President Trump should have used other language when he called the media an enemy of the people.

New exec VP

Union Pacific has appointed Lynden Tennison executive vice president and chief strategy officer, RelSci reported. Tennison earned a bachelor’s degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, August 1, 2018
shortDescription: Transistor technologyUTA technology could change the way computers dissipate heat, U.S. Fed News, Phys.org and Germany's Tekk.tv reported. UTA researc
body:
Transistor technology

UTA technology could change the way computers dissipate heat, U.S. Fed News, Phys.org and Germany's Tekk.tv reported. UTA researchers have received a patent on a novel cold electron transistor that drastically reduces the amount of energy required to operate as compared to traditional transistors. Seong Jin Koh, a Department of Materials Science and Engineering professor and the principal architect behind the research, said the technology evolves now to enable large-scale, manufacturable, marketable devices.

3-D blood vessels

UTA is improving the 3-D printing process for tissue-engineered blood vessels, which will help children with vascular defects, KXAS NBC 5 reported. Yi Hong, UTA professor of bioengineering, is leading the project.

Dual-credit courses

UTA was featured in a Chronicle of Higher Education story that analyzed the effectiveness of dual-credit courses, and whether they serve students well and save them money. The results from the University of Texas System study and other small-scale studies around the country are encouraging.

Trump comments

Brent Sasley, UTA associate professor of political science, said it's difficult to evaluate President Trump's comments on meeting with Iran's leader, KLIF 570 AM reported. Sasley said the comments may have been made off the cuff and may have been changed by the president’s advisers. 

Deck parks

Kathryn Holliday and Kevin Sloan, professors in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, were cited in a Christian Science Monitor article about deck parks in neighborhoods divided by highways. Both commented on the planned deck park in Dallas’s Oak Cliff neighborhood, which seeks to rejuvenate the diverse community situated around Interstate 35.

UTA ranked

Forbes’ third annual America’s Best Value Colleges ranked UTA No. 191 overall, Houston's KTRH 740 AM reported. The rankings list is based on net price, net debt, alumni earnings, timely graduation, school quality and access for low-income students.

Film program noted

UTA’s film school was featured in a Backstage list of the nation’s best schools. UTA’s program was described as striving to balance practical application with theoretical appreciation of film.  

Sustainability award

UTA is one of three universities to win the Excellence in Sustainability Award this year, U.S. Fed News reported. The award is earned by institutions that have demonstrated excellence and innovation in sustainability leadership, including financial, facilities, operational, environmental, community and climate. 

Music production camp

Micah Hayes, UTA senior lecturer in Music Industry Studies, 90.5 AM is running a week-long summer audio production camp for budding high school music producers, KUT 90.5 AM in Austin reported. He wants the campers to know what audio production is really like, showing them the different types of microphones, speakers and other technologies involved. 

Davis Drive work

Phase I of Arlington Water Utilities’ Davis Pressure Plane Project – which is primarily located along South Davis Drive, between West Park Row Drive and UTA Boulevard – is on schedule to finish in spring 2019, ArlingtonTx.gov reported. The article described what has been accomplished so far and what students and faculty returning to the UTA campus in August can expect to see.

Alumna running for office

UTA alumna Annette Hyde has declared her candidacy for the 24th District state Senate seat in Georgia, the Augusta Free Press reported. Hyde has a bachelor’s degree in communications from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, August 8, 2018
shortDescription: Chancellor finalistUniversity of Texas System regents voted Saturday to name James B. Milliken, former chancellor of the City University of New York a
body:
Chancellor finalist

University of Texas System regents voted Saturday to name James B. Milliken, former chancellor of the City University of New York and former president of the University of Nebraska, as the sole finalist for chancellor of the 14-campus system, The Texas Tribune, Austin American-Statesman, Dallas Morning News, Houston Chronicle, Star-Telegram, Chronicle of Higher Education and many other media outlets reported.

DUNE project

Jae Yu, a UTA physics professor, said the teamwork involved in the ProtoDUNE project is what makes it strong, Symmetry Magazine reported. DUNE is the Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment, an international mega-science project with more than 1,100 scientists from 32 countries, hosted by the Department of Energy’s Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill.

National History Museum

University of Texas at Arlington researchers, along with scientists from the National History Museum and The Smithsonian, are investigating how frog visual systems have changed as the animals have adapted to different lifestyles, the National History Museum website reported. Matthew Fujita, UTA assistant professor of biology, used a National Science Foundation grant to conduct the research. Read more about UTA’s research.

Finding the right therapist

Jan Finch and Sabine Rakos, UTA associate and assistant professors in practice in the School of Social Work, said in a Dallas Morning News story that finding the right therapist takes time and effort.

3D gun issue

Lewis Wasserman, UTA professor in the Department of Criminology and Criminal Justice, said on a KERA 90.1 FM All Things Considered segment that the publication of instructions on how to use 3D printing to produce a gun brings up freedom of speech issues. “What we have to ask is what this is going to do to protect the public. I think it’s minimal,” said Wasserman, who was a practicing attorney for many years before coming to UTA. He said if the nation is to maintain a democracy, officials should be wary of limiting free speech. Wasserman's interview starts at the 1:47 mark.

Ohio special election

Allan Saxe, a UTA associate professor of political science, said President Trump’s appearance recently in a special election of an Ohio congressional district may have put the Republican candidate on the road to victory, WBAP 820 AM reported. The race was decided by less than 1 percent. A recount is likely. Saxe said in a separate WBAP 820 AM story that Democrats have reason to smile even if they lose because the district is one that Trump carried by double-digit percentage points in the presidential election.

PhD student to speak

Dallas NAACP President Aubrey Hooper has been leading the charge to thank North Texas legal and law enforcement warriors who he says are fighting for justice in turbulent times, The Dallas Morning News reported. Hooper is a doctoral student UTA's College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs. Hooper will speak at the event, "Justice for All Brunch: Balancing the Scales of Justice," at 10:30 a.m. Saturday at Lofty Spaces, 816 Montgomery St., just south of downtown Dallas.

Accounting graduates promoted

Hayden Grahm was promoted to partner of JTaylor, an accounting firm, CityBizList.com reported. Patty Perez Vavrin has been named a principal at the firm. Grahm and Vavrin are UTA accounting graduates.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, August 13, 2018
shortDescription: Robotic smart skinUTA has patented a smart skin, created by Zeynep Çelik-Butler, a UTA electrical engineering professor, that gives robots more sensit
body:
Robotic smart skin

UTA has patented a smart skin, created by Zeynep Çelik-Butler, a UTA electrical engineering professor, that gives robots more sensitive tactile feeling than humans, Wireless Design Magazine, Science & Enterprise Magazine, R&D Magazine, the Namibian Sun, New Atlas, Techstory, Printed Electronics World and many other media outlets reported.

Cache efficiency

Song Jiang, a UTA associate professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, is working on a National Science Foundation program that will make accessing data more efficient, Phys.org, Dallas Innovates and iConnece007.com reported.

UTA/DART celebration

The UTA/DART Transportation Leadership Academy commemorated the program's successful inaugural year Thursday night with a celebration at the Dallas Tower Club, NewsEdge.com reported.

Preservation addressed

Dallas’ 10th Street neighborhood, one of the last historic freedman towns, is undergoing change as public and economic development projects take place, The Dallas Morning News reported in an article about the changing area. Kathryn Holliday, a UTA architectural historian and associate professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, said she believes historic preservation is often viewed as an impediment to economic development, but is really a tool for it.

Bring back home economics

The educational system needs to bring back home economics classes, wrote Marti Harvey, a UTA communication lecturer, in an op-ed piece for the Cleveland Plain Dealer and HeraldNet.com in Everett, Wash. The original column ran in The Dallas Morning News. She said classes like home economics would better prepare students for the real world.

Panel discussion

Ryon Cobb, UTA assistant professor in the School of Social Work, has been named to a discussion panel for a Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture event later this month, PressReleasePoint.com reported. The discussion kicks off a six-part series titled "gOD-Talk: A Black Millennials and Faith Conversation Series" and will be held at the California African American Museum in Los Angeles. The series is in partnership with the Pew Research Center.

Trump influence

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said in a WBAP 820 AM interview that one of the reasons the Republicans are leading a tight Ohio congressional special election is because of President Trump’s influence and stumping in that election. The race is still too close to call, but the Republican candidate holds about a 1,500 vote lead.

Alumnus named interim dean

Zephyrinus Okonkwo was named interim dean to Albany State University’s College of Arts and Sciences, New York’s Albany Herald reported. Okonkwo earned his doctorate in mathematics from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, July 16, 2018
shortDescription: Plastic pinsSahadat Hossain, UTA civil engineering professor and director of the UTA Solid Waste Institute for Sustainability, is using recycled plast
body:
Plastic pins

Sahadat Hossain, UTA civil engineering professor and director of the UTA Solid Waste Institute for Sustainability, is using recycled plastic to form large pins that stabilize shifting soil on highway slopes, HowStuffWorks reported.

Power grid improvements

Ramtin Madani, an assistant professor in UTA's Electrical Engineering Department, recently was awarded a $325,000 grant from the National Science Foundation to develop massively scalable computational methods to increase the efficiency, reliability and security of the national power grid, Dallas Innovates reported.

Glass art

Justin Ginsberg, UTA’s glass area coordinator and assistant professor of practice in UTA’s Art and Art History Department, said the Pilchuck Glass School, a Washington state summer camp for object makers who specialize in glass, offers an idealized approach to the art, Glasstire reported. The story also quoted Kelley McCabe, a UTA graduate of the glass art program.

Environment workshop

The Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality is partnering with UTA’s Environmental Training Institute to hold a workshop July 31-Aug. 1 on pollution prevention, efficient business operations and environmental management systems, the Newton County Times reported.

Trump-Putin meeting

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, told KLIF 570 AM listeners that today’s meeting between President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin will center on important issues like the Syrian conflict, Crimea and nuclear stability.

Nationally ranked

UTA’s School of Social Work was ranked No. 28 in the nation for online Master of Social Work degrees by SocialWorkGuide.org, Virtual Strategy Magazine and seattlepi.com reported.

Board appointments

Charles Williams, president and CEO of the Regional Medical Center in Orangeburg, S.C., has been elected to the boards of Healthcare Risk Services South Carolina, Palmetto Hospital Trust and Palmetto Healthcare Liability Insurance Program, the Times & Democrat of South Carolina reported. Williams earned his master’s degree in business administration from UTA.

Best CFO

Sarah Tacker of Ronald McDonald House Charities of Central Texas was named the best chief financial officer in that region, the Austin Business Journal reported. Tacker earned her Master of Social Work degree from UTA.

Dreamer featured

UTA student Alex Medrano was featured in a MENAFN of Qatar story about white-collar Dreamers climbing the ladder at major American companies. He works at Wells Fargo and has been taking business classes at UTA, though he is considering changing to engineering. Bloomberg originally ran the story about the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program.

Alumnus hired at Post

The Washington Post reported that UTA alumnus John Harden has joined its team as the local section’s first data reporter. Harden is a graduate of UTA with a degree in broadcast journalism.

Davis promoted

UTA has promoted Jeff Davis to executive director of special events facilities, Front Row News reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, July 25, 2018
shortDescription: Sustainability awardThe University of Texas at Arlington has won a prestigious Excellence in Sustainability Award from the National Association of Col
body:
Sustainability award

The University of Texas at Arlington has won a prestigious Excellence in Sustainability Award from the National Association of College and University Business Officers, ScienMag, Stamford Advocate and many other media reported. The Excellence in Sustainability Award is earned by institutions that have demonstrated excellence and innovation in sustainability leadership, including financial, facilities, operational, environmental, community and climate. 

Music production summer camp

Micah Hayes, UTA senior lecturer in Music Industry Studies, is running a week-long summer audio production camp for budding high school music producers, KERA News and Dallas Art Dealers Association reported. He wants the campers to know what audio production is really like, showing them the different kinds of microphones, speakers and other technologies involved. 

Community garden

Thanks to a collaboration between the City of Arlington and UTA, even those with a small yard or no yard can grow their own produce, Arlington-TX.gov reported. Gardeners can rent a plot at UTA’s community garden for only $25 a year. The only requirement is that plot owners must donate at least half of the food they grow to Mission Arlington, the garden’s designated food bank program.

Lockheed Martin interns

UTA students were featured in an Arlington-TX.gov story about former Arlington school district students who landed jobs at Lockheed Martin after internships. Martin Smith, a UTA student who has nearly completed his degree in mechanical engineering who participated in the inaugural Lockheed Martin internship program, received a job offer at the company’s High School Intern Signing Day.

Maverick Theatre Company

The Maverick Theatre Company is participating in Fort Worth Fringe Fest in September with Mask Madness, an original devised theatre production grounded in the European Character Mask style, TheatreJones reported. The production follows a mad scientist who has developed a machine that can transform small clay figures into fully animated life-size figures.

Plaza mural

The Arlington Park Plaza mural, painted by local artists and UTA students, is being painted over, NBCDFW.com reported. The mural stood for more than three years in East Arlington as an anchor of urban beautification. Earlier this week, nearly 15 works of the mural were painted over with a fresh coat of brown paint.

Zoning practices

Andrew Whittemore, a former UTA assistant planning professor, published an article in CityLab on his research on zoning practices over 70 years in Durham, N.C., which suggested a correlation between zoning outcomes and the race of local legislators. Whittemore is now at UNC Chapel Hill.

Alumnus named to board

UTA alumnus Jerry Haag has been named to the board of the Christian Alliance for Orphans Lakeland Chamber of Commerce reported. Haag serves as president and CEO of Florida Baptist Children's Homes and One More Child, a leading foster care and family crises prevention agency headquartered in Lakeland, Fla., that provides services in more than 50 locations locally and globally. He earned a UTA doctorate in finance and real estate in 1995.

Alumna performs

UTA alumna Iv Amenti will be performing a celebration of afrobeat star Fela Kuti as part of the fourth season of the AT&T Performing Arts Center’s Elevator Project, TheatreJones reported. 

New business development director

UTA alumnus Justin Pruitt has been named as the city of Lubbock’s new business development director, Lubbock Online reported. Pruitt has been an assistant city attorney with the city since 2015. He has a Masters of Public Administration with an Economic Development specialty from UTA, and a law degree from Texas A&M.

Alumnus to lead association

Joel Ivy, a UTA alumnus and Lakeland Electric general manager, was named head of state municipal utility association, Florida's The Ledger reported. He earned a bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, July 18, 2018
shortDescription: Eye-movement technologyUTA has been awarded a patent for new technology that is able to scan a user’s eye movements and enable them to navigate mobile
body:
Eye-movement technology

UTA has been awarded a patent for new technology that is able to scan a user’s eye movements and enable them to navigate mobile platforms, such as electric wheelchairs, without the use of hands, KXAS NBC 5 reported. Christopher McMurrough, a UTA computer science and engineering lecturer, developed the technology. NBCDFW.com also ran the story.

Homebuyer advice

Sriram Villupuram, UTA associate professor of finance in the College of Business, said first-time homebuyers should look at ease of liquidity for that first dwelling, WalletHub.com and The Ladders reported in a question-and-answer column about first-time homebuyers. Villupuram said liquidity is important because those homebuyers eventually will upgrade homes. He said neighborhoods with a well-rated school district would be a good place to start.

Forensic drug analysis

Kevin Schug, UTA professor of chemistry and biochemistry, and Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry, compared different types of forensic drug analysis in the Chromatography Online blog, which ran on China’s antpedia.com, a professional website for scientific instruments and analytical testing.

GPISD-UTA partnership

Grand Prairie school district partnered with UTA to build an accelerated path for students to become bilingual education teachers, The Dallas Morning News reported in a story about El Centro and UNT-Dallas launching a similar partnership.

UTA alumnus finds calling

Tejay Johnson, a former TCU safety, has found his calling as a teacher and coach in the Arlington school district, the Star-Telegram reported. Johnson earned his master’s degree in education and leadership from UTA.

Student racing

Former and current UTA formula racing teams traveled to the United Kingdom to participate in FSAE events that opened the British Grand Prix, The Manufacturer reported. UTA’s 1998 FSAE car and current FSAE car raced in the event.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, July 23, 2018
shortDescription: Successful re-entryThe lack of access to transportation has been identified as a major barrier to successful re-entry for former criminal offenders. A
body:
Successful re-entry

The lack of access to transportation has been identified as a major barrier to successful re-entry for former criminal offenders. A UTA multidisciplinary research team led by Anne Nordberg, assistant professor in the School of Social Work, has been awarded a grant from the National Institute for Transportation and Communities that will link those transportation essentials to needed services like employment centers, educational opportunities and medical access, Techsite reported. 

New cancer treatment

Researchers at UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation have developed a new nanoparticle-based platform for simultaneous imaging and treatment of esophageal cancer, Cancer Week reported. "This is precision medicine," said Zui Pan, an associate professor of nursing and one of the corresponding authors of a paper about this nanoparticle published in the journal Nature Communications. 

Eye-movement technology

UTA has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that scans a user’s eye movements and enables users to navigate mobile platforms, such as electric wheelchairs, without the use of hands, Digitimes Tech of Taiwan reported. Christopher McMurrough, a UTA computer science and engineering lecturer, developed the technology.

Biden possibility

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by WBIX 950 AM in Utica, N.Y., about the possibility that Senator Joe Biden might run for President in 2020. “Joe Biden will have to beat a lot of other democratic candidates,” Saxe said. 

Driverless cars

An op-ed column in the Star-Telegram about the risks and benefits of driverless cars on Texas roads discussed the testing of these technologies along the I-30 corridor, streets in Arlington around the entertainment district and the UTA campus. Applying the technology to real-world environments like those are vital to demonstrating the success of these technologies to the public, the column said.

Video gaming

UTA’s esports captain Christian Gross was interviewed by KXAS NBC 5 about how video games could be the next step in the evolution of high school sports. Gross is working with local high schools to develop esports teams.

Alumna joins newsroom

UTA alumna and Arlington native Madelyn Edwards  is the newest addition to the Weatherford Democrat’s newsroom, the Cleborne Times-Review reported. Edwards was hired as a news reporter.

Graduate featured

UTA alumna Erin Clack’s work at Non-Violence Works was featured in The Taos News of New Mexico. She completed her Masters in Social Work with high honors at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, August 15, 2018
shortDescription: Contemporary mathDavid Jorgensen, UTA professor and associate chair of the Department of Mathematics, told KXAS NBC 5 that the University has offered
body:
Contemporary math

David Jorgensen, UTA professor and associate chair of the Department of Mathematics, told KXAS NBC 5 that the University has offered some students the option of taking a contemporary math course instead of the more traditional algebra. He said contemporary math teaches students everyday topics like mortgage rates and credit card interest. He added that UTA incorporated the contemporary math in its curriculum several years ago.

Public trust

Jim Quick, the John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy, said the Grand Prairie school district isn’t being entirely forthcoming on expenses it used for the district-owned superintendent’s house, KTVT CBS 11 reported in an investigative report concerning GPISD financial dealings. “We’re talking about a public trust, not a private company,” said Quick, who has taught ethics classes at UTA for many years. 

Smart skin

UTA has patented a smart skin, created by UTA electrical engineering professor Zeynep Çelik-Butler, that gives robots a more sensitive, tactile feeling than humans, The Robot Report and China’s Gunosy reported.

Mineral Wells project

Randy and Misty Nix have outlined their downtown vision and efforts, the Mineral Wells Index and Cleburne Times-Review reported. That vision often follows a UTA study conducted several years ago. UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs crafted the plan. The Nixes have purchased many  downtown Mineral Wells buildings.

Nursing alumna

Ben Banogu, TCU’s top-flight defensive lineman, was profiled in a Dallas Morning News story about his rapid rise to stardom. Ben’s mother, Ugochi, was quoted extensively about her son. Ugochi earned a nursing degree from UTA.

Play direction

Melanie Mason has provided steady direction in Theatre Arlington’s rendition of The Sweetest Swing in Baseball, TheaterJones.com reported. Mason is a UTA lecturer in the Department of Communication.

Psychiatrist added

Psychiatrist Nicholas Ray has joined Carris Health's Rice Memorial Hospital, Minnesota’s West Central Tribune reported. Ray received a UTA bachelor’s degree in biology.

Alumnus named loan officer

Paul Moreno was named senior loan officer at North Carolina’s Live Oak Bank, WilmingtonBiz reported. Moreno received a UTA bachelor’s degree in international business.

Chief product officer

LendingTree named Sushil Sharma its chief product officer, 360Wise.com reported. Sharma earned a UTA master’s degree in computer science and engineering.

Alumnus publishes book

Anurag P. Lakhlani makes his publishing debut with the release of Manage Your Mind, WAVE CBS 3 in Louisville, Ky., WAFB CBS 9 in Baton Rouge, La., and several other media outlets reported. The self-help book teaches readers how they can develop effective skills to manage stress in everyday life. Lakhlani has a UTA master’s degree in engineering.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, August 10, 2018
shortDescription: Smart skinUTA has patented a smart skin, created by UTA electrical engineering professor Zeynep Çelik-Butler, that gives robots more sensitive tactile
body:
Smart skin

UTA has patented a smart skin, created by UTA electrical engineering professor Zeynep Çelik-Butler, that gives robots more sensitive tactile feeling than humans experience, Engineering 360, ECN, Techsite, ZDNet, Nanowerk, Science and Technology Research News, Phys.org and many other media outlets reported.

Human services app

Rebecca Mauldin and Kathy Lee, two new UTA School of Social Work assistant professors, were winners of the Best Human Services App Idea Award at the Education and Social Development Conference in Dublin, Ireland, recently, Scienmag reported. The duo developed the SageServe app to provide older adults with opportunities to strengthen existing social roles and develop new ones by connecting them to online-based volunteer opportunities.

More efficient computer access

Song Jiang, a UTA associate professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, is working on a National Science Foundation program that will make accessing data more efficient, NewsEdge.com reported.

Highest research

UTA is one of three universities in North Texas to earn the Carnegie classification of R1 Highest Research Activity, Dallas Innovates reported. The article said these institutions attract the brightest minds, research funding and original solutions to some of today’s most complex problems.

Land rights

The U.S. Supreme Court struck a blow to private property owners in a decision that allowed the city of New London, Conn., to take the property of Suzette Kelo for a private development project, UTA economist Roger Meiners wrote in a Washington Examiner opinion piece. Meiners is a UTA professor and the chair of economics. He co-wrote the piece with Terry Anderson, a senior fellow at Stanford’s Hoover Institution.

Dems did well

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said in a KLIF 570 AM interview that the Democrats did well in an Ohio special election for a congressional seat, a district that Republicans typically control.

Minority contractors

UTA leadership helped spread the word that minority contractors could be a part of the Texas Live! construction, the North Dallas Gazette reported in an article highlighting minority firms that were a part of the project.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, July 9, 2018
shortDescription: Nanoparticle researchResearchers at UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation have developed a new nanoparticle-based platform for simultaneous i
body:
Nanoparticle research

Researchers at UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation have developed a new nanoparticle-based platform for simultaneous imaging and treatment of esophageal cancer, Science Daily, News-Medical.net, Medical Xpress, Sina News of Tawian and DuoWei News of China reported. "This is precision medicine," said Zui Pan, an associate professor of nursing and one of the corresponding authors of a nanoparticle paper, published in the journal Nature Communications this month. 

Eye-tracking device

A new head-worn device from UTA is designed to facilitate user communication to a robotic platform when food or water, or other objects, are required, Electronics 360 reported. "My interest in this technology grew out of seeing how my mother-in-law struggled with eye-tracking devices as an ALS patient," said inventor Christopher McMurrough, a UTA computer science and engineering lecturer.

Gun violence panel

UTA student Waed Alhayek participated in a panel on gun violence at Paul Quinn College that forms part of the Road to Change tour organized by March For Our Lives activists, The Dallas Morning News and WFAA ABC 8 reported. "This issue is so much bigger than just schools," Alhayek said. "People don't feel safe anywhere."

Ogden sets goals

UTA Maverick men’s basketball coach Chris Ogden set some high standards for the team in an interview with The Dallas Morning News, just three months after taking on his new job. “Our goal every single year, and we don’t hide from it, we don’t run from it, we talk about it, is to play in the NCAA tournament,” Ogden said. “Anything less than that will be a disappointment for us.”

Evaluating forensic drug analysis

Kevin Schug, UTA professor of chemistry and biochemistry, and Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry, compared different types of forensic drug analysis in the Chromatography Online blog.

Cuba exhibit

David LaFevor, UTA assistant professor of history, will showcase a new exhibit, Cuba: Histories of the Present, through Aug. 3 in gallery space at Artes de la Rosa, 1140 N. Main St., in Fort Worth, the Fort Worth Weekly reported. LaFevor uses the nearly 17 years of his travels to Cuba for his extraordinary images.

UTA alumnus named dean

George Nnanna said he was eager to start as dean of the UT Permian Basin College of Engineering, the Odessa American reported. Nnanna earned his master’s and doctoral degrees from UTA in mechanical engineering.

Dallas Mavericks should change design

Mark Lamster, UTA architecture professor and architecture critic for The Dallas Morning News, wrote a column about how the Dallas Mavericks NBA team needs to update its design and uniforms.

Video game lounge

DFW International Airport now has video game lounges, KDAF CW 33 reported. The story mentioned UTA’s Esports team, which competes on a national level, and that the city of Arlington is building an Esports arena.

Transportation alternatives

App-based transportation options offer low-income users a viable alternative to becoming more mobile, the Jordan Times reported in a column written by Lynn Malkawi, a UTA MBA alumna.

Police chief retires

After a nearly 50-year career in law enforcement, Bartlesville, Okla., Police Chief Tom Holland will retire, the Bartlesville Examiner-Enterprise reported. Holland received his bachelor’s degree in political science from UTA in 1970, with minors in history and criminal justice.

Weber named to board

Greater Community Bank named Peter Weber of Calhoun to its board of directors, Northwest Georgia News reported. Weber is a UTA alumnus.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, July 11, 2018
shortDescription: Optimizing power gridRamtin Madani, an assistant professor in UTA's Electrical Engineering Department, recently was awarded a $325,000 grant from the
body:
Optimizing power grid

Ramtin Madani, an assistant professor in UTA's Electrical Engineering Department, recently was awarded a $325,000 grant from the National Science Foundation to develop massively scalable computational methods to increase the efficiency, reliability and security of the national power grid, Energy Central News, World Industrial Reporter and Techsite reported.

Keeping corals healthy

Laura Mydlarz, UTA associate professor of biology, said coral immunity scholars hope to see a shift to what keeps corals healthy – not just what makes them sick, Popular Science and Vaaju.com reported in a story about a new research paper on that subject.

New cancer treatment

UTA researchers at the College of Nursing and Health Innovation have developed a new nanoparticle-based platform for simultaneous imaging and treatment of esophageal cancer, ChinaGate.com, ecancernews, Science and Technology Research News and other websites reported. Zui Pan, an associate professor of nursing and one of the authors of the paper on this nanoparticle, said the long-term goals of the research are to help prevent this tumor from forming and to find better, safer and more targeted treatments for esophageal cancer.

Eye movement navigation

UTA has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that is able to scan a user’s eye movements and enable them to navigate mobile platforms, such as electric wheelchairs, Greece’s news.makedonias and MobiHealthNews reported. Christopher McMurrough, a UTA  computer science and engineering lecturer, developed the technology.

Supreme Court nominee discussion

UTA’s Allan Saxe, associate professor of political science, said he was a little surprised at President Trump’s selection of Brett Kavanaugh as his Supreme Court Justice nominee, KTRH 730 AM reported. Saxe said he thought Trump might have picked a woman like Amy Coney Barrett, a circuit judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, to be the nominee. Saxe also was heard on KLIF 570 AM, WBAP 820 AM and Cincinnati’s WLW 700 AM about the Kavanaugh appointment.

UTA at British Grand Prix

Former and current UTA formula SAE racing teams are in the United Kingdom to participate and race in opening festivities at the Great Britain Grand Prix, Arlington-tx.gov reported. UTA’s 1998 FSAE car will race with the original team as part of the festivities.

Political movies

Bart Weiss, UTA associate professor of film in art and art history, writes that politics and movies about politics might soothe people or spur them to take action in his Theater Jones monthly column. Weiss rattles off many of the all-time great movies that center on politics as well as some movies that are more obscure.

White-collar dreamers

Alex Medrano was one of the dreamers profiled in a Bloomberg story about the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, an Obama administration program that President Trump has signed an order to end. The story was about while-collar Dreamers. Medrano took business classes at UTA. The story also ran on msn.com and The Malaysian Reserve.

Movin' Mavs host event

The UTA Movin’ Mavs and the Arlington Mayor's Committee on People with Disabilities will host the Ability Experience Journey of Hope South cycling team for the 22nd year on Friday, July 13, at the Maverick Activities Center, U.S. Fed News reported. Journey of Hope cyclists are traveling from Los Angeles to Washington, D.C., on their cross-county trip across America. Both the 10 a.m. welcome and the 1 p.m. wheelchair basketball game are free and open to the public.

UTA hosts ArlingCon

UTA played host to the Arlington Public Library’s ArlingCon, a recent annual pop culture convention, U.S. Fed News reported.

UTA alumna appointed

Gov. Greg Abbott appointed Rossy Fariña-Strauss to the State Pension Review Board, the Houston-based Guidry News reported. Fariña-Strauss received a UTA bachelor’s degree in architecture.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, July 13, 2018
shortDescription: Eye-movement technologyUTA has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that scans a user’s eye movements and enables them to navigate
body:
Eye-movement technology

UTA has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that scans a user’s eye movements and enables them to navigate mobile platforms, such as electric wheelchairs, without the use of hands, KDAF CW 33 reported. Christopher McMurrough, a UTA  computer science and engineering lecturer, developed the technology. CW33.com also ran the story.

Improving the grid

Ramtin Madani, an assistant professor in UTA's Electrical Engineering Department, recently was awarded a $325,000 grant from the National Science Foundation to develop massively scalable computational methods to increase the efficiency, reliability and security of the national power grid, phys.org and chemeurope.com reported.

Sprawl drawbacks

Recently published studies show that urban sprawl reduces life expectancy and doesn’t attract knowledge-intensive businesses, Politics & Government Week reported. Shima Hamidi, UTA assistant professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, and two directors of the National Institutes of Health did the sprawl study, while Hamidi teamed with Ahoura Zandiatashbar, a UTA research associate, to write about how sprawl affects efforts to attract the knowledge economy.

Student award

Theresa Arias, who will complete her master of arts in history with an archival administration certificate from UTA this summer, has been selected in the first cohort of Florida State University’s Diversity Resident Librarian Program, U.S. Fed News reported.

Ad slogan

University of Wyoming professors are opposing that university’s new ad slogan, “The World Needs More Cowboys,” a Star-Telegram opinion piece said. The writer believes the new slogan isn’t disrespectful or sexist, and isn’t that much different than UTA’s campaign to “Be a Maverick.”

New principal

Edwin Hood was named principal of Lincoln Elementary School, Iowa’s Cedar Valley Business Monthly reported. Hood earned his superintendent certification at UTA.

Basketball family

Fort Worth’s first family of basketball, Keith and Kevin Langford and Justin Wesley, were featured in a Star-Telegram profile. The brothers’ mom, Charlene Taylor, played basketball at UTA, as did her ex-husband.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, August 17, 2018
shortDescription: UTA professor leads pain advisory groupRobert Gatchel, UTA Distinguished Professor of Psychology and Nancy P. and John G. Penson Endowed Professor of
body:
UTA professor leads pain advisory group

Robert Gatchel, UTA Distinguished Professor of Psychology and Nancy P. and John G. Penson Endowed Professor of Clinical Health Psychology, led a federal advisory group that published recommendations on the prevention of acute and chronic pain to the Federal Research Pain Strategy, Scienmag, Medicine Newsline and Medical Xpress reported. The strategy is an interagency committee that oversees the government's long-term strategic plan to support pain research.

Smart skin

UTA has patented a smart skin, created by UTA electrical engineering professor Zeynep Çelik-Butler, that gives robots a more sensitive, tactile feeling than humans, ASEE’s First Bell, Edgy Labs, Germany’s Ingenieur.de and Turkey’s Future Notes reported. ASEE is the American Society for Engineering Education.

Remembering the Queen of Soul

UTA’s Jamar Jones reminisced about playing with Aretha Franklin yesterday, WFAA ABC 8 reported. Jones, a lecturer of music industry studies at UTA and an alumnus, played with the Queen of Soul several times in his career as a pianist. Franklin died yesterday. He said that with Franklin’s passing, “It’s like we’ve lost a diamond.”

ICARUS project

UTA professors, researchers and students are busy readying the data acquisition system for the ICARUS project, which recently has been moved to its new Fermilab home in Illinois, NewsEdge.com reported.

Transparency key to public institution

Jim Quick, the John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy, said transparency is a key for a public institution, KTVT CBS 11 reported in an investigative report on the financial dealings of Grand Prairie school district. “You ask the question, you put it out on the table and you figure out what’s the right thing to do,” Quick said.

Doctoral fellowship

Marialis Rosario-Franco, a UTA doctoral student in physics, has been awarded the Gröte Reber Doctoral Fellowship from the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, a facility of the National Science Foundation, Scienmag reported.

Professor elected Fellow

Mark Haykowsky, a UTA nursing professor and leading expert in exercise physiology and heart failure rehabilitation, has been elected a Fellow of the American College of Cardiology, Cancer Weekly reported.

App helps elderly

Kathy Lee and Rebecca Mauldin, who will start in the fall semester as assistant professors in the School of Social Work, began developing the SageServe app for aging-related services, Clinical Trials Week reported. The duo won the Best Human Services App Idea Award for their idea at the Education and Social Development Conference in Dublin, Ireland, recently.

Lady Movin' Mavs players in championships

Lady Movin’ Mavs Rose Hollermann and Abby Dunkin, seniors and gold medalists in the 2016 Paralympic games, along with graduate student Morgan Wood, are set to represent Team USA in the 2018 International Wheelchair Basketball Federation’s World Championships in Hamburg, Germany, ArlingtonTX.gov reported. The championships run through Aug. 26.

Alumna named dean

Pamela Holland Obiomon was named dean of Prairie View A&M University’s Roy G. Perry College of Engineering, USBE Information Technology Magazine reported. Obiomon earned her UTA bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering.

New principal

Karina Lopez was named principal of Houston’s Edison Middle School, Houston ISD’s blog said. Lopez earned her UTA master’s degree in educational leadership and policy studies.

Alumnus appointed

Texas Gov. Greg Abbott appointed Feyi Obamehinti to the Texas Diabetes Council, NewsEdge.com reported. Obamehinti received a UTA bachelor’s degree in microbiology.

CEO talks to alumni

Brian Coltharp, president and CEO of Freese and Nichols, talked about his business career to UTA’s Alumni Association, Fort Worth chapter, at its August luncheon, Freese.com reported. Coltharp is a 1992 UTA graduate in civil engineering.

Column warns of future meetings

People may have to work with or for bullies from previous life experiences, Marti Harvey wrote in a Dallas Morning News op-ed column. She suggested some strategies on handling awkward situations like that. Harvey is a lecturer for UTA’s Department of Communication.

Alumna profiled

Ashley Whitt was profiled in LENSCRATCH, a publication about fine art photography. Whitt is a UTA graduate.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, August 20, 2018
shortDescription: Questions remainUTA physics Professor Manfred Cuntz was featured in a Forbes article about questions that make astrobiologists squirm, such as the puz
body:
Questions remain

UTA physics Professor Manfred Cuntz was featured in a Forbes article about questions that make astrobiologists squirm, such as the puzzles around extraterrestrial life. “We do not fully understand the origin of life; the transformation of non-living matter to living matter,” Cuntz said. "This lack of knowledge is also limiting our abiltity to identify habitable worlds beyond earth." 

CLEAR to host conference

Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation or CLEAR labs, is hosting the second annual Responsible Shale Energy Extraction Conference at UTA Oct. 12-13, Petro Industry News reported. The conference will be held in UTA’s new Science & Engineering Innovation & Research building.

Pain advisory group

UTA psychology Professor Robert Gatchel led a federal advisory group on the prevention of acute and chronic pain, Dallas Innovates and Health Medicine Network reported. “Our main conclusion is that better public education to heighten awareness about pain and its health consequences, and to teach individuals to manage their own pain, would make the greatest short-term impact,” Gatchel said.

Anti-malaria video

Daniel Sledge, UTA associate professor of political science, discussed a 1943 anti-malaria video, produced by Walt Disney for the U.S. government and starring the Seven Dwarfs, on WFDD 85.5 in Winston-Salem, NC. "It's very practical," he said. "Avoiding standing water is really critical. Screening windows is really critical." In his research, Sledge has focused on malaria control and eradication in the United States, particularly before 1950.

Scholarship recipient

UTA student Shelby Young received a $500 scholarship from The Citizens Fire & Public Safety Volunteer Association, the Copperas Cove Leader-Press reported. 

Alumnus featured

UTA alumnus Adam Martin was featured in a Texas Banking profile on how he became a banker in Central Texas' Killeen. He is now senior vice president for commercial lending at First National Bank Texas. 

Alumnus elected chair

UTA alumnus Skip Ogle was elected chair of the Tyler Area Chamber of Commerce, the Tyler Morning Telegraph reported. Ogle graduated UTA with a bachelor’s degree in architecture and a master's degree in city and regional planning. 

Alumna named engineering dean

UTA alumna Pamela Holland Obiomon, a professor of electrical and microelectronic engineering at Prairie View A&M University in Texas, has been named dean of the Roy G. Perry College of Engineering at Prairie View A&M University, the Journal of Blacks in Higher Education reported. Professor Obiomon holds a bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, August 27, 2018
shortDescription: Hydrogel grantUTA bioengineering professor Yi Hong has won a new $460,000 grant from the National Institutes of Health to develop a bioactive hydrogel
body:
Hydrogel grant

UTA bioengineering professor Yi Hong has won a new $460,000 grant from the National Institutes of Health to develop a bioactive hydrogel to repair heart tissue, News-Medical.net, Phys.org, Biospectrum India and Targeted News Service reported. "We are working on a new biodegradable and bioactive hydrogel material that could be injected into the heart to promote cardiac repair after a heart attack," Hong said. 

Fighting pathogens

Mark Pellegrino, UTA assistant professor of biology, is lead investigator on a five-year, $1.8 million grant from the National Institutes of Health that is looking for new ways to enable the body’s own defense responses to fight pathogens, Dallas Innovates and Homeland Preparedness News reported. “My team is looking to harness the way mitochondria defend themselves to generate new ways to both boost innate immunity and improve resistance to infections,” Pellegrino said.

UTA physicist selected

Ramon Lopez, a UTA physics professor, has been selected as one of the recipients of Great Minds in STEM's 2018 Education Award, Targeted News Service reported. Great Minds in STEM is a nonprofit organization dedicated to keeping America technologically strong by promoting science, technology, engineering and math, or STEM, careers, especially in underserved communities.

Lecturer interviewed

UTA lecturer Charles Hermes was interviewed by the Star-Telegram about the City of Fort Worth’s notice on its website about reporting "unusual activity" that could be signs of domestic terrorism to the Fort Worth Police Department Homeland Security's new hotline. Some residents have concerns with the message this sends to marginalized communities and communities of color. "Reporting 'anything suspicious' is deeply troubling not only because of the national and state context, but because of the Fort Worth context," Hermes said. 

SPJ chapter honored

The Society of Professional Journalists selected UTA’s SPJ chapter as the Region 8 representative that has shown overall excellence, Targeted News Service reported.  SPJ also honored UTA campus programming around Sexual Assault Awareness Month.

Effect on esports

UTA student Christian Gross was interviewed by WFAA ABC 8 about the shooting at an esports competition in Florida yesterday. Gross said that the actions of one “unstable kid” would not have long-term effects on the sport. 

Unusual instruments

Billi London-Gray, a 2018 graduate of UTA's Master of Fine Arts Intermedia Studio program and a lecturer in the Department of Art and Art History, has won a Puffin Foundation grant for her ongoing project, The Loop and Saw Choir, Targeted News Service reported. Her project consists of workshops, jam sessions and performances in which she collaborates with volunteers of all ages and abilities to make music and sound art using musical saws, analog synthesizers, human voices, homemade instruments and looping devices.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, July 30, 2018
shortDescription: Technology ready for marketUTA senior lecturer Christopher McMurrough was inspired by his mother-in-law’s ALS to design goggles with 3-D video and eye
body:
Technology ready for market

UTA senior lecturer Christopher McMurrough was inspired by his mother-in-law’s ALS to design goggles with 3-D video and eye tracking that enable people unable to speak and move to communicate directly what they need or are interested in, WFAA ABC 8, WMAZ CBS 13 in Macon, Ga., and WBIR NBC 10 in Knoxville, Tenn., reported. The technology has just received a patent and McMurrough, who teaches in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, is now looking for investors to help bring it to the market. 

Alzheimer's help

Noelle Fields, UTA assistant professor in the School of Social Work, is developing an in-home psychoeducational intervention program for people with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia, ClinicalTrials.gov reported. The Senior Companion Program Plus is accessible, sustainable and affordable.

Invasive zebra mussels

UTA research on zebra mussels was cited in an article in the Rivard Report about the invasive threat of the mussels growing in Canyon Lake. UTA researchers observed three Texas lakes – Texoma, Ray Roberts and Belton – and found that a rapid increase in zebra mussel numbers was followed by a steep decline.

Consider COE

As potential students explore their options for pursuing an undergraduate degree, The University of Texas at Arlington’s College of Engineering should rise to the top of their list, Study International reported. Located in the Dallas-Fort Worth metro area, UTA is the most comprehensive engineering school in the region.

New executive VP

Union Pacific has appointed Lynden Tennison executive vice president and chief strategy officer, The American Journal of Transportation and ENP Newswire reported. Tennison has a bachelor’s degree from UTA. 

Alumnus opens tiki place

J.P. Hunter, a UTA alumnus nearing retirement in the construction business in Houston, has opened 4 Kahunas, a real live tiki joint in Arlington, The Dallas Morning News’ GuideLive reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, July 6, 2018
shortDescription: Eye movement technologyThe University of Texas at Arlington has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that scans users' eye movemen
body:
Eye movement technology

The University of Texas at Arlington has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that scans users' eye movements and enables them to navigate mobile platforms, such as electric wheelchairs, without the use of hands, Canada’s New Atlas, Russia’s Vesti, Greece’s Palo.gr, China’s cnBeta.com, Medical Product Outsourcing, Dallas Innovates, Phys.org, Techsite and many other websites reported.

Sprawl lessens life expectancy

Recently published studies show that urban sprawl reduces life expectancy of its inhabitants and doesn’t attract knowledge-intensive businesses, Medicine newsline, ScienceDaily, BrightSurf.com, Techsite and other websites reported. Shima Hamidi, UTA assistant professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, and two directors of the National Institutes of Health did the sprawl-life expectancy study, while Hamidi teamed with Ahoura Zandiatashbar, a UTA research associate, to write about how sprawl affects attracting the knowledge economy.

Finding best practices

Daniel Sledge and Herschel Thomas, UTA associate and assistant professor of political science, respectively, received a National Science Foundation grant to report best practices from response and recovery efforts in U.S. natural disasters, Dallas Innovates reported.

Deen talks Supreme Court

Rebecca Deen, chair and associate professor of the UTA Department of Political Science, offered expert insight about President Trump’s upcoming U.S. Supreme Court nominee on KERA 90.1’s Think program. Trump will nominate someone to replace the retiring Judge Anthony Kennedy.

Frequent flyer advice

Abdul Rasheed, chair of the UTA Department of Management in the College of Business, offered advice about frequent flyer miles and airline credit cards in a question-and-answer column for WalletHub. Rasheed also is the Eunice and James L. West Distinguished Professor at UTA.

Foreign students a plus

A Dallas Morning News column said foreign-born graduates boost the region’s economy and colleges. The column mentioned UTA’s number of international students and graduates.

Immigrant fundraiser

A UTA student is organizing the Migration is Sweet event at 7:30 p.m. Friday at The Wild Detectives in Dallas’ Bishop Arts District, The Dallas Morning News reported. Jennifer Hernandez, a 22-year-old UTA student, said the Dallas fundraiser combines her concern for immigrants with her family’s love of Mexican pastries.

Anarchist movement

Kenyon Zimmer, UTA associate professor of history, has written a comprehensive treatment of the American anarchist movement, People’s World reported. It is a volume in the series Working Class in American History, edited by a team of renowned scholars. Zimmer’s six chapters, plus an introduction and conclusion, span political ideologies like Zionism, fascism, socialism, unionism and communism.

Arlington's 4th of July festivities

KDFW Fox 4, KRLD 1080 AM and Patch.com previewed Arlington’s 4th of July Parade, which included part of the UTA campus. In another story, Andrew Campbell, who is a downtown Arlington business owner and UTA alumnus, was looking forward to the city’s fireworks and parade events on July 3 and 4, KRLD 1080 AM reported. Campbell said Arlington is becoming a destination for Independence Day events.

Amputee research

Erick Jones Sr., a UTA professor of industrial, manufacturing and systems engineering, contributed to a study that explains how electromagnetic fields amplify pain in amputees, everythingRF reported. Mario Romero-Ortega, a UT Dallas associate professor and former UTA associate professor, led the study.

Hervey a surprise

On Point Basketball reported that UTA’s Kevin Hervey could be one of the steals of this year’s NBA draft. Hervey was picked in the second round by the Oklahoma City Thunder.

Top students pick UTA

Ten valedictorians and salutatorians from Dallas County high schools will be attending UTA next fall, aldiadallas reported.

Right-sizing home

A Dallas Morning News story offered five examples of families right-sizing to find the best home for various points in their lives. Richard and Barrie Page Hill of Arlington have made two moves as Barrie's 84-year-old mother, Bobbi Wilburn, joined the household and later as their daughter left for college. Barrie Page Hill is an academic adviser in the Department of Communication.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, August 29, 2018
shortDescription: Infrastructures centerThe NSF Center for Integration of Composites into Infrastructure, of which UTA is a partner institution, is emphasizing its adva
body:
Infrastructures center

The NSF Center for Integration of Composites into Infrastructure, of which UTA is a partner institution, is emphasizing its advanced fiber-reinforced polymer composites and techniques for rapid repair, upgrading, rehabilitation or replacement of many types of infrastructure at the CAMX 2018 conference, Composites World reported. 

Music chair featured

Dan Cavanagh, chair and professor of UTA’s Department of Music, was featured in a City of Arlington American Dream profile. “As a musician, as a professor, as someone who believes in higher education, this has been a fantastic place to be,” Cavanagh said.

Shakespeare in the Park

Felicia Bertch, a faculty member in UTA’s Fine Arts Program, has participated each year since 2013 in Wheaton's Shakespeare in the Park, suburban Chicago's The Daily Herald reported. 

Affordable online degree

EDsmart, a nationally recognized publisher of college resources and rankings, has named UTA one of Most Affordable Online Master’s Programs for its 2018-19 edition, Digital Journal reported. The ranking includes only fully accredited schools that offer a master's program online.

Biden could face competition

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said former Vice President Joe Biden will face a lot of competition before he could reach the point of nomination, and that he would be a centrist candidate in a party that is moving sharply to the left, WIBX 950 AM in Utica, N.Y., reported.

Appointed chief nursing officer

Norman Regional Health System appointed UTA alumna Brittni McGill, MSN, RN, its permanent chief nursing officer, The Oklahoman reported. She holds a master of science in nursing administration degree from UTA.

Alumna named partner

Beth Looney, previously an assurance director in BDO USA's Fort Worth office, has been named a partner, Fort Worth Business reported. BDO is an accounting and consulting firm. Looney earned her master's and bachelor's degrees in accounting from UTA.

Lumpkin earns mentor award

Tom Lumpkin, director of the Tom Love Division of Entrepreneurship and Economic Development and C. S. Trosper Chair and Professor of Entrepreneurship at the Michael F. Price College of Business at the University of Oklahoma, recently received an international mentor award at the Academy of Management’s annual meeting, The Norman Transcript reported. He received his doctoral degree in business administration from UTA. 

Alumnus appointed executive director

Liu Xianfu has been appointed as an executive director of Fountain Set Holdings Limited in Hong Kong, hkexnews.hk reported. He received his executive master's business administration degree from UTA. 

UTA graduate named finalist

Christy Martinez, assistant chief of the Grand Prairie Police Department, is a finalist for Chief of Police in Denton, NBCDFW.com reported.  She holds a bachelor's degree in criminal justice and criminology from UTA. 

State finalist

Tim Harkrider, who has been superintendent of Willis ISD for five years, was selected as state finalist for the annual Superintendent of the Year, KCBD NBC 11 in Lubbock reported. He holds a master's degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, July 2, 2018
shortDescription: Valedictorians, salutatorians headed to UTATen valedictorians and salutatorians from Dallas County high schools will be attending UTA next fall, The D
body:
Valedictorians, salutatorians headed to UTA

Ten valedictorians and salutatorians from Dallas County high schools will be attending UTA next fall, The Dallas Morning News reported. 

Dems could control House after election

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said on WBAP 820 AM that there is a good chance that the Democrats may take control of the House of Representatives during the upcoming mid-term elections. He also said there are divisions within the Democratic party between the left and the radical left that might make that takeover more difficult.

Alumnus named manager

UTA student Larry Coffman has been named operating room manager by Saint Francis Healthcare System, the Southeast Missourian reported. He holds an associate degree in nursing sciences and is earning a bachelor's degree in nursing at UTA.

Hervey selected

The Oklahoma City Thunder selected UTA Maverick basketball forward Kevin Hervey with the 57th pick in the NBA draft, KTVT CBS 11 reported. He is the fourth player from UTA ever drafted into the NBA. 

Abbott names UTA alumnus

Gov. Greg Abbott has appointed UTA alumnus Vince Puente Sr. to the finance commission of Texas, GuidryNews.com reported. Puente is co-owner and president of marketing and sales for Southwest Office Systems Inc. He is a member of the board of directors for the YMCA of Metropolitan Dallas, Dallas Regional Chamber and Texas Values, a group that supports family values in the state.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, August 22, 2018
shortDescription: New ecosystemUTA President Vistasp Karbhari published an article in The Evolllution about the need for a re-envisioned higher education ecosystem with
body:
New ecosystem

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari published an article in The Evolllution about the need for a re-envisioned higher education ecosystem with better alignment with the labor market, faster and more flexible program development models, improved personalization and customization of the academic experience, and a greater focus on lifelong learning. 

Leg exercises

New research led by UTA kinesiology professor Paul Fadel shows that simple leg exercises could reduce impact of sedentary lifestyles on heart and blood vessels, The Physiological Society, The MiceTimes of Asia and Archyworlds reported. Fadel and his team recently published a research paper on this subject in Experimental Physiology. 

Institutional changes needed

James Campbell Quick, the John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in UTA’s Goolsby Leadership Academy, was cited in an Associated Press article about how institutions could better manage sexual abuse. What matters, he said, is how problems are tackled by the leadership, who need to set the tone about what behaviors are inappropriate. The Washington Post also ran the AP story. 

Fighting pathogens

A UTA researcher has won a five-year, $1.8 million grant from the National Institutes of Health to look at new ways to harness the body's own defense responses to fight pathogens like bacteria, Targeted News Service reported. "My team is looking to harness the way mitochondria defend themselves to generate new ways to both boost innate immunity and improve resistance to infections,” said Mark Pellegrino, the UTA assistant professor of biology who is leading the project.

Industry funding

A UTA faculty member has connected with blockchain provider Komodo to support student competition, Phys.org reported. The agreement, signed by Sajib Datta, a senior lecturer in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, provides funding for an annual blockchain competition at UTA, funding for two senior design projects, and scholarships for two undergraduate and two graduate students for two semesters.

Transportation guide

Diane Jones Allen, UTA associate professor, program director of landscape architecture and principal at DesignJones LLC, was a member of advisory panel that developed a new guide on transportation launched today by the American Society of Landscape Architects, AECCafe, Fleet News Daily and many other media reported. 

UTA NAACP chapter wins

UTA’s NAACP chapter won best overall in the nation for juvenile justice advocacy, The Dallas Examiner reported. The Texas NAACP Youth and College Division swept the NAACP Idea Lab competition, themed “Buying Black,” leading with 10 awards at its 109th annual convention in San Antonio last month.

Alumna featured

UTA alumna Pratima Rao Gluckman was featured in Great Leadership discussing the importance of fearless leadership. Gluckman, author of “Nevertheless, She Persisted: True Stories of Women Leaders in Tech,” knew she wanted to be an engineer from a young age. She attained a master's degree in computer science and engineering from UTA. 

New Aflac president

UTA alumna Teresa White, the first woman and African-American to hold the title of president of Aflac, is the founder of Bold Moves, a program of Girls Inc. to inspire another generation of girls to meet their full potential, MyAJC reported. She earned a UTA bachelor's degree in business administration.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, July 20, 2018
shortDescription: Eye-movement patentUTA has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that scans a user’s eye movements and enables the user to navigate
body:
Eye-movement patent

UTA has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that scans a user’s eye movements and enables the user to navigate mobile platforms, such as electric wheelchairs, without the use of hands, ASEE’s First Bell and Greece’s Athens Magazine reported. ASEE is the American Society for Engineering Education. Christopher McMurrough, a UTA computer science and engineering lecturer, developed the technology.

Rethinking higher education

Universities must radically rethink how access, excellence and impact are brought together, UTA President Vistasp Karbhari wrote in an opinion piece for The EvoLLLution, a higher education publication. He said transforming the university to serve a global, knowledge-based society is being done today at a number of institutions, including UTA, where faculty are driving change at an unprecedented pace, engaging social, economic, technological and market forces to adapt to the world of tomorrow—as we meet the present and future needs of our students today.

Archiving Cuba

The British Library Endangered Archives Programme has extended a UTA-led project to digitize colonial documents in Cuba by another six months as part of its global initiative to preserve endangered documents relating to pre-industrial societies, Phys.org, Infosurhoy, Press TV and Techsite reported.

Fair housing assessment

After extensively analyzing fair housing in North Texas, UTA researchers have discovered that in many cases, segregation and associated problems are becoming more pronounced, Phys.org reported. The North Texas Regional Housing Assessment analysis included 22 cities and housing authorities across North Texas. It shows empirically that public housing segregation is embedded racially and economically, keeping those residents largely in the same living quarters with no hope of gaining ground.

Brain injury research

Two UTA researchers studying traumatic brain injury were featured in Texas Health Journal, a UT System publication. Ashfaq Adnan, associate professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering, and Michael Cho, the Alfred R. and Janet H. Potvin Endowed Chair in Bioengineering, are using two Office of Naval Research grants to conduct the research.

Climate disasters

The United States has just completed a record year for weather and climate disasters and, by most accounts, it's only going to get worse, The Dallas Morning News reported in an article that included research from UTA’s Arne Winguth, an earth and environmental science associate professor. "While the state highway system was built above flooding levels, the connector roads may be easily flooded," said Winguth, who co-authored the report. The Morning News reran the story, which originally ran on Feb. 15.

Neutrino research

UTA physicists are leading a global team to discover why the universe is full of matter, South Dakota’s Rapid City Journal reported. The UTA researchers, led by Professor Jaehoon Yu, have completed a prototype detector focused on a tiny particle called the neutrino, which may hold the answer to this question. The Dallas Morning News originally reported the story.

Democrat hopefuls

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, predicted that former Vice President Joe Biden could become the Democrats’ hopeful to unseat President Donald Trump in 2020, WFLA 970 AM in Tampa Bay, Fla., reported. Saxe said U.S. Sens. Kamala Harris of California and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts also could vie for the nomination. Saxe added that U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Hillary Clinton, former Secretary of State, could run, too.

Simmons Park plans

The 200-acre Harold Simmons Park between the Trinity River levees is moving forward, D Magazine reported. The article mentioned Kevin Sloan, UTA assistant professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, who has written extensively about re-wilding the river.

New area superintendent

James McSwain was named area superintendent for the Houston school district, the HISD News blog reported. McSwain received his Bachelor of Arts degree in history from UTA.

Alumna named senior VP

Lori Bradley has been named senior vice president for talent management and organizational effectiveness, eTurboNews, Markets Insider, AviationPros and other media outlets reported. Bradley earned her master's degree in English/Critical Theory from UTA.

UTA graduate in Weatherford

Madelyn Edwards, an Arlington native and recent UTA graduate, is the newest addition to the Weatherford Democrat’s newsroom, the Weatherford Democrat reported. While at UTA, Edwards worked for the college’s newspaper, The Shorthorn.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, September 5, 2018
shortDescription: Contamination cleanupHyeok Choi, a UTA associate professor of civil engineering, will use a U.S. Department of Defense grant to create a system that w
body:
Contamination cleanup

Hyeok Choi, a UTA associate professor of civil engineering, will use a U.S. Department of Defense grant to create a system that will allow easier cleanup of contaminated soil and water that the U.S. military has identified, Phys.org reported.

Hydrogel project
