Yi Hong, a UTA bioengineering associate professor, is working on a National Institutes of Health grant to develop a new biodegradable, bioactive hydrogel that could repair cardiac tissue following a heart attack, Dallas Innovates reported.

Understanding differences

Wayne Crawford, UTA assistant professor of management, and colleagues have applied the self-verification theory to better understand discrepancies between the way people actually present themselves and the way others perceive them, Psychology Today reported on the team's recent study. The theory says that meeting someone for the first time can offer rare insights into a person's psychological makeup.

West campus buildings open

UTA opened two new west campus buildings – West Hall, the university’s newest residence hall, and The Commons, a place for students, faculty, staff and community members to eat and meet, U.S. Fed News and Arlington Voice reported.

Purple Heart University

UTA was designated a Purple Heart University at a recent ceremony by the Military Order of the Purple Heart, NewsEdge.com reported.

Prestigious fellowship

Shannon Beston, a UTA doctoral student in biology, has been awarded a prestigious American Association of University Women Fellowship to fund her dissertation project, Scienmag reported. The project evaluates the ecological drivers of eye and brain size evolution in a species of fish.

Signs, polls matter less

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said signs and polls have become less of an issue in political races, KLIF 570 AM reported in an extensive interview with the professor about the Ted Cruz-Beto O’Rourke race. He cited the Donald Trump-Hillary Clinton race as evidence that signs and polls are meaning less and less. Saxe also was featured on WBAP 820 AM concerning the U.S. Senate race.

Photography professor on panel

Kenda North, UTA photography professor, will serve on a panel discussion of “What is a Professional Artist: Ingredients of a Successful Career” 4-6 p.m. Friday, Sept. 7, at the Turner House in Dallas, Canada’s Penticton Herald, New York’s Albany Times Union, AXcessnews.com and other websites reported.

Alumnus profiled

Chidozie Menakaya was profiled about his unplanned adventure in Alaska, which translated into a pharmacist’s job, the Fairbanks Daily News-Miner reported. Menakaya earned a UTA bachelor of science degree in biology.

Student in transportation story

UTA student Marvin Tran was featured in a transportation story about Via, Arlington’s on-demand ride service, Ars Technica and Preston Business Review reported.

UTA student named top teacher

Alejandra Ortega has been named Houston’s Teacher of the Year in her second year in the classroom, Alcalde reported. Ortega is working toward her master’s in educational leadership and policy studies from UTA, which she expects to finish in December.

Alumna appointed chief nursing officer

Brittni McGill has been appointed chief nursing officer for the Norman Regional Health System, Lady Click reported. She holds a master of science in nursing administration degree from UTA.

Alumnus profiled

Dallas architect Ajay Kothari was profiled in a D Magazine article. Kothari is a UTA architecture alumnus. His ties to the late spiritual leader Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh also were highlighted. Those ties have been popularized in the recent Netflix docuseries Wild Wild Country.

New senior VP

Chris Hanrattie has been promoted to Crescent Real Estate LLC’s senior vice president of investments, EIN Presswire and Arizona’s Tucson News Now reported. Hanrattie earned his bachelor’s and master’s degrees in business administration from UTA.

Doctoral graduate to conduct talk

“Little Creatures That Run the World” will be Ann Mayo’s study talk at 7 p.m. Thursday, Sept. 13, at the Weatherford Cherry Park Community Center, the Weatherford Democrat reported. The talk is about ants. Mayo is a Weatherford College associate professor and earned her doctorate from UTA.

New principal

Melissa Martin, assistant principal at Francone Elementary School, was named the school’s new principal on Aug. 3, Cy-Fair Lifestyles & Homes reported. Martin earned her master’s degree in educational leadership and policy studies from UTA.

Superintendent of the Year finalist

Tim Harkrider, Willis school district superintendent, is a state finalist in the Texas Association of School Board’s Superintendent of the Year award, the El Paso Herald-Post reported. Harkrider received his master’s degree from UTA.

Wild Detectives event

The Wild Detectives bookstore is bringing an international literary event — Hay Festival-Bogotá 39 — to Oak Cliff on Saturday, Sept. 8, The Dallas Morning News reported. The festival began 30 years ago in the small, books-crazed town of Hay-on-Wye, Wales. Dallas landed the inaugural American version. Among the festival’s sponsors is UTA, which will hold similar panels with the authors in the days after the Wild Detectives event.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, July 27, 2018
shortDescription: Online nursingUTA was mentioned as one of the largest online nursing programs in the higher education community, Vietnam’s Communications Delivery rep
body:
Online nursing

UTA was mentioned as one of the largest online nursing programs in the higher education community, Vietnam’s Communications Delivery reported in an article about online learning.

Germany collaboration

A city of Arlington contingent visited Rothenburg recently to talk about mutual business and education opportunities, Germany's Nordbayern.com reported. Rothenburg officials expressed interest in establishing partnerships with UTA.

U.S. News ranking

U.S. News and World Report’s university rankings placed UTA’s Computer Science and Engineering program at No. 91 nationally, China’s Sohu.com reported.

Alumnus celebrates birthday

Sajeeb Wazed Joy, the only son of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and the eldest grandson of Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, celebrated his 48th birthday, Dhaka, Bangladesh’s Daily Sun reported. Joy earned his bachelor’s degree in computer science and engineering from UTA.

Counsel finalist

Shelby Boseman, UTA’s university attorney, was named a finalist in D CEO’s 2018 Corporate Counsel Award, D Magazine reported.

Alumnus named exec VP

Lynden Tennison has been named executive vice president and chief strategy officer for Union Pacific, GuruFocus.com and Railway Age reported. Tennison earned his bachelor's degree from UTA.

Alumna named CFO

Sarah Hagan has been named chief financial officer for ECi Software Solutions, WICZ Fox 40 in Binghamton, N.Y., Business Wire and several other media reported. Hagan received her MBA at UTA.

NCAA award

The NCAA has awarded UTA a $120,000 an Accelerating Academic Success Program Comprehensive Grants to support the schools’ efforts to meet the requirements of the Division I Academic Performance Program, which was developed to ensure schools provide an environment that supports education while enhancing the ability of student-athletes to earn a degree, HBCU Sports reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, May 16, 2018
shortDescription: Cancer trapUTA bioengineer Liping Tang has invented an implantable medical device that attracts and kills circulating cancer cells, KTVT CBS 11, Pharm
body:
Cancer trap

UTA bioengineer Liping Tang has invented an implantable medical device that attracts and kills circulating cancer cells, KTVT CBS 11, Pharmacy Choice, Medicine newsline and U.S. Fed News reported. The cancer trap can be used for early diagnosis and treatment of metastasized cancer. UTA has patented the device in Europe.

Testing water

UTA scientists gathered skin swabs and water samples Tuesday in Ponder, where some residents have complained of burning, itching rashes after exposure to their tap water, the Denton Record Chronicle, The Dallas Morning News, WBAP 820 AM, WFAA ABC 8 and KXAS NBC 5 reported. UTA chemistry professor Kevin Schug and consultant Zac Hildenbrand manage UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR lab, which performed analysis.

Brain research

UTA is participating in ongoing research projects that help with traumatic brain injury as part of the federal and UT System BRAIN Initiative, Dallas Innovates reported. Since 2015, UTA has received more than $6 million in brain research funding.

Supereruption impact

Naomi Cleghorn, UTA associate professor of sociology and anthropology, participated in research on how humanity may have thrived after a volcano’s supereruption 74,000 years ago, Vision Times reported. The research paper was initially published in Nature. 

Regulating license plates

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said although he believes in an unfettered right to free speech, the state has the right to regulate wording on personalized license plates, the Houston Chronicle, the Albuquerque Journal, the Daily World, KXAS NBC 5 and the Austin American-Statesman reported in publishing a story that first appeared in the Star-Telegram.

Sports betting

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, says state lawmakers need to “strike while the iron is hot” to make sports betting legal in Texas, KTVT CBS 11 reported. “It’s not a moral question. If it was, we wouldn’t have the lottery,” Saxe said. The U.S. Supreme Court recently made a legal decision that paved the way for legal sports betting in other states.

Alumna art exhibition

Kathryn Hart, a UTA MBA graduate, has a solo art exhibition on display in New York City, artdaily.org reported.

Memorial Day speaker

Bryan Degner, director of education at the National Museum of the Pacific War, will be the guest speaker at the Lakeway Memorial Day Ceremony at 11 a.m. May 25, the Austin American-Statesman reported. Degner is a UTA graduate.

Design inspirations

Kate Aoki, architect at Dallas-based DSGN Associates, moderated The Dallas Architecture Forum’s panel discussion of “Design Inspirations” last night at Dallas Black Dance Theater, Dallas Uptown BubbleLife reported. Aoki earned her master’s degree in architecture from UTA. Bang Dang, a UTA lecturer and graduate, and UTA alumni Jessica Stewart Lendvay and Madhavi Sonar were on the panel.

Out of Amazon bid

The city of Arlington announced it is no longer in the running for the Amazon HQ2 bid, Patch.com reported. In its pitch, the city said UTA was close to the 200-acre proposed site.

Scholarship recipient

Manuel Melgar received a Texas Builders Foundation scholarship, Texas Builders reported. Melgar plans to attend UTA in the fall.

Economists back plan

Roger Meiners, chair of the UTA College of Business’ Department of Economics, was one of several national economists signing a letter endorsing President Trump’s tax cuts and job act, SMIonline.com reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, August 24, 2018
shortDescription: Tech Titans finalistsUTA’s EpICMavs program is a 2018 finalist for the Tech Titans awards, the Dallas Business Journal reported. The Journal interview
body:
Tech Titans finalists

UTA’s EpICMavs program is a 2018 finalist for the Tech Titans awards, the Dallas Business Journal reported. The Journal interviewed Teri Schultz, director of UTA’s Office of Technology Management, which runs the program. Ali Abolmaali, chair of UTA’s department of civil engineering, is another Tech Titans finalist, the Dallas Business Journal reported. The article said Abolmaali is at the forefront of engineering technology in Texas. The winners will be announced at a gala event tonight.

Shale extraction conference

UTA is hosting the second annual Responsible Shale Energy Extraction Conference Oct. 12-13 at its new state-of-the-art Science & Engineering Innovation & Research building on the south side of campus, Targeted News Service and Techsite reported. "The goal of this conference is to show that shale energy extraction and environmental stewardship can be achieved conjointly," said Kevin Schug, UTA's Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of the Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation or CLEAR lab, who are conference organizers.

BionorthTX conference

BionorthTX, the leading life science industry association for the North Texas region, will hold its Fourth Annual iC3 Life Science Summit Wednesday, Oct. 10, at UTA, Contify Life Science News, Biospace.com, Spoke.com and many other media reported. The summit provides senior executives, scientists, educators and community leaders with a forum to network, exchange ideas, learn and promote business opportunities in the region.

Convictions have impact

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, predicts that the recent convictions of two of President Trump's closest associates will hurt congressional Republicans in the November elections, WBAP 820 AM and KLIF 570 AM reported. Saxe said it's far more diffciult to forecast the possibility of impeachment.

History helps economic development

Kathryn Holliday, UTA associate professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, said historic preservation of neighborhoods like Dallas' 10th Street neighborhood, a historic district south of the Trinity River founded by freed slaves after the Civil War, is a “tool for economic development,” The Texarkana Gazette reported.

Move-in Day

UTA’s Move-in Day was featured on KDFW FOX 4. The story mentioned that approximately 10,000 students now live on the UTA campus, which has opened a new residence hall this semester called West Hall.  

College textbooks

UTA students are finding new ways to save on college textbooks, KXAS NBC 5, NBCDFW.com and KRLD 1080 AM reported. Among the ways are sharing textbooks with other students and renting ebooks on Kindle.

Alumna appointed

UTA alumna Becky Johnson has been appointed by Gov. Greg Abbott to the Texas Board of Professional Geoscientists, Guidry News reported. Johnson is a past president of the Society of Texas Environmental Professionals and citizen advisory committee member for the City of Fort Worth Waste Management. Johnson received a bachelor's of science degree in geology from UTA. 

PGA qualifier

Stuart Deane, the director of golf at UTA, qualified for the 2019 PGA Professional Championship, which serves as the club pros' qualifier for the PGA Championship, The Dallas Morning News reported. The Professional Championship is April 28 to May 1 at Belfair in Bluffton, S.C..

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, May 9, 2018
shortDescription: Nursing retentionAnne Bavier, dean of UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation, was interviewed by KTVT CBS 11 about how the shortage of experie
body:
Nursing retention

Anne Bavier, dean of UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation, was interviewed by KTVT CBS 11 about how the shortage of experienced nurses is changing the benefits and perks that nurses are being offered to stay in particular hospital chains. “The nurses are winning, but the patients receive the ultimate benefit,” Bavier said.

New hydrogel for bioprinting

Yi Hong, UTA assistant professor of bioengineering, was interviewed by KTVT CBS 11 and KDAF CW 33 about his new highly elastic biodegradable hydrogel for bioprinting of materials that mimic natural human soft tissues. The research was also covered by KLIF 570 AM, the Syrian-Arab News Agency, One News Page USA and was included in UT System’s Texas Health Journal.

Pullout decision

Brent Sasley, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by KLIF 570 AM about President Trump’s decision to take the United States out of the Iran nuclear agreement. “I’m not sure that the President has a sense of what to do next,” Sasley said. “I think he just assumes that Iran will feel compelled to negotiate a better deal.”

Water recycling

A new paper from UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation looked at wastewater in the Eagle Ford Shale region to figure out what’s in it — and what needs to be removed so it can be reused, the San Antonio Express-News reported. “There’s so much need for water recycling,” said Kevin A. Schug, College of Science interim associate dean, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of the CLEAR lab.

Tops among Nigerians

UTA figures among the top five universities for Nigerian students, Nigeria Today reported. The top five universities are all located in Texas.

UTA part of diversity

The city of Arlington was ranked as Wallethub.com’s 10th most diverse city in America, U.S. Fed News reported. The story also said UTA is ranked as the fifth most diverse campus by U.S. News & World Report and contributes to the city's diversity.

Alumna running for governor

UTA alumna Lupe Valdez could make history as Texas’ first Hispanic governor, the Huffington Post reported. The former Dallas County sheriff earned her master’s in criminology and criminal justice from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, May 11, 2018
shortDescription: Artopia helps vets copeUTA researchers have found that 98 percent of veterans participating in the University’s Artopia program believe art therapy he
body:
Artopia helps vets cope

UTA researchers have found that 98 percent of veterans participating in the University’s Artopia program believe art therapy helped them cope with service-related trauma or disability, KXAS NBC 5, KXTX Telemundo 39, Medicine News Line, The Medical News of Australia, and Medical Xpress, ScienMag and Bright Surf, all of Great Britain, reported. The multidisciplinary project was guided by Amanda Alexander, UTA associate professor of art abd art history, and faculty from the Department of Psychology in collaboration with the Veterans Assistance Center at UTA.

New gel for bioprinting

Yi Hong, UTA assistant professor of bioengineering, was interviewed by KXAS NBC 5 about his new highly elastic biodegradable hydrogel for bioprinting of materials that mimic human soft tissues. The research was also included in ASEE First Bell.

Piper professor

David Hullender, a longtime UTA professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering, has been named a 2018 Piper Professor by the San Antonio-based Minnie Stevens Piper Foundation, Defense & Aerospace Week and News RX Health & Science reported.

Pipes curing report

A literature review of chemical emissions of the resin used in the cured-in-place pipe, or CIPP, process was conducted at UTA’s Center for Underground Infrastructure Research and Education on behalf of the National Association of Sewer Service Companies. The review was non-conclusive, Trenchless International reported.

Software to be sold

Mentis, a software born at UTA for university management needs that is running at many universities, will now be sold, customized and enhanced by Brainvire Inc., WAFB CBS 9 in Baton Rouge, La., and more than 150 other media reported.

Hormone-cholesterol link

Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry and biochemistry, and a team of researchers are investigating the link between ovarian hormones and the blood-cholesterol balance in the body, a key determinant of cardiovascular health or disease, Biotech Week reported.

Helping students finish

UTA is among the universities making innovative approaches toward students who dropped out but were in fact close to finishing their degrees, the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators website reported.

Downtown redevelopment

Chris McMurrough, a UTA senior lecturer in computer science and engineering, said he was happy that the city was gathering opinions about downtown redevelopment, the Arlington Voice reported. The city held its first public downtown planning session Wednesday night. McMurrough, who has lived in Arlington his whole life, said if the city wants young professionals to come here, there should be single-family homes available for them.

Alumna featured

Former Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez, who is running for Texas governor, was profiled on KDAF CW 33 and Latina Style Magazine. Valdez earned her master’s degree in criminology at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, May 14, 2018
shortDescription: Mom-daughter graduateMickaela Alves-Rosario, who graduated with her UTA College of Liberal Arts bachelor’s degree last week, was featured in an Al Dia
body:
Mom-daughter graduate

Mickaela Alves-Rosario, who graduated with her UTA College of Liberal Arts bachelor’s degree last week, was featured in an Al Dia profile about her earning the degree while working and raising a child. The Al Dia story also ran in La Genta Radio La Primerisima in Managua, Nicaragua. Alves-Rosario plans to enroll in law school.

Commencement ceremonies

The University of Texas at Arlington conferred nearly 6,400 degrees in commencement ceremonies May 10-12 at College Park Center on the UTA campus, U.S. Fed News reported.

Discout grocery stores

Fernando Jaramillo, chair of UTA’s Department of Marketing in the College of Business, told KTVT 39 Telemundo viewers how discount grocery stores use a sliding scale surcharge as a hidden expense in their business models.

Art helps veterans

UTA researchers have found that 98 percent of veterans participating in the University’s Artopia program believe art therapy helped them cope with service-related trauma or disability, Medicalnewser.com reported. The multidisciplinary project was guided by Amanda Alexander, UTA associate professor of art and art history, and faculty from the Department of Psychology in collaboration with the Veterans Assistance Center at UTA.

New hydrogel for bioprinting

Yi Hong, a UTA bioengineering assistant professor, and his team of researchers have developed a highly elastic biodegradable hydrogel for bio-printing of materials that mimic natural human soft tissues, 3DPrint.com reported.

Cholesterol-hormones link

Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry and biochemistry, and a team of researchers are investigating the link between ovarian hormones and the blood cholesterol balance in the body, a key determinant of cardiovascular health or disease, Science & Technology Research News reported.

Tree saver

Richard McMullen, a UTA earth and environmental sciences adjunct professor, was included in Jacquielynn Floyd’s farewell column at The Dallas Morning News. Floyd included McMullen as one of her favorite interviews for his work to save a palm tree on Division Street.

Esports profiled

The UTA esports team and its members were featured in a profile about the Heroes of the Dorm annual competition at ESPN.com.

Mom, daughter, son graduate

Carolyn and Nathan Wade, and Christina Cannon – mother, son and daughter – all graduated with associate degrees last week, Austin’s KUT 90.5 FM and KDFW Fox 4 reported. Nathan and Christina will continue their education to seek bachelor’s degrees at UTA.

Personalized license plates

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said although he believes in an unfettered right to free speech, the state has the right to regulate wording on personalized license plates, the Star-Telegram reported.

Fare hike concern

Molly Beyer, a member of North Texas Transit Riders, cited concern for DART’s 20 percent fare hike in a Dallas Morning News op-ed column. She cited a UTA public transportation analysis that said it’s unaffordable in the “transit dependent core” of Dallas.

Future UTA student

Myra Simon of Shoemaker High School received her associate’s degree at the Texas Biosciences Institute and will finish her education at UTA, the Killeen Daily Herald reported.

Gubernatorial candidate alumna

Lupe Valdez and Andrew White, the two Democrat candidates for the Texas governor’s race, were featured in a San Angelo Standard-Times article. Valdez earned her UTA master’s degree in criminology.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, June 11, 2018
shortDescription: NAE member on boardNational Academy of Engineering member Robert Schafrik, an internationally renowned expert in materials and manufacturing, has join
body:
NAE member on board

National Academy of Engineering member Robert Schafrik, an internationally renowned expert in materials and manufacturing, has joined UTA, strengthening the university’s programs around manufacturing, materials and aerospace engineering, Dallas Innovates reported. The Governor’s University Research Initiative matching grant of $2 million helped recruit Schafrik to UTA.

Artificial intelligence

George Siemens, executive director of UTA's Learning Innovation and Networked Knowledge Lab, talked about the future of artificial intelligence in the world, KDFW Fox 4 reported. Siemens was featured on Dan Godwin’s Fox4Ward segment.

Birth mothers' research

New research findings could change the adoption landscape for birth mothers struggling with the life-altering decision to place their children Newswise, LadyClick and other websites reported. Scott Ryan, dean of the UTA School of Social Work, and Michael Killian, assistant professor in the UTA School of Social Work, contributed to the study.

National champion

Junior Alexus Henry became the first UTA woman to win an individual national championship, taking the title in the women’s high jump at the NCAA Outdoor Track & Field Championships Saturday evening at historic Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., Texas' Port Arthur News, RunnerSpace.com and several other websites reported.

Hervey turning heads

UTA’s Kevin Hervey is turning heads in the June 21 NBA draft, MidMajorMadness.com reported. The San Antonio Spurs is one of the teams that could target Hervey in the second round, UPROXX.com reported.

Alumna makes 40-under-40 list

Melissa Go, senior client services account manager at Centricity, has been named to Dealerscope’s 40-under-40 list. Dealerscope is a manufacturing and distribution industry website. Go earned a UTA bachelor’s degree in university studies.

Alumni honored

A graduate luncheon celebrating more than 30 Dallas school district alumni who are succeeding at college included UTA graduates Anthia Rodriguez, DeAndre Jones Ayane Rodriguez and Fataha Ibriham, El Lider USA reported. The graduates were all part of ScholarShot, a nonprofit dedicated to helping at-risk students earn college degrees.

Folk art market

Santa Fe’s International Folk Art Market comes to UTA’s The Green at College Park June 14-16, FolkArtMarket.org, The Dallas Morning News and Travel Breaking News reported.

Music fest

UTA presented the Downtown Arlington Music Fest this weekend, U.S. Fed News reported. Joe Ely headlined the many artists taking the stage.

New managing director

Atlanta-based DNA Behavior International continues its growth and evolution with a member of the executive team taking on a new role. Leon Morales has been named managing director of Atlanta-based DNA Behavior International, WAND NBC 17 reported. Morales earned his accounting degree from UTA.

NFL helps with sustainability

The NFL Draft, held in Arlington at AT&T Stadium recently, left a positive sustainability and green footprint in Arlington during the event, Sports Destinations Management reported. The article cited UTA volunteers for helping sort recyclable materials.

Current health status

Kenneth Crane, biology and math professor at Texarkana College, will present his findings about Days Creek's current health status in a talk to Friends United for a Safe Environment Tuesday, the Texarkana Gazette reported. Crane received his doctorate from UTA.

Op-ed explores North Texas smog

A Star-Telegram op-ed column explains why North Texas won’t have the same smoggy air that engulfed Los Angeles in the 1990s. Richard Greene, a UTA adjunct professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Administration and former Arlington mayor, wrote the column.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, May 18, 2018
shortDescription: Overcoming adversityOrlando Carrillo Maffei, a star student-athlete at UTA who has overcome great adversity in his life, was profiled in a Star-Telegr
body:
Overcoming adversity

Orlando Carrillo Maffei, a star student-athlete at UTA who has overcome great adversity in his life, was profiled in a Star-Telegram story. Maffei graduated last week with a master’s degree in construction management. He played with the Movin’ Mavs wheelchair basketball team.

Cancer trap

UTA bioengineer Liping Tang has invented an implantable medical device that attracts and kills circulating cancer cells, the Star-Telegram, KXAS NBC 5, KLIF 570 AM, Houston’s KHOU CBS 11, Austin’s KVUE ABC 24, WTNZ Fox 43 in Knoxville, Tenn., Brinkwire, Medical Design Technology and many other websites reported. The cancer trap can be used for early diagnosis and treatment of metastasized cancer. UTA has patented the device in Europe.

Testing water

UTA scientists gathered skin swabs and water samples Tuesday in Ponder, where some residents have complained of burning, itching rashes after exposure to their tap water, KLIF 570 AM reported. UTA chemistry professor Kevin Schug and consultant Zac Hildenbrand manage UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR lab, which performed the analysis.

Sexual harassment

Research by UTA’s James Campbell Quick and M. Ann McFadyen in 2017 was cited in the May issue of Monitor on Psychology in an article titled "Sexual harassment on campus." Quick, a UTA management professor, and McFadyen, an associate professor of management, collaborated on a paper titled "Sexual Harassment: Have we made any progress?" in the Journal of Occupational Health, Psychology.

Healthcare innovation

Dallas innovation was highlighted during a panel discussion on healthcare, Dallas Innovates reported. UTA was mentioned in the article as one of the major research universities in North Texas.

Implementation time

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said results from the upcoming meeting between President Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un would take considerable time to implement after the meeting happens, WBAP 820 AM reported.

Wings start

UTA’s College Park Center was featured in a Dallas Morning News story listing five things one has to know about the Dallas Wings as the 2018 WNBA season tips off soon. The Wings play their home games at College Park Center.

Alumna welcomed

LaShonda Putman has been welcomed into the International Nurses Association, PR News Channel reported. Putnam earned her bachelor’s degree in nursing from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, June 6, 2018
shortDescription: Startup uses UTA technologyCalifornia startup SensTek has licensed pH sensor technology that uses two issued patents developed by UTA electrical engin
body:
Startup uses UTA technology

California startup SensTek has licensed pH sensor technology that uses two issued patents developed by UTA electrical engineering Professor J.-C. Chiao, Infosurhoy, News Locker, MedWorm, Topix and many other websites reported. Chiao said the pH sensor is simple, biocompatible, flexible, inexpensive and easily mass-produced.

UTA partners with Foxconn

A partnership between a UTA industrial engineering team and Foxconn, a global electronics manufacturing giant and primary supplier for iPhones, will reduce fraudulent replacement claims for iPhone repairs at its Fort Worth facility, Dallas Innovates reported. Shouyi Wang, an assistant professor in UTA’s Industrial, Manufacturing and Systems Engineering Department, is leading the team, which includes Wang’s IMSE colleagues Paul Componation, Victoria Chen, Jay Rosenberger and Aera Leboulluec.

Best tools

Kevin Schug, UTA’s Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry, wrote a blog for Chromatography Online debating which type of mass spectrometry instrumentation provides the best specificity during trace quantitative analysis from complex mixtures.

UTA, Sandia partnering

Work on a U.S. Department of Energy Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy grant will be conducted in collaboration with the UTA and Sandia National Laboratories, the Kaplan Herald reported. The project is for advanced reactor research and is part of the Nuclear Energy Reinvigoration Program.

Students like Via

About 64 percent of the rides operated by ride-sharing service Via in Arlington start or end in the UTA area, WFAA ABC 8 and WBAP 820 AM reported. Six months in, Arlington says this Uber-like experiment has completed more than 28,000 rides.

Alumna named chief nursing officer

Brittni McGill will serve as Norman Regional Health System’s chief nursing officer, Becker Hospital Review reported. McGill earned her master’s degree in nursing administration at UTA.

UTA partnership

Seventeen Red Oak seniors have earned their associate's degrees from Navarro College as Hawk Scholars, the Waxahachie Daily Light reported. Red Oak school district exercises a partnership with Navarro College and The University of Texas at Arlington. During their junior year, the Hawk Scholars meet with UTA advisers to review elective selections and focus on plans for the degree that adequately suit the students.

Valedictorian chooses UTA

Katrina Wisofsky, valedictorian at Industrial High School, will continue her education at UTA, the Jackson County (Texas) Herald-Tribune reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, June 1, 2018
shortDescription: LINK Lab grantGeorge Siemens, executive director of UTA’s Learning Innovation and Networked Knowledge or LINK Research Lab, has received a new grant t
body:
LINK Lab grant

George Siemens, executive director of UTA’s Learning Innovation and Networked Knowledge or LINK Research Lab, has received a new grant to help Boeing plan for teaching employees to work alongside bots, robots and artificial intelligence, KXAS NBC 5 and ScienMag reported.

Diseased coral research

The National Science Foundation and Environment Guru reported on UTA research that found a correlation between a strong immune response in diseased corals and a lower expression of genes associated with growth and reproduction. Laura Mydlarz, UTA associate professor and associate chair of biology, led the research, which was published last month in the Royal Society Open Science journal.

Friendship Council

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari was among the community leaders who participated in the Indian American Friendship Council reception for Nikki Randhawa Haley, U.S. ambassador to United Nations, at the Four Seasons Hotel in Irving, Indian Defense News reported.

Using genes to heal

Juhyun Lee, an assistant professor in the Bioengineering Department, has been awarded a prestigious Career Development Award by the American Heart Association to study how genes might be used to heal hearts, Heart Disease Weekly reported.

Geosynthetics committee

Asif Ahmed, UTA research assistant professor of civil engineering, has been named a member of the 2018-2021 Transportation Research Board Standing Committee on Geosynthetics, Geosynthetics Magazine reported.

Panama connection

UTA is one of the universities with strong connections to the Universidad del Istmo in Panama, enterate507 reported. The article says that Panamanian Generation Z students are looking for an international and high-tech university experience.

UTA enrollment target

UTA is one of the target universities for students graduating from Fort Worth’s Young Men’s Leadership Academy, KXAS NBC 5 reported.

Arlington among best

Arlington was featured among the top 50 best big college towns in America, MSN reported. UTA and Arlington Baptist University are listed as the local universities.

Via program

Arlington’s Via Rideshare provides affordable transportation for UTA students, U.S. Fed News reported.

Hervey could be drafted

UTA’s Kevin Hervey says playing for the NBA's Dallas Mavericks would be a dream come true, The Dallas Morning News reported. Hervey could become the fourth player from UTA to be selected in the draft, and the first since 1982.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, September 19, 2018
shortDescription: Fall enrollmentUTA’s fall enrollment set a new record at 42,496, with 3,400 incoming freshmen, KTVT CBS 11, ArlingtonTx.com, Targeted News Service and
body:
Fall enrollment

UTA’s fall enrollment set a new record at 42,496, with 3,400 incoming freshmen, KTVT CBS 11, ArlingtonTx.com, Targeted News Service and U.S. Fed News reported. KTVT quoted UTA President Vistasp Karbhari as saying that this new record enrollment reflects UTA’s value in the state and around the world. 

Sprawl reduces life expectancy

The Wall Street Journal featured research by Shima Hamidi, director of UTA’s the director Institute of Urban Studies, on the link between urban sprawl and life expectancy. Hamidi’s research found that, all other things being equal, Americans who live in compact metropolitan counties live longer on average than those who reside in more sprawling ones. Hamidi also is an assistant professor of urban planning in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

Job anxiety

Reader’s Digest and MSN.com quoted James Campbell Quick, a UTA management professor emeritus, on how much job-related anxiety and depression seep into other aspects of life. “When you leave work, it would be ideal if you left the work behind,” Quick said. “Some people are able to do that well, but some experience spillover effects, meaning they leave the office in a bad place psychologically then take their stress out on the people they live with.”

Online course materials

Matthew Crosslin, a UTA learning innovation researcher, has developed a new set of openly licensed materials aimed at helping instructors construct online classes, Inside Higher Ed reported. Creating Online Learning Experiences: A Brief Guide to Online Courses, From Small and Private to Massive and Open (Pressbooks, July 2018) started as a guide to creating massive open online courses for an audience of instructors at UTA, but eventually Crosslin expanded its scope on the advice of his colleague George Siemens, executive director of the university’s LINK Research Lab.

New album

Dan Cavanaugh, UTA Department of Music chair and professor, forms part of a duo at St. Olaf College, that released its second album, “20 Years” with performances last week, Northfield News of Northfield, Minn., reported. 

Duo to perform

Cheyenne Cruz, UTA faculty member and clarinetist, will be performing as part of the WoodWired Duo at Northwestern State University on Sept. 20, Natchitoches Parish Journal reported. The group's debut album, “In the Loop,” was released in March under The University of Texas at Arlington record label.  

Task force to meet

The last meeting on recommendations for the City of Arlington’s Race and Culture Task Force will be held at UTA Research Institute, KRLD 1080 AM reported. 

Alumnus selected

UTA alumnus Tim de Noble, professor and dean of the College of Architecture, Planning & Design at Kansas State University, has again been selected and recognized by DesignIntelligence as among the Top 25 Most Admired Educators in Architecture, Interiors and Landscape Architecture for 2019, Kansas State University reported. He earned his bachelor's degree in architecture from UTA. 

Executive of the Year

UTA alumnus Andrew Pryor, senior vice president of human resources of ECi Software Solutions, has been named by the International Business Awards as the Gold Winner for International Human Resources Executive of The Year, eParisExtra reported. Pryor has served on the advisory board of directors for UTA’s College of Business Graduate MBA Programs for the past 11 years.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, June 13, 2018
shortDescription: Recruiting STEM teachersThe Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at The University of Texas at Arlington has been awarded a $1.5 million grant by
body:
Recruiting STEM teachers

The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at The University of Texas at Arlington has been awarded a $1.5 million grant by the National Science Foundation, Dallas Innovates reported. The program will help recruit and prepare new science, math, engineering and computer science teachers.

UTA startups featured

Four UTA startup companies demonstrated their innovations at the TECH Fort Worth Showcase, the Fort Worth Business Press reported.

UTA artist exhibit

Sedrick Huckaby, UTA assistant professor of art and art history, spoke at a seminar and art exhibit this week, the Springfield News-Leader and OzarksFirst.com reported. Huckaby helped teach former President George W. Bush how to paint.

U.S.-North Korea meeting

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, discussed President Trump’s meeting with North Korea’s Kim Jong-un, WIBX 950 AM in Utica, N.Y., reported. The second part of the WIBX interview talked about what the United States might seek in the negotiations. Saxe interviews about the historic meeting also aired on WFLA 970 AM in Tampa Bay, Fla., and WSYR 570 AM in Syracuse, N.Y.

IHOP branding

Elten Briggs, UTA associate professor of marketing, talked about branding and whether it will matter that the International House of Pancakes changed its name from IHOP to IHOB, KRLD 1080 AM reported. The “B” stands for burgers.

Israel survey

Hysteria over an Israel/Diaspora split has to stop, a Forward opinion column said. Brent Sasley, a UTA associate professor of political science, wrote the column. A recent American Jewish Committee’s survey revealed that American Jews and Israeli Jews have diverged to the point that while a majority of both groups see the other as family in one form or another, they are content to live within their own geographic-political spaces, separate from one another.

Water testing

KXAS NBC 5 reported on a city of Ponder situation that has residents concerned about their tap water. The story said a UTA study of the water should be finished soon.

Fact-checking

Fact-checking might help politicians determine which claims to remove from speeches, Poynter.org reported. The article mentioned the heightened use of tools like ClaimBuster, a fact-checking tool created by UTA researchers.

Making of a podcast

Bart Weiss, associate professor in UTA’s Department of Art and Art History, wrote about the making of his podcast about the documentary film, The Fog of Truth, in a TheaterJones column.

Graduates named assistant principals

Molly Corrington and Tiffany Farmer were named assistant principals at Collins Intermediate and Jose Antonio Navarro Elementary schools, respectively, the Corsicana Daily Sun reported. Corrington earned her master’s degree from UTA. Farmer earned her bachelor’s and master’s degrees from UTA.

High jump champion

Junior Alexus Henry became the first UTA woman ever to win an individual national championship, taking the title in the women’s high jump at the NCAA Outdoor Track and Field Championships Saturday evening at Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., the Beaumont Enterprise, Beaumont’s KBMT ABC 6 and the Star-Telegram reported.

Hervey profiled

The Dallas Morning News listed strengths of UTA’s Kevin Hervey, who could be selected in the June 21 NBA Draft.

UTA listed in guide

DestinationDFW, a relocation guide for newcomers to the North Texas area, listed UTA as the region’s 23rd largest employer.

Folk art market coming

The International Folk Art Market comes to UTA’s The Green at College Park June 14-16, The Dallas Morning News’ GuideLive reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, May 21, 2018
shortDescription: Online educationUTA President Vistasp Karbhari said online education is a way for the University to reach the new traditional student in higher educat
body:
Online education

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari said online education is a way for the University to reach the new traditional student in higher education, The Washington Post reported in a story about the rising popularity of online education. Karbhari said UTA, which has huge online enrollments in nursing and education, focuses on face-to-face, online and a mix of the two to provide education. The Standard-Examiner of Ogden, Utah, also ran the Post story.

Ethiopia agreement

UTA civil engineer Sahadat Hossain is leading a $4 million grant with the city of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to answer sustainable urban development problems like landfill management, Phys.org reported.

Royal expertise

Elisabeth Cawthon, dean of the UTA College of Liberal Arts and associate professor of history, offered her expertise on the royal wedding for KDFW Fox 4 viewers Friday. The story also ran on the station’s website. Cawthon said divorce and not the fact that Meghan Markle is an American could be much more important to the British.

Collaboration with manufacturer

A partnership between a UTA industrial engineering team and Foxconn, a global electronics manufacturer giant and primary supplier for iPhones, will reduce fraudulent replacement claims for iPhone repairs, Phys.org reported. Shouyi Wang, an assistant professor in UTA’s Industrial, Manufacturing and Systems Engineering Department, is leading the team, which includes Assistant Professor Aera Leboulluec, Professor and Chair Paul Componation, Professor Jay Rosenberger and Professor Victoria Chen.

Cancer trap

UTA bioengineer Liping Tang has invented an implantable medical device that attracts and kills circulating cancer cells, WFAA ABC 8, Dallas Innovates and several other media outlets reported. The cancer trap can be used for early diagnosis and treatment of metastasized cancer. UTA has patented the device in Europe.

Yanny or laurel?

UTA’s Daniel Scarpace, a senior lecturer in linguistics, said it’s certain people’s ability or inability to hear the lower frequencies as the reason some hear yanny in an Internet debate over whether a recorded voice says yanny or laurel, Austin’s KUT 90.5 FM reported. He said some people hear something else entirely.

Artopia helps veterans

UTA researchers have found that 98 percent of veterans participating in the University’s Artopia program believe art therapy helped them cope with service-related trauma or disability, Info Infosurhoy.com and U.S. Fed News reported. The multidisciplinary project was guided by Amanda Alexander, UTA associate professor of art and art history, and faculty from the Department of Psychology in collaboration with the Veterans Assistance Center at UTA.

Meeting with North Korea

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said President Trump and his administration are simply trying to exert pressure on North Korean officials by conducting military exercises with South Korea recently, WBAP 820 AM reported. This posturing is in advance of the scheduled June 12 meeting between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

Graduate overcomes

Yahoo! Sports profiled Orlando Carrillo Maffei, a star student-athlete at UTA who has overcome great adversity in his life. The story originally appeared in the Star-Telegram. Maffei graduated this semester with a master’s degree in construction management. He played with the Movin’ Mavs wheelchair basketball team.

Hervey shines at combine

UTA men’s basketball star Kevin Hervey had a 21-point performance Friday at the NBA Draft Combine, SI.com and The Ringer reported. Both stories said Hervey helped his draft stock with the performance. The NBA Draft is June 21.

Via program

Ben Aghapour, a recent UTA graduate of landscape architecture, is one of the 4,000 people who have ridden Via, Arlington’s ride share program since the program started in December, U.S. Fed News reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, May 23, 2018
shortDescription: Healing heartsJuhyun Lee, an assistant professor in UTA’s Bioengineering Department, has been awarded a prestigious Career Development Award by the Am
body:
Healing hearts

Juhyun Lee, an assistant professor in UTA’s Bioengineering Department, has been awarded a prestigious Career Development Award by the American Heart Association to determine how genes might be used to heal heart tissue, Infosurhoy.com reported.

Cancer trap

UTA bioengineer Liping Tang has invented an implantable medical device that attracts and kills circulating cancer cells, Seattle’s KING NBC 5 reported in a story that originally aired on WFAA ABC 8. The cancer trap can be used for early diagnosis and treatment of metastasized cancer. UTA has patented the device in Europe.

Transportation changes

Experts say car ownership is changing and predict that before long, it will look nothing like it has for the past century, mainly because of technology, CBN News reported. Shima Hamidi, UTA assistant professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, said research shows that low-income families pay the most for car ownership because affordable housing is rarely close to public transportation.

UTA to host Special Olympics

The Special Olympics Texas Summer Games is making its way to UTA this week in torch runs across the state, the Odessa American and the Bryan/College Station Eagle reported.

Architecture criticism

Mark Lamster, a UTA professor and the architecture critic of The Dallas Morning News, talked about how architecture criticism has evolved to include important urban issues in The Architect’s Newspaper.

Election security

A group of academic experts and professors have signed a letter urging Texas to undertake measures for improving election security, PressReleasePoint.com reported. UTA’s Jiang Ming, an assistant professor of computer science and engineering, signed the letter, which was forwarded to the elections division of the Texas Secretary of State’s office.

Results inconclusive

A UTA study that examined chemical emissions of cured-in-place pipe or CIPP showed it to be non-conclusive, WTVR CBS 6 of Richmond, Va., reported in a story about residents’ health suffering in an area where CIPP is being done.

GOP advantage

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said a generic poll still shows Republicans hold an advantage in Texas elections, Houston’s KTRH 740 AM reported in a story about Tuesday’s statewide primary runoff elections.

Park celebration

Julia Burgen, former Arlington council member, and city officials will celebrate the one-year anniversary of a 66-acre park named after her later this week, U.S. Fed News reported. Burgen earned her UTA master’s degree in interdisciplinary studies with an emphasis in biology and science.

Planning director hired

AJ Fawver has been hired as Lubbock’s planning director, the Lubbock Avalanche-Journal reported. Fawver earned her master’s degree in public administration from UTA.

Alumnus named principal

Tim Betts has been named the new principal at Navarro Elementary, the Corsicana Daily Sun reported. Betts earned his master’s degree in educational leadership from UTA.

Graduate named CEO

Jay Minmier has been named chief executive officer at Extreme Plastics Pins, PE Hub Network reported. Minmier earned a UTA bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering.

Journalist named

Andrea Henderson, a UTA alumna, has been named one of several Goldring Arts Journalists, the Charleston, S.C., Post and Courier reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, June 15, 2018
shortDescription: Opioid crisisAs director of UTA’s Center for Addiction and Recovery, Debra Woody oversees programs that work to help some of the most heartbreaking vi
body:
Opioid crisis

As director of UTA’s Center for Addiction and Recovery, Debra Woody oversees programs that work to help some of the most heartbreaking victims of the opioid crisis, pregnant women and the babies to whom they give birth, Texas Health Journal reported in a question-and-answer story about the opioid crisis and the center. Woody also is associate dean for academic affairs at UTA’s School of Social Work.

Diperts profiled

Dan and Linda Dipert, a longtime Arlington business couple, were featured on the Arlington-tx.gov website as part of the city’s "Arlington: The American Dream City" campaign. Both have contributed greatly to UTA. Dan received the Mid-Cities Entrepreneurial Achievement Award. Linda helped bring the International Folk Art Market to UTA. The couple also committed a gift toward the Dan Dipert University Welcome Center.

Tang research

The Texas Health Journal featured Liping Tang’s research that yielded a patent on a cancer trap.

Future of artificial intelligence

George Siemens, executive director of UTA's Learning Innovation and Networked Knowledge, or LINK, Research Lab, talked about the future of artificial intelligence in the world and the impact on the human workforce, The Epoch Times reported.

Group helps

Mohammad Mohammad, a UTA student, was featured in a KUT 90.5 FM story about Rohingya Muslims, an ethnic minority in Myanmar, formerly Burma. The Austin NPR station detailed how the Islamic Circle of North Texas helps the Rohingya Muslims, who are persecuted.

Autonomous vehicles project

The Arlington City Council is considering a proposal to start a pilot project placing autonomous vehicles in the entertainment district by this fall, the Star-Telegram and KXAS NBC 5 reported. The city also is meeting with UTA about possibly being a partner in the project. The delivery vehicles, which are ideal for groceries or small packages, could potentially be used on the campus.

Folk art market

The International Folk Art Market will be on display today and tomorrow at The Green at College Park on the UTA campus, Arlington-TX.gov and Southlake Style reported. Global folk art from 30 different countries will be featured.

Future workforce

The U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce Foundation has announced a University Partnership initiative with UTA and the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board to help build the workforce of the future, Hispanic Engineer & Information Technology reported.

STEM center

The STEM Center of Excellence recently debuted at Camp Whispering Cedars, just south of downtown Dallas, Park Cities People reported. The Girl Scout camp features robotics, computer coding, botany, chemistry and other science disciplines. UTA and other universities are providing instructional materials and training for troop leaders and volunteers.

Adjunct featured speaker

Ray Jordan, a UTA adjunct professor in the Center for African American Studies, was one of the featured speakers Wednesday at a 54th annual memorial service for the three civil rights workers murdered in 1964 by the Ku Klux Klan, the Neshoba Democrat in Philadelphia, Miss., reported.

Former teacher honored

Former Sam Houston High School teacher Judy Thomas was honored by the Arlington City Council, the Arlington Voice reported. Thomas earned her master’s degree in English from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, May 30, 2018
shortDescription: Indian American Friendship CouncilUTA President Vistasp Karbhari was among the community leaders who participated in the Indian American Friendship Co
body:
Indian American Friendship Council

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari was among the community leaders who participated in the Indian American Friendship Council reception for Nikki Randhawa Haley, United States Ambassador to United Nations, at the Four Seasons Hotel in Irving, NRI Press and News India Times reported. 

UTA professor featured

Michael Vasilyev, a UTA electrical engineer, was quoted extensively in IEEE Signal Processing Magazine about research that is working toward a signal processing-enabled photonics feature. Last year, Vasilyev and a colleague announced research results that could yield a dramatic reduction in the cost and energy consumption of high-speed internet connections. IEEE is the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.

Healing hearts

Juhyun Lee, an assistant professor in UTA’s Bioengineering Department, is working to determine how genes might be used to heal heart tissue damaged by heart attacks, Dallas Innovates  and Science and Technology Research News reported.

Diseased coral research

UTA researchers have found a correlation between a strong immune response in diseased corals and a lower expression of genes associated with growth and reproduction, Science Daily, Phys.org  and The TeCake reported. Laura Mydlarz, UTA associate professor and associate chair of biology, led the research, which was published this month in the Royal Society Open Science journal.

Artopia helping veterans

Many of the thousands of veterans attending UTA deal with disabilities and lingering trauma. Amanda Alexander, a UTA associate professor in art education, conducted research to find out whether these veterans could benefit from art therapy, KERA’s Art and Seek, Fort Worth Business Press and the Dallas Art Dealers Association reported.

Cancer trap

UTA bioengineer Liping Tang has invented an implantable medical device that attracts and kills circulating cancer cells, Clinical Trials Week and the Penn Bioengineering Blog reported. The cancer trap can be used for early diagnosis and treatment of metastasized cancer. UTA has patented the device in Europe.

Recycling industry

Sadahat Hossain, a UTA civil engineering professor was interviewed by Texas Standard and broadcast over Texas Public Radio about China’s decision to no longer import recycled trash from El Paso. “They made a regulation that impurity in recycling cannot be more than .5 percent,” Hossain says. “Before that, it was around 20 percent. To get to the level of .5 percent is almost impossible.”

Helping STe²M students

LaTasha Taylor Starr, a UTA industrial systems and manufacturing engineering doctoral student, and UTA mathematics doctoral student Ariel Bowman, have developed the ESTe²M Builders educational program to help young students gain knowledge and self-esteem through hands-on activities in science, technology, engineering, entrepreneurship and mathematics, or STe²M, ScienMag reported. 

Mom profiled

UTA nursing graduate and student Dorothy Osborne was featured in the Star-Telegram and many other media outlets discussing her experiences overcoming major obstacles to reach her professional goals, while helping her son graduate from Oklahoma State University and become a rookie with the Dallas Cowboys.

UTA student plans for med school

Mansfield teen and UTA student Melody Delatorre has left high school with an associate degree and plans for medical school at 18, NBC5DFW.com reported. She starts her final year of college this summer at UTA, then it's off to medical school next year -- where she'll still be only 18.

Pursuing nursing at UTA

Recent high school graduate Sarah Medlin, daughter of a deceased police officer, will be attending UTA this fall to pursue a nursing degree, KXAS NBC 5 , KDFW FOX 4 and the Mineral Wells Index reported. Her father’s colleagues accompanied her at her graduation. 

Special Olympics

More than 3,000 athletes from across Texas gathered at UTA for the Special Olympics of Texas, KDFW FOX 4 reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, June 4, 2018
shortDescription: LINK Lab fundingUTA researchers want to help shape the future with artificial intelligence, NBCDFW.com and KXAS NBC 5 reported. George Siemens, execut
body:
LINK Lab funding

UTA researchers want to help shape the future with artificial intelligence, NBCDFW.com and KXAS NBC 5 reported. George Siemens, executive director of UTA’s Learning Innovation and Networked Knowledge, or LINK, Research lab, received a grant from Boeing to study new learning environments and how artificial intelligence can play a role.

Navy grants

Andrew Makeev, a UTA aerospace engineering professor, has received two Office of Naval Research grants worth nearly $1.5 million that will further enhance UTA's Advanced Materials and Structures Lab’s national standing and capabilities, Photonics reported.

UTA study cited

A UTA study that found that birth mothers who decide to put a child up for adoption experience isolation, stigmatization and a lack of social and emotional support, both during pregnancy and after adoption, was cited in an op-ed article supporting adoption over abortion in The Telegraph in Macon, GA.

Op-ed lauds tax breaks

Richard Greene, professor in practice at UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, wrote an op-ed article in the Star-Telegram about the advantage of tax breaks for developments such as the Arlington Highlands retail development, which proved so successful the Arlington City Council terminated its tax break. Greene is a former Arlington mayor.

Symphony premiere

UTA alumnus Michael McElroy has premiered his first symphony, the St. Albert Gazette reported. The soft-spoken pastor studied trumpet in school and received an undergraduate degree at UTA before working on a double master of divinity and choral composition at Golden Gate Baptist Seminary in Mill Valley, Calif.

Volunteer of the Month

UTA alumna Yessica Macias received Volunteer of the Month for June, the City of Arlington reported. Macias joined the Arlington Police Department as a volunteer on Nov. 15, 2017. While a volunteer, Macias attended UTA to earn a degree in criminal justice.

Joint performance

Close to 200 varsity choir students from the four Killeen Independent School District high schools performed Mozart’s “Coronation Mass” under the direction of Karen Kenaston-French, UTA associate professor and director of choral activities, the Killeen Daily Herald reported.

Valedictorian to attend UTA

Citlally Lopez, valedictorian at Rosie M. Collins Sorrells School of Education and Social Services at Yvonne A. Ewell Townview Center, will attend UTA to pursue a degree in applied math pre-med, Dallas Patch reported. Several other valedictorians and salutatorians from Dallas school district who plan to attend UTA or transfer to UTA were included in the article.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, May 25, 2018
shortDescription: UTA laudedUTA is continuing its legacy of setting milestones of achievement across the broad spectrum of higher education, a Star-Telegram op-ed colum
body:
UTA lauded

UTA is continuing its legacy of setting milestones of achievement across the broad spectrum of higher education, a Star-Telegram op-ed column by Richard Greene said. The column praised the University’s outcomes in terms of preparing graduates for successful careers. Greene is a former Arlington mayor and an adjunct professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

Coral research

UTA researchers have found a correlation between a strong immune response in diseased corals and a lower expression of genes associated with growth and reproduction, Technology Networks reported. Laura Mydlarz, UTA associate professor and associate chair of biology, led the research, which was published this month in the Royal Society Open Science journal.

Space gaps

Bernd Chudoba, UTA aerospace engineering professor, has received a $250,000 grant from the Air Force Research Laboratory to develop a toolbox that planners can use to identify science and technology gaps related to space transportation issues, Techsite and Phys.org reported. The grant also would identify and rank emerging technologies that the United States needs to address.

Healing hearts

Juhyun Lee, an assistant professor in UTA’s Bioengineering Department, has been awarded a prestigious Career Development Award by the American Heart Association to determine how genes might be used to heal heart tissue, Techsite reported.

Sexual harassment

Texas lawmakers have recognized the need to establish and enforce policies against sexual harassment, but they have yet to reveal penalties for violators, The Dallas Morning News reported. The article quoted a recent report by M. Ann McFadyen and James Campbell Quick, two UTA management professors, that surveyed sexual harassment in the workplace. The report said the business world has a long way to go in addressing those concerns.

Special Olympics

The Special Olympics Texas Summer Games is making its way to UTA this week, KBTX CBS 3 in Bryan and KRLD 1080 AM reported. 

Alumna wins runoff

Lupe Valdez, former Dallas County sheriff, made history in Tuesday’s runoff elections by becoming the first Latina and the first openly gay person to win a major party’s nomination for governor in Texas, The New York Times reported. Valdez earned her master’s degree in criminology from UTA.

Cancer trap

UTA bioengineer Liping Tang has invented an implantable medical device that attracts and kills circulating cancer cells, Prostate Cancer News Today reported. UTA has patented the device in Europe.

UTA 23rd largest employer

UTA is the DFW area’s 23rd largest employer, DestinationDFW reported.

Scholarship winner

Umesh Bhandari, a UTA student, received the Scholarship America 2017 Dream Award, Great American Financial Resources reported. Scholarship America is the nation's largest nonprofit, private-sector scholarship and education support organization.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, June 8, 2018
shortDescription: NAE member joins UTANational Academy of Engineering member Robert Schafrik, an internationally renowned expert in materials and manufacturing, has joi
body:
NAE member joins UTA

National Academy of Engineering member Robert Schafrik, an internationally renowned expert in materials and manufacturing, has joined UTA, strengthening the university’s programs around manufacturing, materials and aerospace engineering, U.S. Fed News, Dallas Business Journal, Fort Worth Cityroom, The U.S. Press Association, IT News Online of India and more than 200 other media reported. The Texas Tribune’s The Blast subscription newsletter also covered the news for its political audience.

Brain performance

A UTA researcher's technology could revolutionize testing and tracking of brain performance, Biotech Week reported. George Kondraske, a UTA electrical engineering and bioengineering professor, also is the chief architect at RC21X, a Coraopolis, Pa.-based company set on delivering the brain performance technology.

Diseased coral research

UTA researchers have shed light on immune response in diseased corals, Biotech Week reported. The research was published this month in Royal Society Open Science as "Transcriptional analyses provide new insight into the late-stage immune response of a diseased Caribbean coral." Laura Mydlarz, UTA associate professor and associate chair of biology, was senior author. 

Nursing book review

Anne Bavier, dean of UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation, was interviewed by The Monitor on a new book by Susan Groenwald, “Designing & Creating a Culture of Care for Students and Faculty: The Chamberlain University College of Nursing Model.” “What truly distinguishes this text and the work it describes … is its thorough coverage of how caring can be operationalized — and made tangible — in all aspects of an organization's mission, vision, people, processes and practices,” Bavier said.

Medallion of Excellence

The Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute will award Michele Bobadilla, UTA senior associate vice president for Outreach Services and Community Engagement and assistant provost for Hispanic Student Services, with its prestigious Medallion of Excellence awards at the Institute’s 41st Annual Awards Gala on Sept. 13 in Washington, D.C., UNIVISION reported.

UTA keeps students

Texas is especially good at keeping their students around. UTA and other North Texas universities each keep more than 50 percent of their former students in the Dallas-Fort Worth area after graduation, The Dallas Morning News reported.

Political districts

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by Houston's KTRH 740 AM about a new report that shows Democratic Congressional districts tend to have more income inequality than red ones. “They (Republicans) have an obligation, if they want to win, to say that Democrats have represented these districts for a long time,” Saxe said.

Glass artist

Glass artist Jim Bowman, who helped create the glass program at UTA, is leaving Texas after 40 years, KERA’s “Art & Seek” reported.

Alumna overcomes

UTA nursing alumna Dorothy Osborne was featured on CBN News for her experience overcoming adversity. The recent graduate's story has gone viral on social media. Osborne's story orginally appeared in the Star-Telegram.

Principal appointment

UTA alumnus Adam Gray has been appointed principal of Vickery Elementary School in east Flower Mound, The Cross Timbers Gazette reported.

Alumna selected

UTA alumna Mollie Vega was selected as director of Secondary Leading and Learning for Brevard Public Schools where she’ll lead principals of multiple middle and high schools, the Brevard Times of Florida reported. She earned a bachelor’s degree in interdisciplinary studies from UTA.

Swimming the Pacific

UTA alumnus and swimmer Benoit “Ben” Lecomte, is trying to swim across the Pacific Ocean, Nachrichten Welt of Germany reported. Lecomte earned a master’s degree in architecture from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, June 25, 2018
shortDescription: Nuclear research prototypeA UTA team has built prototypes for an aluminum electric field cage inside a particle detector for an experiment conducted a
body:
Nuclear research prototype

A UTA team has built prototypes for an aluminum electric field cage inside a particle detector for an experiment conducted at the European Organization for Nuclear Research in Geneva, Dallas Innovates reported. 

Latino influence

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, commented on Texas’ growing Latino population for KXAS NBC 5. This politically diverse group can wield greater political power if they don't give all their power to one political party, Saxe said. 

Esports club

A UTA esports club has competed with thousands at Dreamhack 2018, the city of Arlington reported. The three-day festival was set in the expo hall at the Austin Convention Center and showcased esports tournaments, the latest gaming and tech gear, cosplay, non-gaming events and much more.

Hervey selected

The Oklahoma City Thunder selected UTA Maverick basketball forward Kevin Hervey with the 57th pick in the NBA draft, KXAS NBC 5 and many other media reported. Hervey is the Mavericks’ all-time leading rebounder and is second all-time in total points scored.

UTA student joins TechFW

UTA student Sandy El-Rayes has joined the Fort Worth-based nonprofit, TechFW, to build partnerships and oversee communications, Dallas Innovates reported. She is currently earning her executive master of business administration from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, June 18, 2018
shortDescription: Particle detectorUTA researchers have built prototypes for an aluminum electric field cage inside a particle detector for an international physics exp
body:
Particle detector

UTA researchers have built prototypes for an aluminum electric field cage inside a particle detector for an international physics experiment conducted at the European Organization for Nuclear Research in Geneva, Switzerland, DailyHunt, Infosurhoy, Phys.org and India’s International Business Times reported.

Former students to race

Former students in the UTA Formula Society of Automotive Engineers will race the team’s 1998 car against Cardiff University during the Formula One British Grand Prix next month, Electronic Specifier, Process and Control, and the West Wales Chronicle reported. The race will commemorate the 20th anniversary of UTA’s FSAE victory. The 1998 drivers will be driving the 20-year-old racecar, which UTA still has.

Folk art market

The International Folk Art Market displayed its wares this past weekend at The Green at College Park on the UTA campus, KDAF CW 33 reported. Global folk art from 30 different countries was featured.

Seniors study

Seniors aging at home have high hopes that academic research will make big changes for their needs and desires, IRIS reported. The story cited a survey conducted by Rupal Parekh, a UTA doctoral student, that showed surprising findings, including that 53 percent of those surveyed have limits due to mental, physical or emotional issues and that 54 percent have no one to help make medical decisions.

Hervey featured

UTA’s Kevin Hervey, who could be selected in the June 21 NBA Draft, has put himself on everyone’s radar with his basketball prowess at UTA and at the NBA Combine, Yahoo! Sports Canada, ESPN, Sports Illustrated and The Dallas Morning News reported.

Alumnus bullish on semiconductors

Harsh Kuman, managing director and senior research analyst at Piper Jaffray & Co. covering the semiconductor sector, is bullish on semiconductors during the rest of 2018, The Wall Street Transcript reported. Kuman earned his master’s degree in business administration from UTA. He was recognized as a Wall Street Journal "Best on the Street" analyst in 2008 and 2010.

UTA famous alumni

Ranker.com listed UTA’s most famous alumni. The top five include astronaut Kalpana Chawla, actor Lou Diamond Phillips, former Gen. Tommy Franks, politician and former Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez and economist/professor Roland Fryer.

Alumnus to join Knicks

Laredo native and Alexander High School graduate Kaleb Canales will be joining the New York Knicks’ coaching staff, the Laredo Morning Times and San Antonio Express-News reported. Canales is a UTA alumnus and was an assistant coach for UTA Maverick basketball.

CEO of the year

Lisa Nguyen, a UTA alumna, was named CEO of the Year by the was selected as Top CEO of the Year for 2018 by the International Association of Top Professionals, Crossroadstoday.com, KAVU ABC 25’s website in Victoria, Texas, reported.

Order of Omega

Arlington-tx.gov profiled the Order of Omega’s international headquarters in Arlington by the UTA campus, as part of the city’s American Dream City campaign. The Order of Omega was established as a recognition honor society to acknowledge those fraternity members/leaders who stand out in their community for their leadership, service and academics.

West Texas energy

When a section of a concrete wall recently collapsed at one of the world’s largest spring-fed pools and forced the closure of Balmorhea State Park to swimmers, some feared drilling, fracking or seismic activity related to the natural gas-oil work nearby caused it but local officials said it wasn't connected to that industry, the San Antonio Express-News reported. The article said UTA is conducting an ongoing water study that shows no contamination in the water.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, September 12, 2018
shortDescription: U.S. News rankingsU.S. News & World Report released its 2019 rankings for universities, KTVT CBS 11, the Houston Chronicle, Dallas CultureMap and San
body:
U.S. News rankings

U.S. News & World Report released its 2019 rankings for universities, KTVT CBS 11, the Houston Chronicle, Dallas CultureMap and San Antonio’s KTSA 550 AM reported. UTA was No. 221 on the list.

Texas Autocross

Collegiate auto racing teams from across the country will converge on The University of Texas at Arlington campus to rev their engines and compete against the clock at the 18th Annual Texas Autocross Weekend Sept. 15-16, Targeted News Service reported.

West campus buildings

UTA opened two new west campus buildings – West Hall, the university’s newest residence hall, and The Commons, a place for students, faculty, staff and community members to eat and meet, the Fort Worth Business Press reported.

Nanotechnology work

UTA researchers, working with the Department of Defense and Argonne National Laboratory, have made photosensors more sensitive to ultraviolet radiation through the use of nanotechnology, Nanowerk reported.

Building design changes

Shih-Ho Chao, UTA professor of civil engineering, wrote a DJC Oregon article about how building design has changed since 9/11.

Better barriers

Max Hu, a UTA associate professor of earth and environmental sciences, is evaluating various kinds of rock formations to assess which is a better barrier to isolate nuclear waste in long-term repositories, Science and Technology Research News reported.

Analytical chemistry impact

Kevin Schug, UTA associate professor of chemistry, authored an LCGC Blog post for the website Chromatography Online about the how analytical chemistry is central to all modern research. Schug also is the Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in the UTA Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry.

Sedentary lifestyles

New research led by UTA kinesiology professor Paul Fadel shows that simple leg exercises could reduce the impact of sedentary lifestyles on heart and blood vessels, derStandard.at, an Austrian newspaper, reported.

New CEO

The Massachusetts-based oncology specialist Agios Pharmaceuticals has appointed Jacqualyn Fouse, former Celgene president and chief operating officer, as its new chief executive officer, Pharmfile.com reported. Fouse earned bachelor’s and master’s degrees in economics and a doctorate in finance from UTA.

UTA sponsors event

UTA is a sponsor of the 10th annual TechFW IMPACT Awards luncheon Oct. 9 at TCU, Dallas citybizlist reported. UTA startup SolGro will be recognized for its work in developing a greenhouse material to convert sunlight into the best colors to grow plants.

Plate tectonics

Christopher Scotese, UTA professor emeritus of earth and environmental sciences, discussed a journal paper on the slowing down of plate tectonics as the earth’s mantle cools, China’s HuaxiaCaixun.com reported. The original article was in National Geographic.

Academic goals

Jim Nelson, Ector school district superintendent, listed improving academically, approving a tax ratification election and naming a permanent superintendent as his three goals this academic year, the Midland Reporter-Telegram reported. Nelson has a UTA bachelor of business administration degree.

Alumna named director

Julie Butticarlo has joined Westmount Realty Capital as a director, IREI reported. Butticarlo earned a UTA bachelor’s degree in marketing.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, June 22, 2018
shortDescription: Burnout exploredJames Campbell Quick, the John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy at UTA and a manage
body:
Burnout explored

James Campbell Quick, the John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy at UTA and a management professor, said there are financial consequences for companies that ignore the mental health of their workforce, Forbes reported in an article about why there is so much burnout in the tech industry. “There are huge, if sometimes hard to calculate, financial costs associated with poor mental health at work," Quick said.

ASLA smart policies

The American Society of Landscape Architects released its smart policies for a changing climate, EnvironmentGuru, Landscape Architecture Magazine and Prism reported. ASLA’s Blue Ribbon Panel on Climate Change and Resilience released the list of standard development practices to help secure a more sustainable future. Diane Jones Allen, program director for landscape architecture in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, served on the panel. Allen also is a principal landscape architect with DesignJones LLC.

Recruiting STEM teachers

The National Science Foundation has awarded close to $1.5 million in a Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program grant to The University of Texas at Arlington to promote the recruitment, preparation and induction of new science and mathematics teachers, bionorthTX In The Know newsletter reported.

read a news excerpt

Hervey drafted
