Kevin Hervey, a UTA basketball player, was selected by the Oklahoma City Thunder with the 57th pick in last night’s NBA Draft, ESPN, The Dallas Morning News, The Oklahoman and Star-Telegram reported. Hervey is the Mavericks’ all-time leading rebounder and is second all-time in total points scored. The News also had a national and local reaction story on Hervey’s selection.

UTA startup

A UTA startup, SolGro, is using special greenhouse nanotechnology to convert incoming sunlight from all colors of the spectrum into red and blue light, which encourages better plant growth, Dallas Innovates reported. The SolGro team includes Wei Chen, a UTA physics professor who specializes in nanotechnology and material sciences. Chen said the technology could increase food production by at least 50 percent.

Alumnus exhibit

Colorado-based architect Mark Harris pushes boundaries from what is to what can be with his exhibit at the 2018 International Venice Biennale, Modern in Denver reported. Each project in the exhibit transcends architecture to investigate human culture with an optimistic vision of our “future future,” depicting what already exists in radical and innovative ways. Harris is a UTA architecture alumnus.

Tarrant County demographics

Rebecca Deen, UTA chair of the Department of Political Science, said Tarrant County may be changing to more Democrats demographically but that doesn’t mean they all go out and vote, the Texas Standard reported in a story that aired on KUT 90.5 FM in Austin.

Little chance at change

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said there isn’t a great chance of Congress making new immigration law because of the divisiveness in Washington, D.C., Miami’s WIOD 610 AM reported.

Textbook guide

The book Designing & Creating a Culture of Care for Students and Faculty: The Chamberlain University College of Nursing Model serves as a guide for any organization seeking to make cultural and structural changes to improve student or employee satisfaction, engagement and achievement, the KXRA 1490 AM and KXRA 92.3 FM website reported. Anne Bavier, UTA College of Nursing and Health Innovation dean and the National League for Nursing president, said the book describes how caring can be operationalized.

Civil rights speaker

Ray Jordan, UTA adjunct professor of African-American studies, presented a sermon advocating people to tell their history of civil rights and celebrate those who gave their lives for that cause, the Philadelphia, Miss.-based Neshoba Democrat reported. Jordan, who also is the senior pastor of Central United Church of Christ in Dallas, spoke at the 54th annual memorial service for the three civil rights workers murdered in 1964 by the Ku Klux Klan.

Expo exhibit

UTA’s College of Engineering will display unmanned aerial systems at the 2018 Commercial UAV Expo Oct. 1-3 in Las Vegas, WAVE NBC 3 in Louisville, Ky., and other websites reported. It will be one of more than 100 exhibits at the expo.

World Cup fever

Hassan Sedky, a 25-year-old Egyptian who is pursuing dual master’s degrees from UTA, was profiled in an F3News story after being photographed as he was carried in his wheelchair by a joyous World Cup crowd. Sedky’s compelling story included his playing on UTA’s Movin’ Mavs 2017 National Championship team.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, June 20, 2018
shortDescription: Pipe testingA UTA study that examined chemical emissions of cured-in-place pipe, or CIPP, showed it to be non-conclusive, UC Underground Construction
body:
Pipe testing

A UTA study that examined chemical emissions of cured-in-place pipe, or CIPP, showed it to be non-conclusive, UC Underground Construction and Trenchless Technology reported. UTA’s Center for Underground Infrastructure Research and Education, or CURIE, and the Institute for Underground Infrastructure in Germany conducted the study. Mo Najafi, director of CUIRE, supervised this project. Melanie Sattler, UTA associate professor of civil engineering, and Kevin Schug, UTA chemistry professor, contributed to the study.

FSAE alums to race

Sudents in UTA’s Formula Society of Automotive Engineers will race the team’s 1998 car against Cardiff University during the Formula One British Grand Prix next month, Design Products & Applications Magazine reported. The race will commemorate the 20th anniversary of UTA’s collegiate victory in FSAE competition. The 1998 drivers will be driving the 20-year-old racecar, which UTA still has.

Champion high jumper

Junior Alexus Henry became the first UTA woman ever to win an individual national championship, taking the title in the women’s high jump at the NCAA Outdoor Track & Field Championships at Oregon’s Hayward Field, KXAS NBC 5 and VYPE SE Texas reported.

World Cup fever

Hassan Sedky, a 25-year-old Egyptian who is pursuing dual master’s degrees from UTA, was profiled in CNN, KingFut.com and Carbonated.tv stories after being photographed as he was carried in his wheelchair by a joyous World Cup crowd. Sedky’s compelling story included his playing on UTA’s Movin’ Mavs 2017 National Championship team.

Parade route

The Arlington Fourth of July Parade will change routes this year due to Abrams Street construction, the Arlington Voice reported. Much of the parade route borders or goes through UTA’s campus.

New president

Nuverra Environmental Solutions Inc. named Robert Fox as president and chief operating officer, Markets Insider, Street Insider and many other websites reported. Fox earned his bachelor’s degree in accounting from UTA.

Scholarship winner

Kilee Torrez, a UTA junior, received a Dallas Press Club scholarship, the Gilmer Mirror reported.

Alumnus named president

William Smith was named president of Nissan Chemical America Corp., DMN Newswire reported. Smith earned his bachelor’s degree from UTA.

Marketing director

Sandy El-Rayes has joined TechFW as marketing director, CityBizList reported. She is currently earning an Executive Master of Business Administration degree from UTA.

New chief commercial officer

Jay Thomas has been named the chief commercial officer of Urban Air Adventure Park, PR Newswire, InPark Magazine, newKerala.com and other websites reported. Thomas received his bachelor’s degree in management from UTA.

Look to Houston park

Dallas should learn how to build Trinity Park from Houston’s Buffalo Bayou, Mark Lamster wrote in a Dallas Morning News column. Lamster is a professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, September 7, 2018
shortDescription: Transfer pathwayUTA President Vistasp Karbhari said UTA has an agreement with Tarrant County College to create an official transfer pathway that inclu
body:
Transfer pathway

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari said UTA has an agreement with Tarrant County College to create an official transfer pathway that includes advising to help students take the right courses needed for a degree. The Dallas Morning News reported about the agreement in detailing a state Senate Higher Education Committee meeting concerning difficulties students have transferring between community colleges and four-year institutions. KRLD 1080 AM aired a similar story.

Hill kicks off series

UTA announced the speakers for its annual Maverick Speakers Series, The Dallas Morning News reported. Graham Hill of TreeHugger.com will kick off the season at 7:30 p.m. Sept. 13 at Texas Hall, 701 W. Nedderman Drive. 

Longtime UTA employee

Zebedee Strong Jr., a founding member of both the Arlington African American Chamber of Commerce and the Arlington NAACP, died this past Saturday, NBCDFW.com and the Kilgore News Herald reported. Strong, formerly of Kilgore, was a longtime UTA employee and an alumnus.

Cleanup grant

Hyeok Choi, a UTA associate professor of civil engineering, will use a U.S. Department of Defense grant that will allow easier cleanup of contaminated soil and water that the U.S. military has identified, Techsite reported.

Finding better barriers

Max Hu, a UTA associate professor of earth and environmental sciences, is evaluating various kinds of rock formations to assess which is a better barrier to isolate nuclear waste in long-term repositories, World Industrial Reporter and NewsEdge.com reported.

NSF fellowship

Kathleen Currie, a UTA doctoral student in biology, has received a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program grant to fund her research in genetic variation in whiptail lizards, News-Medical.net and Targeted News Service reported.

Underground freight system

UTA researchers have completed a study showing how an underground freight system could be used at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, Transportation Research reported. Sia Ardekani, a recently retired UTA civil engineering professor, led the study. The study found that such a system would greatly reduce truck traffic within the DFW Airport area and consequently improve safety, efficiency and air quality. The study was published in ScienceDirect.

Improving outcomes

Diane Snow, UTA clinical professor in the College of Nursing and Health Innovation, wrote a column describing how managing psychiatric disorders, assessing risk factors and educating patients are keys to improve outcomes for patients using opioids, Medical Xpress and Medicalnewser.com reported.

Reducing textbook costs

Yash Singh, UTA student body president, signed a letter from student organizations to Congress urging lawmakers to renew and strengthen the Open Textbooks Pilot, uspirg.org reported. The effort is aimed at reducing the costs of textbooks.

UTA ranked

UTA ranked No. 9 in the country on the best values list at SmartAsset, Dallas CultureMap reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, August 31, 2018
shortDescription: West campus buildingsKDFW FOX 4 and KRLD 1080 AM reported on the opening of UTA’s West Hall and The Commons, the new west campus residence and dining
body:
West campus buildings

KDFW FOX 4 and KRLD 1080 AM reported on the opening of UTA’s West Hall and The Commons, the new west campus residence and dining facility, respectively. Students expressed their delight with the new facilities, especially the new Starbucks.

NIH grant on enzymes

UTA biochemists are mapping the function of specific enzymes which may facilitate development of new drugs to fight bacterial infection, cancer and potentially neurodegenerative diseases like autism, Down syndrome, Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's, Phys.org and Targeted News Service reported. Brad Pierce, UTA associate professor of biochemistry, recently received a $429,033 National Institutes of Health grant to continue his research mapping out of the chemical mechanism of three key enzymes. 

Maverick Speakers Series

A sustainability innovator, an actor-artist-activist, a science historian, an animal conservationist and an actor-playwright-professor make for an exceptionally strong lineup for the 11th annual University of Texas at Arlington's Maverick Speakers Series, U.S. Fed News and Targeted News Service reported. 

Plate tetonics

Christopher Scotese, UTA professor emeritus of earth and environmental sciences, was interviewed by National Geographic and MSN.com about a journal paper on the slowing down of plate tectonics as the earth’s mantle cools. Instead of a gradual slowdown, Scotese predicts that plate tectonics will be invigorated during the next one to two billion years, before the conveyor belt ends. 

Pain recomendations

Robert Gatchel, UTA Distinguished Professor of Psychology, led a federal advisory group that has published its recommendations on the prevention of acute and chronic pain to the Federal Research Pain Strategy, an interagency committee that oversees the government's long-term strategic plan to support pain research, Drug Week reported. 

Fighting pathogens

Mark Pellegrino, UTA assistant professor of biology, has won a five-year, $1.8 million grant from the National Institutes of Health to look at new ways to harness the body's own defense responses to fight pathogens like bacteria, Cancer Weekly reported. 

Clinton's emails

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by WIOD 610 AM in Miami, Fla., about the report that Chinese entities had infiltrated Hillary Clinton’s email server to the point that they were receiving all her mails in real-time. He said that it was likely true. 

Sexual abuse research

UTA research was cited in a Philadelphia Inquirer op-ed about sexual abuse of children by catholic priests. The UTA research studied sexual abuse cases as reported by Protestant churches to insurance companies contracted by these religious organizations and demonstrates that the Catholic Church was not alone in its failings.

Student spends summer at Cambridge

UTA senior Michael Oladugba spent his 2018 summer break at the University of Cambridge studying mutations in the DNA of fruit flies as part of the UT System's Summer Research Academy Abroad program, Targeted News Service reported. "It was a dream come true to be able to study at Cambridge, one of the world's greatest universities," Oladugba said. "As a pre-med, it also strengthened my resume to the point where I can aspire to top medical schools such as Stanford, as long as my MCAT and grades are good enough," he added.

Prestigious fellowship

Marialis Rosario-Franco, a UTA doctoral student in physics, has been awarded a prestigious fellowship to continue her doctoral studies in exomoons - moons which orbit planets located in other stellar systems, Physics Week and NewsRX Health and Science reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, September 21, 2018
shortDescription: Smart seat cushionUTA has patented a smart seat cushion that uses changes in air pressure to redistribute body weight and help prevent the painful ulc
body:
Smart seat cushion

UTA has patented a smart seat cushion that uses changes in air pressure to redistribute body weight and help prevent the painful ulcers caused by sitting for long periods of time in a wheelchair, Science Daily, Phys.org, Tech Site, Rehab Management, Medgadget, Medical Newsline and The Business Standard of India reported. Muthu Wijesundara, chief research scientist at UTA’s Research Institute, was co-inventor of the technology, which can also be used to create prosthetic liners that accommodate changes in body volume to maintain a comfortable fit.

Navy-UTA partnership

UTA and the Naval Surface Warfare Center's Philadelphia Division entered into a formal Education Partnership Agreement on Sept. 11, Defense Visual Information Distribution Service reported. The UTA agreement allows NSWCPD to make its scientific, engineering, technology assets and subject matter experts available to University faculty to enhance both their research activities and the educational experience of UTA students.

Tare appointed

A UTA administrator has been appointed to the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine's Board on Higher Education and Workforce, Policy and Global Affairs, Targeted News Service reported. Meghna Tare, UTA's executive director of the Institute for Sustainability and Global Impact, will serve a three-year term on the board.

Sexual harassment

Jim Quick, UTA professor emeritus in the College of Business, was interviewed by KXAS NBC 5 about the sexual harassment allegations in the Dallas Mavericks business office. He said that society struggles to define sexual harassment and understand what's often behind it. Quick and a colleague, Ann McFadyen, UTA associate professor of management, compiled a 2017 study looking at sexual harassment in the workplace and what has or has not changed during the last 20 years.

Architect analysis

Mark Lamster, UTA associate professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, wrote an analysis on the importance of architect Robert Venturi for The Dallas Morning News. Venturi died this week. 

Travel award

Leni Matthews, UTA user experience librarian, was awarded a travel award from The Association of Research Libraries to attend the 2018 Library Assessment Conference in Houston, Dec. 5-7, Targeted News Service reported. The Library Assessment Conference Travel Awards are offered to students and early-career professionals from historically underrepresented racial and ethnic groups. 

UTA among most affordable

UTA is among the Texas universities that offer the best, most affordable education for middle-class students, The Beaumont Enterprise reported in refernece to rankings published by the education data site Niche.

UTA conducts assessment

Jubilee Park in Dallas is working with UTA on a community needs-assessment, which will include property in next door to Fair Park, The Dallas Morning News reported. Jubilee Park CEO Ben Leal figures it will be some kind of multifamily development, maybe for seniors, with resource centers, food banks and other necessities. 

Senior care

Seniorcare.com, an online resource dedicated to informing consumers on the realities and options within the senior care industry, recently conducted a study in association with the UTA regarding seniors aging alone, The Sociable reported. The study shows that 52 percent reported being lonely, 70 percent have not identified a would-be caregiver and 35 percent have no help in a crisis. 

Via expanding

The City of Arlington and Via, the city’s current rideshare service, have announced an expansion of the public transportation service area south to the Interstate 20 region, KRLD 1080 AM, ArlingtonTx.gov and The Arlington Voice reported. UTA has a stop as part of this program. 

PhD student receives grant

A UTA doctoral student in biology has received a prestigious grant to fund her research in genetic variation in whiptail lizards, NewsRx Health and Life Science Weekly reported. Kathleen Currie, a third-year doctoral student, was awarded a Graduate Research Fellowship Program grant by the National Science Foundation.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, September 10, 2018
shortDescription: UTA rankedThe University of Texas at Arlington is nationally ranked No. 221 on the U.S. News & World Report’s Best Colleges for 2019 list, which was r
body:
UTA ranked

The University of Texas at Arlington is nationally ranked No. 221 on the U.S. News & World Report’s Best Colleges for 2019 list, which was released Monday, Sept. 10, Arlington-TX.gov reported. UTA also ranked No. 126 among top public universities in the magazine’s rankings.

Strong tribute

U.S. Rep. Marc Veasey, D-Fort Worth, lauded UTA employee Zeb Strong on C-SPAN. Strong died earlier this month. Veasey said Strong embodied the spirit of the UTA campus. He called Strong a uniting force in the university's halls.

Better waste barrier

Max Hu, a UTA associate professor of earth and environmental sciences, is evaluating various kinds of rock formations to assess which is a better barrier to isolate nuclear waste in long-term repositories, Dallas Innovates reported.

Fellowship awarded

Kathleen Currie, a UTA doctoral student in biology, has received a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program grant to fund her research in genetic variation in whiptail lizards, Medicalnewser.com reported.

Cross Connections exhibition

The University of Texas at Arlington was one of the institutions participating in the UT Rio Grande Valley’s Cross Connections exhibition of fine art, Targeted News Service and several other media outlets reported.

STEM strategies

Two UT El Paso professors will work with The University of Texas at Arlington to address effective teaching strategies in the science, technology, engineering and math fields, the El Paso Herald-Post reported. The effort is part of a National Science Foundation grant.

West Hall

Richardson-based Hill & Wilkinson built West Hall, UTA’s new 534-bed residence hall, RE Business Online reported.

Changing marketplace

Kenda North, UTA professor of photography, was part of the roundtable discussion of a business summit titled "Conquer the Changing Marketplace" this past weekend in Oak Cliff, The Dallas Observer reported.

Global education fair

The University of Texas at Arlington was one of the participants in an Institute of Management and Foreign Studies global education fair, India’s Telangana Today reported.

Alumna named associate

Spacesmith, a New York City-based architecture firm, has appointed Amy Jarvis to associate, Commercial Construction & Renovation Magazine reported. Jarvis received a UTA master’s degree in architecture.

Adjunct makes finalist list

The city of Woodway near Waco has named Bob Hart as a finalist for its city manager position, the Waco Tribune-Herald reported. Hart has served as an adjunct faculty member at UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

New managing editor

About Dallas Magazine named Christine Muir as managing editor. Muir is currently a regional planning student at UTA.

Scholarship winner

Claire Sissons, a 2018 graduate of Texas’ New Boston High School, was awarded a $1,500 scholarship from the Texarkana, Texas, Council of Garden Clubs, the Texarkana Gazette reported. She will be attending UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, September 14, 2018
shortDescription: Fracking wastewater useThe American Society of Engineering Education’s First Bell newsletter highlighted a UTA opinion piece in The Dallas Morning New
body:
Fracking wastewater use

The American Society of Engineering Education’s First Bell newsletter highlighted a UTA opinion piece in The Dallas Morning News on using fracking wastewater in the oil and gas industry. Zacariah Hildenbrand, UTA consultant and alumnus, and Kevin Schug, UTA’s Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry, wrote the piece. They operate UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR lab. The article is highlighted under the Research and Development category in First Bell.

U.S. News rankings

UTA is ranked No. 11 in Texas according to the latest Best Colleges list from U.S. News & World Report, Fort Worth CultureMap reported.

3D shapes created

Kyungsuk Yum, an assistant professor in UTA’s Materials Science and Engineering Department, and his doctoral student, Amirali Nojoomi, have developed a process by which 2D hydrogels can be programmed to enable the formation of complex 3D shapes and motions, R&D Magazine, Space Daily, Health Medicine Network and other media outlets reported. Potential applications for the technology include bioinspired soft robotics, artificial muscles and programmable matter.

Jumping genes

Esther Betran, UTA biology professor, will be using the high-tech tools provided by the North Texas Genome Center to shed light on the role of  “jumping genes,” Phys.org, News-Medical and Targeted News Service reported. Jumping genes make up a large fraction of the genome and are responsible for much of the mass of DNA in cells. They are known as jumping genes because they change their position or copy themselves within the genome. The research is part of an NSF grant Betran received.

Rewilding popular

What makes rewilding distinct is that it defines an inventory of natural life that is worked back into the environment and practically supported, wrote Kevin Sloan, a UTA landscape architecture professor in practice and professional landscape architect in Dallas, in a column about rewilding for The Dallas Morning News. Rewilding is an approach to landscape and environmental development that is sweeping the globe.

Mapping enzymes

UTA biochemists are mapping the function of specific enzymes that may facilitate the development of new drugs to fight bacterial infection, cancer and diseases, Pharma Business Week reported. Brad Pierce, UTA associate professor of biochemistry, is leading the study with an National Institutes of Health grant.

Heroic debate

Sam Haynes, UTA professor of history and director of the Center for Greater Southwestern Studies, said he agreed with a recent committee to remove the word heroic from school textbooks when describing Alamo combatants, Austin’s KUT 90.5 FM reported. Haynes said state officials issued the study as a kind of “moral instruction." He said the history profession has come a long way since then. Part 2 of the interview can be heard here.

TMAC state executive director

Mark Sessumes, metroplex regional director, was selected as TMAC's state executive director, Targeted News Service reported. One of TMAC’s regional centers is at UTA. TMAC’s mission is to improve the global competitiveness of the Texas economy by working to grow the extended manufacturing enterprise.

Better sensors

UTA researchers, working with the Department of Defense and Argonne National Laboratory, have made photosensors more sensitive to ultraviolet radiation through the use of  nanotechnology, Science Daily, R&D Magazine, Phys.org and other media outlets reported.

Texas Autocross

Collegiate auto racing teams from across the country will converge on The University of Texas at Arlington campus to rev their engines and compete against the clock at the 18th Annual Texas Autocross Weekend Sept. 29-30, U.S. Fed News reported.

Book featured

Alusine Jalloh, UTA associate professor of history, was featured in a story about his book “Muslim Fula Business Elites and Politics in Sierra Leone,” Sierra Leone’s The Organiser reported.

3D vision technology

Christopher McMurrough, UTA senior lecturer in computer science and engineering, and James Staud, UTA graduate, are working on 3D vision technology, robotics and automation, Arlington-tx.gov reported in the city’s American Dream City series.

Golf director wins

Stuart Deane, UTA director of golf, shot 65-66 for 131 to win the North Texas PGA's Joyce Crane/Veritex Bank Section Championship at Old American Golf Club in The Colony, The Dallas Morning News reported. It was Deane's third section championship title and 14th individual major championship.

Texas Trust-UTA pact

Texas Trust Credit Union is kicking off its fifth year of strategic partnership with UTA, CUInsight.com reported. According to Jim Baker, UTA athletics director, “Students attending games at College Park Center will have access to student-centric specials, games, merchandise, and more, available exclusively within the Texas Trust corridor before and during the games.”

Band is committed

UTA student Lauren Pinto said BTS, a South Korean pop boy band, has a commitment to social justice that makes the band stand out compared to American or British boy bands, the Star-Telegram reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, September 17, 2018
shortDescription: Medallion of ExcellenceThe Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute awarded Michele Bobadilla, UTA senior associate vice president for outreach service
body:
Medallion of Excellence

The Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute awarded Michele Bobadilla, UTA senior associate vice president for outreach services and community engagement and assistant provost for Hispanic student services, with its prestigious Medallion of Excellence awards at the Institute’s 41st Annual Awards Gala on Sept. 13 in Washington, D.C., KUVS 19 Univision in Sacramento, Calif., reported.

NSF post

Minerva Cordero, a UTA mathematics professor and an associate dean in the College of Science, has accepted a one-year position in the National Science Foundation's Division of Education and Human Resource Development as program director of the ADVANCE and Hispanic-Serving Institutions or HSI programs, Targeted News Service reported. She said working with these programs is meaningful because it builds upon her work and expertise on key issues facing women and other historically underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering and mathematics or STEM fields.

Mentor grant

A UTA associate professor has received a state grant that will support hiring mentors to guide and encourage students in the Pathways Program at local GO Centers, Targeted News Service reported. Carla Amaro-Jimenez, associate professor in the College of Education's Department of Curriculum and Instruction and director of the Pathways to College Access and Career Readiness Program, was awarded a Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board grant to support the effort.

Short story dispenser

UTA Libraries recently installed the first short story dispenser in the state of Texas, Targeted News Service reported. The dispenser delivers literature, both classic and contemporary works of art, in a vending machine style. Users can select whether they want a one, three or five-minute story by pressing a simple button. The dispenser will then print a randomly selected short story on a scroll type paper.

Keynote speaker

Adrian Parr, dean of UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, was the keynote speaker at the Constructing Architectural Ecologies symposium organized by the Architectural Ecologies Lab at California College of the Arts, The Potrero View in San Francisco reported. Her presentation examined how built environments are turned into weapons of war, as with the leveling of cities like Aleppo or Gaza, and the ecological ramifications of warfare as it pertains to the built environment and sustainable design.

Jumping genes

Esther Betran, UTA professor of biology, will be using the high-tech tools provided by the North Texas Genome Center to shed light on the role of ‘jumping genes,’ MedicalNewser reported. She recently won a $570,197 National Science Foundation grant for this functional and comparative genomics research.

Programming hydrogels

Kyungsuk Yum, an assistant professor in UTA’s Materials Science and Engineering Department, and his doctoral student, Amirali Nojoomi, have developed a process by which 2D hydrogels can be programmed to expand and shrink in a space- and time-controlled way that applies force to their surfaces, enabling the formation of complex 3D shapes and motions, Haptic of Romania, The Times of News of Russia, Innovations Report, R & D Magazine and Dallas Innovates reported. Potential applications for the technology include bioinspired soft robotics, artificial muscles and programmable matter. 

Student lands job

UTA administrative assistant Akina Brodeak was featured in a Star-Telegram article which describes how she stood on a street corner with resumes to try to get a job. She was eventually successful and now works for UTA.

Esports in tourney

UTA’s esports team will be competing in the collegiate Overwatch tournament Powered by the Dallas Fuel and Team Envy on Saturday, Sept. 22, WICZ Fox 40 in Binghampton, N.Y., and many other media reported. The two-day event will take place at the Irving Convention Center. 

Alumnus on editorial staff

UTA alumnus David Dunn has joined the editorial staff of The Midlothian Mirror and Waxahachie Daily Light, the Waxahachie Daily Light reported. Dunn was the film critic for the UTA student newspaper The Shorthorn. 

Architecture awards

Mark Harris, principal of markharris Architects, received three Rethinking the Future Awards for Sustainable Design, the Colorado Springs Gazette reported. Harris has a UTA bachelor's degree in architecture, urban planning and environmental design.

New TechFW director

Hayden Blackburn has been promoted to executive director of TechFW, Dallas Business Journals, Dallas Innovates and Dallas citybizlist reported. He succeeds Darlene Boudreaux, who will continue part-time as one of the coaches for TechFW clients. UTA has an agreement with TechFW, a non-profit technology incubator.

Tour comes to UTA

More than 650 high school students participated in the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities and U.S. Army University Tour hosted at The University of Texas at Arlington recently, Targeted News Service reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, October 1, 2018
shortDescription: SEIR openingUTA is taking big strides toward becoming a health research powerhouse in the North Texas area, KTVT CBS 11, DFW.CBSlocal.com, KDFW FOX 4,
body:
SEIR opening

UTA is taking big strides toward becoming a health research powerhouse in the North Texas area, KTVT CBS 11, DFW.CBSlocal.com, KDFW FOX 4, The Dallas Morning News, ASEE First Bell, Fort Worth Business Press and Arlington-Tx.gov reported. Last Friday, UTA officially dedicated its new Science & Engineering Innovation & Research building, or SEIR, which includes teaching areas as well as 12 research neighborhoods.

Next generation

UTA’s Department of Computer Science and Engineering students are learning to build the next generation of computer interfaces, Dallas Innovates reported. Studying problems in human-computer interactions, they are developing autonomous trucks, and using gamification to help workers work more effectively and safely with robots in manufacturing facilities.

Kavanaugh hearings

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by KLIF 570 AM and many other media about hearings related to U.S. Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh and the decision to conduct an FBI investigation into his behavior.

UTA employee featured

Shaunda Musick continues to live her dream in working at various jobs throughout Arlington, Arlington-tx.gov reported. The city website featured Musick as part of its American Dream City video series. The 2013 UTA graduate is now the in-game host during all Dallas Cowboys home games and also performs hosting duties for FC Dallas, UTA men's and women's basketball games and the Dallas Wings at College Park Center, while working fulltime as UTA alumni relations coordinator.

Alumna named to board

UTA alumna Deborah Messemer has been named to the Board of Directors of Allogene Therapeutics, Inc., a clinical-stage biotechnology company pioneering the development of allogeneic CAR T therapies for cancer, the Odessa American reported. She received a bachelor’s degree in accounting from UTA.

Statewide appointment

UTA alumna Dian Cuellar Ruud, a clinical social worker at the University of Texas Counseling and Mental Health Center, has been named to the board of the Texas ACLU, Targeted News Service reported. She earned her doctorate in social work from UTA.

Teacher profiled

UTA alumna Linda Harrelson, a second grade teacher at Sam Houston Elementary, is this week’s featured teacher, the Corsicana Daily Sun reported. She also earned her master's degree in curriculum and instruction in reading and English as a Second Language from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, October 8, 2018
shortDescription: Helping studentsUTA’s Carla Amaro-Jiménez, an associate professor in the College of Education, helps first-generation and Hispanic students overcome o
body:
Helping students

UTA’s Carla Amaro-Jiménez, an associate professor in the College of Education, helps first-generation and Hispanic students overcome obstacles in their higher education journeys, The Washington Post reported in an article produced by The Hechinger Report, an independent, nonprofit newsroom covering in-depth education topics. UTA is one of the few universities that explicitly includes its faculty in working to meet these academic challenges. “A person can make a change,” Amaro-Jiménez said, “just by asking questions and showing that they care.”

Sprawl study

A UTA study that shows urban sprawl reducing a person’s life expectancy was mentioned on the Clark Howard Show on WOKV 690 AM in Jacksonville, Fla. UTA’s Shima Hamidi, an assistant professor of urban planning in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, published the study earlier this year in the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health.

Student voter registration

Dallas’ KUVN Univision 23 interviewed several UTA students on a voting registration drive they were conducting.

Successful habits

UTA’s James Campbell Quick, professor emeritus in the College of Business, said reflecting on past experiences may get to the bottom of why one feels blue on Mondays, Australia’s Business Insider reported. The story was about what successful people do on Sunday evenings. It initially ran in the Huffington Post.

UTA-Navy education agreement

UTA and the Naval Surface Warfare Center Philadelphia signed an education partnership agreement, Dallas Innovates reported. The pact could involve faculty and students from UTA in U.S. Navy research projects, loan equipment to the university for educational purposes, and, perhaps, develop and teach science and engineering courses at the University.

Hearings turn ugly

UTA’s Allan Saxe, an associate professor of political science, said people have been turned off by the hearings leading up to the appointment of Brett Kavanaugh as a U.S. Supreme Court justice, WBAP 820 AM reported. Saxe believes the hearings were a blemish on the U.S. Senate and American democracy.

DUNE project

A UTA physics team is working on a neutrino detector project as part of DUNE, or Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment, Lifeinism.com reported. “Our project is to lead work on the DUNE prototype field cage and detectors being developed in collaboration with many European institutions while the U.S. research facilities are being built,” said Jaehoon Yu, UTA physics professor and lead on the DUNE project for UTA.

More sensitive sensors

Stephen Magill, physicist at the U.S. Department of Energy’s Argonne National Laboratory, is working with a UTA team to make more sensitive photosensors that would better detect ultraviolet radiation, Spaceflight News reported.

UTA in international college fair

Thirty-three U.S. universities, including UTA, participated in the largest U.S. college fair in Pakistan, The Balochistan Times, the Business Recorder and the Daily Times, all of Pakistan, reported.

Alumnus named VP

Perstorp, a specialty chemicals company, has appointed Jim Ren as vice president of the Asia Pacific market, eFeedLink.com reported. Ren earned his executive MBA from UTA.

Alumna joins Christus

Tracy Casey has joined Christus Trinity Clinic-Gladewater, the Longview News-Journal reported. Casey earned her bachelor’s degree in nursing at UTA.

Final community meeting

The city of Fort Worth Race and Culture Task Force will hold the last of its community meetings at 6 p.m. Thursday at the UTA Research Institute, KTVT CBS 11 reported.

Statewide committee appointment

Rich Stoglin was appointed by Gov. Greg Abbott to the Texas State Board of Examiners of Marriage and Family Therapists, the Guidry News reported. Stoglin, CEO of Arlington’s The Stoglin Group, earned his master’s degree in public administration from UTA.

UTA attorney a finalist

Shelby Boseman, UTA’s university attorney, was a finalist for the 2018 D CEO Corporate Counsel Awards, D Magazine reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, November 16, 2018
shortDescription: UTA offers community feelingMichele Bobadilla, senior associate vice president for Outreach Services & Community Engagement, told KXTX Telemundo 39 th
body:
UTA offers community feeling

Michele Bobadilla, senior associate vice president for Outreach Services & Community Engagement, told KXTX Telemundo 39 that UTA is a great community and safe campus for students to excel. Telemundo was on campus for its 4 p.m. newscast yesterday. Bobadilla, who also is the assistant provost for Hispanic Student Services, said UTA offers students a great family atmosphere to learn everything the University has to offer.

Good job choice

Dennis Chiessa, architecture lecturer in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, told KXTX Telemundo 39 that studying to become an architect is a good job choice to make a decent wage. The Telemundo piece was about where Latino students have financial opportunities.

UTA band, cheerleaders featured

KXTX Telemundo 39 was on the UTA campus for much of its 4 p.m. newscast yesterday. This segment included the UTA band, cheerleaders, the spirit team and students.

Tech talent drives decisions

Duane Dimos, UTA vice president for research, said that if a region brings a major new facility like Amazon to the area, technical and business talent is driving that decision, KTVT CBS 11 and KRLD 1080 AM reported.

Lubricant patent

UTA has been awarded a patent for a lubricant composition that can be used as a universal grease for aircraft, World Industrial Reporter, Phys.org, Scienmag and Techsite reported. Pranesh Aswath, a professor of materials science and engineering and mechanical and aerospace engineering and the vice provost for Academic Planning and Policy, led the research.

Soil, embankment grants

﻿Anand Puppala, a UTA civil engineering soil researcher, is using U.S. Department of Transportation and the Texas Department of Transportation grants that will employ geopolymers for soil modification and sustainable cement materials to strengthen highway embankments in the Paris, Texas, district, Phys.org and Targeted News Service reported.

Tech university collaboration

A Dallas Morning News editorial urged the region to build an “Amazon U” even though the company decided against building its second headquarters in Dallas. The Amazon U was a joint project among UTA and other higher education institutions that would have provided the firm with a steady pipeline of skilled workers. Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban agreed in a DMN Sports Day story about Amazon.

Patent purifies ethylene

UTA researchers have filed a provisional patent application on a new copper compound that can be used to purify ethylene for use as a raw material in the production of plastics, as well as other industrial compounds, SpaceDaily reported. Rasika Dias, UTA distinguished professor of chemistry and biochemistry, is leading the research.

Engineering jobs

KXTX Telemundo 39 interviewed Adrian Rodriguez, a UTA assistant professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering, and students Elida Sorto-Ramos and Lauren Sorto-Ramos about high-paying jobs for Latinos.

Implantable probe

Weidong Zhou, a distinguished professor at UTA in electrical engineering, received a $200,000 Partnerships for Innovation grant from the National Science Foundation to develop an implantable optical probe that can be inserted in the brain to monitor brain function after traumatic injuries or surgeries, then be absorbed by the body, Electronics Newsweekly reported. Zhou is working with John Rogers, a world leader in the field of bioresorbable or biodegradable electronics at Northwestern University.

Veterans Day parade

Hundreds attended the Mansfield Veterans Day Parade and Salute earlier this week, the Star-Telegram reported. The UTA ROTC unit marched in the parade.

UTA architecture students' project

UTA architecture students created hotel models for downtown El Dorado, Ark., the El Dorado News-Times reported. The models are in an exhibit that will be displayed at the Price Gallery until Dec. 2.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, November 12, 2018
shortDescription: New immune response pathwayUTA researchers have found a possible new pathway to regulate immune response and potentially control inflammatory diseases
body:
New immune response pathway

UTA researchers have found a possible new pathway to regulate immune response and potentially control inflammatory diseases of the central nervous system, such as meningitis and sepsis, Science Daily, Technology Networks, China’s Antpedia.com, Medicine newsline and several other websites reported. Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry, led the research.

Python adaptation

A UTA study has found that Florida’s Burmese pythons have rapidly adapted to become hardier and more resistant to cold than their Asian cousins, the Miami Herald reported. The story also ran in the Bristol, Conn., Herald Courier, the San Francisco Chronicle and U.S. News & World Report.

NSF partners grant

Weidong Zhou, a Distinguished Professor at UTA in electrical engineering, received a $200,000 Partnerships for Innovation grant from the National Science Foundation to apply fundamental research derived from his work with John Rogers, a world leader in the field of bioresorbable or biodegradable electronics at Northwestern University, Medicalnewser.com reported.

President's Medal

The University of Texas Arlington honored Texas Gov. Greg Abbott with the President's Medal at its 54th annual Distinguished Alumni Awards on Friday, Nov. 9, U.S. Fed News reported. Abbott studied finance at UTA from 1976 to 1978.

Election impact on international scene

Brent Sasley, UTA associate professor of political science, evaluated what midterm election results mean for international relations with a panel of experts in a podcast hosted by The Scholars’ Circle.

Midterm changes

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, told WBAP 820 AM listeners that he expects the political voice to change in Washington D.C. following the midterm elections. He said he believes Nancy Pelosi, who could be the next Speaker of the House, realizes that too many investigations or impeachment talk could turn people off and impact the Democrats’ chances in 2020.

National award

Arlington Water Utilities was recognized in the national Route Fifty 2018 Navigator Awards' Tech Innovators category, Arlington-TX.gov reported. The department, with UTA faculty and students, use a robot to gather information about the city's sewer system.

Furniture help

Fräsch, a Grand Prairie furniture company, is helping UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs revamp its furniture class and classrooms, Dallas Innovates reported.

Gourley Foundation luncheon

Fifteen UTA students were honored during the annual Mary I. Gourley Foundation Scholarship Luncheon on Wednesday, U.S. Fed News reported. UTA's 2018-19 scholarship recipients are Dustin Ash, Nakesha Blackman, Hilda Carmona, Liliana Castillo, Juan "Frank" Chavez, Elizabeth Coello, Chelsea Coulter, Alexandria Dean, Carmen Flores, Christopher “Dillan” Lawson, Justin Lewis, Rachael Moffitt, Shelly Naugle, Lyn Nguyet Nguyen and Julie Rodriguez.

Safety never finished

Karen Puckett, director of the UTA Center for Environmental Excellence Division of Enterprise Development, said safety programs shouldn’t end when employees walk out the door and get into a vehicle to drive, Mondaq.com and the Seyfarth Shaw blog reported following a presentation that Puckett made at the 2018 National Safety Council Congress last month.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, October 19, 2018
shortDescription: PhD pipelineA UTA computer science professor has received a $1.2 million grant from the U.S. Department of Education, supplemented with $300,000 in UT
body:
PhD pipeline

A UTA computer science professor has received a $1.2 million grant from the U.S. Department of Education, supplemented with $300,000 in UTA matching funds, that will significantly increase the number of doctoral students, especially among women and minorities, the City of Arlington and Techsite reported. Ishfaq Ahmad, UTA professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, will lead the project.

Patents awarded

UTA has been awarded U.S. and international patents on a nanoparticle material that can be activated by light, microwave, X-ray or ultrasound to kill multiple kinds of cancers, DOTmed and Radiology Business reported. “This new nanoparticle material has many properties that improve upon traditional photodynamic cancer therapies, where light is used to activate a particle that kills cancer cells,” said Wei Chen, UTA physics professor and inventor.

Helping students

UTA tailors its faculty training to the needs of first-generation and Hispanic students, who represent 42 percent and 24 percent of its student population, respectively, EAB reported. This year, part-time faculty members and teaching assistants also will receive the training, said Carla Amaro-Jiménez, an associate professor who works on the project. The original story ran in The Hechinger Report.

New senior VP

Elisabeth Cawthon, dean of UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, and Lynn Peterson, senior associate dean for academic affairs in the College of Engineering, were both quoted in The Daily Tar supporting Kimberly van Noort’s appointment as senior vice president for academic affairs and chief academic officer for the University of North Carolina System. Van Noort was previously an assistant professor, associate dean for academic affairs in the College of Liberal Arts and associate vice provost for undergraduate studies at UTA.

Voter registration

Jennifer Hernandez, a UTA student in the College of Business and president of the UTA chapter of Jolt, a Texas organization that promotes civic engagement and voting in the Hispanic community, was featured in a Time article about how the anti-Trump movement is organizing its outrage. Hernandez has relatives who are undocumented. She’s made voter registration her main extracurricular activity.

Art show review

Mark Lamster, architecture critic of The Dallas Morning News and professor in practice at UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, reviewed the Dallas Museum of Art Show, “Cult of the Machine: Precisionism and American Art” for The Dallas Morning News. The show covers the interwar years of the 1920s and 1930s, when America transformed itself into a modern industrial giant.

UTA in top 5

UTA is one of the top five U.S. institutions that enrolled the most Nigerian students, Africa Independent Television reported.

Most Valuable Professional

Lynn Osborn, board member for UTA's Center for Underground Infrastructure Research and Education, will be awarded the 2019 Most Valuable Professional at a banquet on Jan. 29 during the Underground Construction Technology International Conference & Exhibition in Fort Worth, Underground Construction reported.

Alumnus joins Ryan

UTA alumnus Maher Maso has joined Ryan, a leading global tax services and software provider, PR Newswire reported. Prior to joining Ryan, Maso served as mayor of Frisco, Texas. Maso earned a bachelor’s degree in business management and an MBA from UTA.

Award winner

UTA alumnus Eric Hess — whose work explores the touchstones of life — won third place in the Stanislav Libenský Award competition recently for "Fragile," a glass-sculpted fetus encased in a 1-foot square ice cube, The Shreveport Times reported. The international competition held in the Czech Republic recognizes outstanding works by emerging glass artists. Hess — the only U.S. artist among the 30 finalists — completed his master’s degree in fine arts at UTA in May.

New managing director

UTA alumna Heather Reynolds, a nonprofit leader with extensive expertise in poverty alleviation, will join the Wilson Sheehan Lab for Economic Opportunities at the University of Notre Dame as its inaugural managing director in January, Targeted News Service reported. Reynolds holds a master's degree in social work from UTA.

Alumna named division president

UTA alumna Laurie Leenhouts has been named Texas division president of the North American Title Co., overseeing the company’s operations throughout the state, News Central Asia reported. She earned her bachelor’s degree in criminology and criminal justice and her master’s degree in public administration from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, January 2, 2019
shortDescription: City, UTA outlookArlington and UTA hold much promise in 2019, Richard Greene wrote in an opinion piece in the Star-Telegram. In the column, Greene sai
body:
City, UTA outlook

Arlington and UTA hold much promise in 2019, Richard Greene wrote in an opinion piece in the Star-Telegram. In the column, Greene said that UTA now has the largest enrollment in the UT System. Greene is a UTA professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs. He also is a former Arlington mayor.

Better forecasting

UTA researcher Yu Zhang, an assistant professor in the Civil Engineering Department, has earned a $515,565 grant from the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration that could lead to more accurate predictions and warnings for snow melt/runoff, flow and similar events, Science and Technology Research News reported.

SEIR economic development

The Fort Worth Business Press said UTA’s opening of the Science & Engineering Innovation & Research building will herald even more economic development for Arlington in a recap of economic trends.

NAI Fellows

UTA Provost Teik C. Lim and L.K. Mestha, affiliated adjunct professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering, were named fellows of the National Academy of Inventors, Biotech Week and MarketScreener.com reported. Lim also is a professor of mechanical engineering. Mestha was featured for the honor in India West.

New snake species

A UTA team has named a new species of snake that was discovered in the stomach of another snake. The tropical reptile Cenaspis aenigma—Latin for "enigmatic dinner snake"—was profiled in Smithsonian Magazine, National Geographic Italy and IFLScience.com. The article originally appeared in National Geographic. Jonathan Campbell, herpetologist and biology professor, led the research team.

Sprawl affect

A UTA study on how urban sprawl lowers the life expectancy of suburbanites by three years was featured on WTIC 1080 AM in Hartford, Conn. Shima Hamidi, UTA assistant professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, led the study.

Biography reviewed

Mark Lamster’s biography of Philip Johnson, “The Man in the Glass House,” was reviewed in the Houston Chronicle. Lamster is a UTA associate professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs and the architecture critic at The Dallas Morning News.

2018 films, TV review

Bart Weiss, UTA associate professor of film, reviewed the year in film and television, TheaterJones.com reported. Weiss also is co-founder of VideoFest and the Video Association of Dallas.

Woman of the Year

LuLu Cowan was profiled in the Amarillo Globe-News for winning the Woman of the Year award from Amarillo. Cowan earned her master’s degree in social work at UTA.

Political impacts

Rebecca Deen, UTA associate professor and chair of the Department of Political Science, said Beto O’Rourke’s recent loss to U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz could have future political impacts, Austin’s  KUT 90.5 FM reported. She also talked about the implications of the recent midterm elections for 2019, the federal government shutdown, the immigration debate and the census' new citizenship question. The Texas Standard website also aired the broadcast.

Debates continue

UTA’s Allan Saxe, associate professor of political science, said he expects Congress and President Trump to continue to debate the funding for a southern border wall, WLW 700 AM in Cincinnati, Ohio, reported. Saxe said he anticipates debates to continue on a number of subjects, especially in light of new committee chairs in the U.S. House. Saxe also talked about the government shutdown on WBAP 820 AM.

Promises kept

Todd Gabel, a UTA clinical associate professor of economics, wrote an opinion piece for the Daily Caller about President Trump’s gifts to the American public and promises the president has kept.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, January 14, 2019
shortDescription: UAV projectUTARI, or The University of Texas at Arlington Research Institute, has signed an agreement with Newcastle Manufacturing to configure and de
body:
UAV project

UTARI, or The University of Texas at Arlington Research Institute, has signed an agreement with Newcastle Manufacturing to configure and demonstrate a network of unmanned aerial vehicles, or UAVs, that can use lights to support emergency response operations at night, Targeted News Service reported.

Better forecasting

DJ Seo, a UTA civil engineering professor received a National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration grant to devise a way to take forecasts and metrics from many sources and merge them into a single, integrated forecast that will be more easily understood and useful during major weather events, Dallas Innovates reported.

Student research award

John Romig, UTA assistant professor of special education, was recognized by the Council for Exceptional Children's Division for Research with a 2019 Student Research Award, Targeted News Service reported.

MLK events

Lisa Thompson, senior director of the Trio pre-college program at UTA, talked on KXAS NBC 5 about upcoming city of Arlington/University of Texas at Arlington MLK Day events. She said the MLK Day of Service has been renamed for Zeb Strong Jr., a former UTA employee and activist, who died recently.

New corporate controller

American Airlines announced that Angie Owens will succeed Mike Carreon as vice president and corporate controller, effective March 1, the American Journal of Transportation, Market Screener and Aero Latin News reported. Owens received her master’s degree in business administration from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 14, 2018
shortDescription: Purifying ethyleneUTA researchers have filed a provisional patent application on a new copper compound that can be used to purify ethylene for use as
body:
Purifying ethylene

UTA researchers have filed a provisional patent application on a new copper compound that can be used to purify ethylene for use as a raw material in the production of plastics and other industrial compounds, Singapore’s Naaju and Health Medicine Network reported. Rasika Dias, UTA distinguished professor of chemistry and biochemistry, is leading the research.

Company investigated

Sriram Villapuram, UTA associate professor in the Department of Finance and Real Estate, said it was odd that a homebuilding firm would reach across the Pacific Ocean to find investors, KTVT CBS 11 reported in a piece about Serene Country Homes. The company has been accused of building shoddy homes and leaving housing editions unfinished. The article also appeared on the station’s website.

Nonprofit helps out

Mission Continues, a nonprofit veterans organization, visited the UTA Veterans Assistance Center to use a $9,000 Home Depot grant to replace flooring, paint walls and install new cabinets in the building, KTVT CBS 11 reported.

Latino jobs

KXTX Telemundo 39 interviewed Adrian Rodriguez, a UTA assistant professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering, and students Elida Sorto-Ramos and Lauren Sorto-Ramos about high-paying jobs for Latinos.

Veterans programs

UTA student Frank Chavez told KXTX Telemundo 39 about the programs available to military veterans at the University for a Veterans Day story.

Optical probe

Weidong Zhou, a distinguished professor at UTA in electrical engineering, received a $200,000 Partnerships for Innovation grant from the National Science Foundation to develop an implantable optical probe that can be inserted in the brain to monitor brain function after traumatic injuries or surgeries, then be absorbed by the body, Science and Technology Research News reported. Zhou is working with John Rogers, a world leader in the field of bioresorbable or biodegradable electronics at Northwestern University.

New pathway

UTA researchers have found a new pathway to regulate immune response and potentially control inflammatory diseases of the central nervous system, such as meningitis and sepsis, China’s Clove Garden and ReachMD reported. Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry, led the research.

Adaptive pythons

A UTA study has found that Florida’s Burmese pythons have rapidly adapted to become hardier and more resistant to cold than their Asian cousins, the Panama City, Fla., News Herald reported.

Amazon disappointment

Dallas Mayor Mike Rawlings said he was disappointed in the city being unable to land Amazon's second headquarters, KTVT CBS 11 and The Dallas Morning News reported. Rawlings said the region had set up a multi-university partnership, which included UTA, to provide a high-tech workforce for the company.

Homecoming 2018

UTA students kicked off Homecoming Week at a "Paint Your Ride" spirit event, where their cars were decorated with cheers such as “Honk for Homecoming,” “Go UTA!” and “Maverick Pride,” High Beam reported.

New certification

UTA is the first Texas university to offer students the opportunity to earn a master’s degree in economics and a National Association for Business Economics Certified Business Economist®, or CBE, professional certification simultaneously, U.S. Fed News and Arlington-tx.gov reported.

President named to board

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari was named a board member at large for the Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities' 2019 board of directors, Targeted News Service reported.

Veterans, police views

The Undefeated reported about how black military veterans and police officers view the national anthem protests in the NFL. W. Marvin Dulaney, a UTA emeritus associate professor of history, said it makes sense that some black police officers feel a kinship with players who have vehemently criticized the police.

Alumnus named VP

Mark Schwartz, a 25-year veteran of cardiovascular device development, has joined BioCardia as vice president of clinical affairs, Cardiovascular News reported. Schwartz holds a master’s degree in biomedical engineering from UTA.

Alumnus named CIO

Chris Andrews has been named chief information officer for Pei Wei Asian Kitchen, Restaurant News reported. Andrews received a master’s degree in professional accounting from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, January 9, 2019
shortDescription: New forecasting modelDJ Seo, a UTA civil engineering professor, received a National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration grant to devise a way
body:
New forecasting model

DJ Seo, a UTA civil engineering professor, received a National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration grant to devise a way to take forecasts and metrics from multiple sources and merge them into a single, integrated forecast that will be more easily understood and useful during major weather events, Techsite reported.

Gas leak research

Kathleen Smits, a UTA civil engineering associate professor, received a $414,000 grant from the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration to develop a method to predict the conditions under which gas leaks may occur and establish best practices to improve response to gas migration incidents and to find and fix leaks, Science and Technology News reported. 

Natural state

Kevin Sloan, UTA assistant professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, was featured in a Texas Climate News’ story about how to build ecological resilience and “rewilding” in development. Rewilding is restoring a piece of land to its natural state.

New snake species

A UTA team has named a new species of snake discovered in the stomach of another snake. The tropical reptile Cenaspis aenigma—Latin for “enigmatic dinner snake”—was profiled in China’s ECNS.cn. The article originally appeared in National Geographic. Jonathan Campbell, herpetologist and biology professor, led the research team. Ecns.cn is the official English-language website of China News Service.

Winter blues

James Campbell Quick, UTA professor emeritus in management, said the winter blues are real in an NBCNews.com article. Quick uses a unique approach to combat them by filling up his calendar with what he calls "Ds," which stands for drain, and "Fs," which stands for fill me up. “The Ds are the people and events that tend to drain my energy, and the Fs are the people and events that bring me joy and excitement and fill me up,” he explained. “You want plenty of Fs on your calendar and not too many Ds.”

Israeli election

Brent Sasley, UTA associate professor of political science, wrote an op-ed column for The Washington Post that previewed an upcoming Israeli election on April 9. The article also reviewed Israel’s political and election system.

Through slaves' eyes

Marvin Dulaney, UTA professor emeritus of history, has been a longtime volunteer at the Dallas African American Museum in Fair Park, KDFW Fox 4 and Black News and Information reported. Dulaney is currently showing visitors an exhibit about Thomas Jefferson, titled “Slavery at Jefferson’s Monticello: Paradox of Liberty,” which looks at Jefferson through the eyes of his slaves. The story was part of Fox 4’s Hometown Heroes series.

Border wall

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, previewed President Trump’s national address last night about the border wall on WBAP 820 AM. Saxe said Trump will try to show the imperative need for a wall along the nation’s southern border. He said if he fails, it could have a significant impact on the 2020 election.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, October 5, 2018
shortDescription: Dean appointedElizabeth Merwin, PhD, RN, FAAN, has been appointed dean of the College of Nursing and Health Innovation at The University of Texas at A
body:
Dean appointed

Elizabeth Merwin, PhD, RN, FAAN, has been appointed dean of the College of Nursing and Health Innovation at The University of Texas at Arlington, Markets Insider, Waco’s KXXV ABC 25, Bezinga.com and U.S. Fed News reported. Merwin is currently serving as the Duke University School of Nursing's executive vice dean, the Ann Henshaw Gardiner Professor of Nursing, and professor of psychiatry and behavioral sciences at Duke University's School of Medicine. 

Smart seat

Researchers at The University of Texas at Arlington have patented a smart seat cushion that uses changes in air pressure to redistribute body weight to help prevent pressure ulcers, MedicalBrief reported. Muthu Wijesundara, co-inventor of the technology, is chief research scientist at UTA's Research Institute.

UTA-Navy partnership

UTA and the Naval Surface Warfare Center Philadelphia Division signed a formal Education Partnership Agreement recently that will enhance research and education at UTA through interactions with division personnel and sharing scientific, engineering and technological assets, Targeted News Service reported.

Komodo-UTA agreement

Komodo Platform, the blockchain service ecosystem, announced a collaboration with The University of Texas at Arlington, CapRE Media and BitcoinExchangeGuide.com reported. Komodo will provide funding for two senior design projects, as well as scholarships for two undergraduate students and two graduate students for one academic year.

Summit scheduled

BionorthTX invites guests to the fourth annual IC3 Life Science Summit Wednesday, Oct. 10, at UTA’s E.H. Hereford University Center, Dallas Innovates reported.

Gas prices

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said rising gas prices at the pump shouldn’t affect the midterm elections next month as long as the economy stays strong, KTRH 740 AM reported.

National ranking

OnlineMasters.com ranked UTA as the 33rd best university in the nation to attain an online master’s in public administration degree, Markets Insider and SFGate.com reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, November 19, 2018
shortDescription: Talent pool improvementsAmazon’s decision not to choose Dallas as its second headquarters is a call to action to develop the local talent pool, The Da
body:
Talent pool improvements

Amazon’s decision not to choose Dallas as its second headquarters is a call to action to develop the local talent pool, The Dallas Morning News reported. UTA ranks No. 72 and No. 90 for research expenditures in engineering and computer science.

Transportation, soil projects

Anand Puppala, civil engineering professor and the associate dean for research in UTA’s College of Engineering, is using U.S. Department of Transportation and the Texas Department of Transportation funding that will employ geopolymers for soil modification and sustainable cement materials to strengthen highway embankments in the Paris, Texas, district, Phys.org reported.

New method

Daniel Armstrong, UTA’s Robert A. Welch Distinguished Professor of Chemistry and Biochemistry, has developed a new method using gas chromatography to measure ethanol content in the popular drink Kombucha, Science Trends reported.

D.C. tone

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, told WBAP 820 AM that he expects that the tone in Washington will change now that the Democrats have control of the House of Representatives. He considers that Nancy Pelosi is thinking 2020, and that too many investigations or suggestions of impeachment of the president may work against them for that election. 

Health study

An article in Bustle on common habits linked to cancer in women cited a UTA 2014 study that found a link between Bisphenol A and breast cancer tumor growth. Bisphenol A is widely used in products such as plastic bottles, including water bottles.

Building to be demolished

The former Great National Life Insurance Co. offices on Harry Hines Boulevard at Mockingbird Lane was cited by UTA architecture professors Kate Holliday and Douglas Klahr as one on their list of "5 significant Dallas buildings to behold," The Dallas Morning News reported in a story about the building's demolition.

New VP

Fort Worth’s Botanical Research Institute of Texas named Christie Eckler as its new vice president of advancement, the Fort Worth Business Press reported. Eckler was development director for UTA’s College of Science previously.

Sales challenge

UTA is participating in the 12th Annual National Sales Challenge at William Paterson University’s Cotsakos College of Business Nov. 14-16, The Commerce and Industry Association of New Jersey reported.

Student debt

Justin Silcox, UTA associate director of financial aid, urges students who borrow to pay for their education “at the very least, pay the interest that is accruing on your loans,” WFAA.com reported. Americans have amassed $1.5 trillion in student loans, more than they owe for auto loans or credit cards.

New Arlington hotel

UTA student Josh Ramos was interviewed for a KTVT CBS 11 feature on the new hotel being built in Arlington targeting young millennials. He commented that “there are a lot more opportunities to do stuff here (in Arlington) rather than go to Dallas or Fort Worth.”

New medical plan

UTA and all UT System institutions in North Texas will now have access to a new medical plan through Southwestern Health Resources, the accountable care organization formed by UT Southwestern and Texas Health Resources, D Healthcare Daily reported.

Alumna hired

LPA has hired Teresa Rodriguez as managing director of the firm’s Dallas office, New York’s WICZ Fox 40, Bezinga and the Albany, N.Y., Times Union reported. Rodriguez holds a master’s degree in architecture from UTA. LPA is an integrated design firm.

Alumnus appointed to board

OnDeck has appointed Chandra Dhandapani to its board of directors, StreetInsider.com, GuruFocus and KHQ NBC 6 in Spokane, Wash., reported. Dhandapani received her MBA in information systems from UTA.

New CFO

PharmaCord has named Patrick Lee its new chief financial officer, Pharmacy Choice and Business Insurance reported. Lee earned his master’s degree in professional accounting from UTA.

Students visit UTA

The Oak Cliff Advocate reported in The Uninformed Parent podcast that students from Felix G. Botello Elementary visited many universities in the area, including UTA. A print story of the podcast was published in the paper.

UTA employee touts artist

Louisiana’s Baton Rouge Advocate profiled Hunter Roth and the work he has done with Baton Rouge artist Charles Barbier. Roth is the digital fabrication specialist in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 7, 2018
shortDescription: Fair housingA UTA fair housing assessment showed economic and racial segregation across Dallas, The Dallas Morning News and D Magazine reported. Myria
body:
Fair housing

A UTA fair housing assessment showed economic and racial segregation across Dallas, The Dallas Morning News and D Magazine reported. Myriam Igoufe, who recently earned her doctorate from UTA, and Stephen Mattingly, a UTA civil engineering professor, performed the assessment for the city of Dallas and 20-plus other cities and housing authorities. “Dallas is marked by a very stark geography of inequity,” Igoufe said. “We have also documented systemic barriers to opportunities.” Mattingly said if the study had gone back earlier than 1990, he believes data would have shown these areas of inequity for a long time.

Election analysis

Allan Saxe, UTA political science associate professor, believes the Democrats probably will take control of the U.S. House, causing even more gridlock in Congress, WBAP 820 AM reported. Saxe also said the Texas gubernatorial election could help U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz’s race against U.S. Rep. Beto O’Rourke because Gov. Abbott is such a strong candidate. Saxe also talked about the Tuesday election with KLIF 570 AM and Houston's KTRH 740 AM.

Record voter turnout

Tom Marshall, UTA political science professor, said a great deal of effort and money has gone into voter registration in this election and that is one reason for a record voter turnout on KDFW Fox 4. Marshall also touched on a number of other election races, issues and topics.

Endowed chair

Bob Woods, the longtime UTA mechanical engineering professor and Formula SAE adviser, is the first recipient of an endowed chair established in his honor in 2017 through a gift from Paul E. Andrews Jr., an entrepreneur and businessman, Bioengineer.org and Targeted News Service reported.

UAV uses

Water & Wastes Digest published an article about the use of unmanned aerial vehicles in managing and evaluating infrastructure. The article, originally published in Roads & Bridges, was authored by Anand Puppala, UTA Distinguished Teaching Professor of civil engineering, and Surya Congress, a graduate research assistant.

Paint your Ride

UTA students kicked off Homecoming Week on Monday at a “Paint Your Ride” spirit event where their cars were decorated with cheers such as “Honk for Homecoming,” Go UTA!” and “Maverick Pride” Arlington-Tx.gov reported.

Top 40 Under 40

Muhammad Farooq Wahab, a UTA research engineering scientist, was named to the Analytical Chemists 2018 Top 40 Under 40 Power List of young analytical scientists, published by the prestigious British magazine The Analytical Scientist in its October 2018 edition, Targeted News Service reported.

Architecture ranked

The UTA architecture program ranked No. 16 among architecture schools with 70 to 99 graduates most hired by firms in the last five years, Targeted News Service reported about a list that DesignIntelligence published.

Recycled road

A UTA civil engineering professor said future highways might be made of a recycled plastic slurry, SentinelSource.com of Keene, N.H., reported. Sahadat Hossain, the civil engineering professor and the director of UTA's Solid Waste Institute for Sustainability, has projects using recycled plastic to shore up failing highway slopes and highway walls. The original story ran in The Washington Post.

Alumna appointed

Debbie Messemer was appointed to Carbon’s board of directors, the Odessa American, Business Wire, KAVU ABC 25 in Victoria, Texas, and many other websites reported. Messemer earned her bachelor’s degree in accounting from UTA. Carbon is a hardware, software and molecular science company.

Startup Lounge hosts events

UTA’s Startup Lounge will host two events during the city of Fort Worth’s Global Entrepreneurship Week, Nov. 8-16, the Fort Worth Business Press and fortworthtexas.gov reported. There will be a Startup-Con for entrepreneurs from noon to 5 p.m. Tuesday, Nov. 13, at UTA’s Startup Lounge, 505 W. Nedderman Drive. The second event will be an intense look at EpICMavs, a weekly entrepreneurship workshop series, at 4:30 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 15, at the lounge.

New technologies

Oklahoma oil and gas regulators have ordered an indefinite shutdown of a disposal well after a 3.3 magnitude earthquake hit in the adjacent state, KTVT CBS 11 reported. The article said UTA professors and students are researching new technologies aimed at making the use of water during fracking procedures more eco-friendly.

Scholarships offered

Ten U.S. and Canadian scholarships for doctoral dissertation held jointly with a Greece research center are being offered in the fields of artificial intelligence, robotics, mechanical learning, big data and bioinformatics, the Interconnection Office of the Democritus University of Thrace reported. UTA’s Department of Computer Science and Engineering is one of the participants.

College Night

UTA is one of the colleges and universities that will be represented at Victoria College’s College Night Nov. 13, the Victoria Advocate reported.

Alumna joins lab

Heather Reynolds, a nonprofit leader with extensive expertise in poverty alleviation, will join the Wilson Sheehan Lab for Economic Opportunities at the University of Notre Dame as its inaugural managing director in January, BuildingIndiana.com reported. Reynolds holds a UTA master’s degree in social work.

New airport director

Joseph Medici has been named director of airport services for the city of Temple, the Temple Daily Telegram and centexproud.com reported. Medici earned his bachelor’s degree in communication from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, January 11, 2019
shortDescription: MLK activitiesThe city of Arlington, UTA, the Arlington ISD and several others sponsor annual MLK activities, U.S. Fed News reported. The MLK Day of S
body:
MLK activities

The city of Arlington, UTA, the Arlington ISD and several others sponsor annual MLK activities, U.S. Fed News reported. The MLK Day of Service on Jan. 21 has been renamed for the late Zeb Strong Jr., a longtime UTA employee and community leader.

Project to help emergency response

The UTA Research Institute has signed an agreement with Newcastle Manufacturing to configure and demonstrate a network of unmanned aerial vehicles that can use lights to support emergency response operations at night, TechSite reported.

New CAPPA course

A new interdisciplinary course in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs will explore recent technological innovations in mobility during spring 2019, Market Screener reported. CAPPA is teaming with AECOM, a multinational engineering firm, to teach the course.

Better forecasting

DJ Seo, a UTA civil engineering professor, received a National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration grant to devise a way to take forecasts and metrics from multiple sources and merge them into a single, integrated forecast that will be more easily understood and useful during major weather events, Phys.org, Scienmag and Targeted News Service reported.

Species boundaries

Kyle O’Connell, a UTA graduate, wrote about species delimitation or boundaries in North American coachwhips and whipsnakes for Science Trends. The article was based on work O’Connell and Eric Smith, a UTA associate professor of biology, published in the journal Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution.

Book review

Texas Architect reviewed Mark Lamster’s book, The Man in the Glass House: Philip Johnson, Architect of the Modern Century. Lamster is a UTA professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs and the architecture critic for The Dallas Morning News.

Chief sustainability officer

Meghna Tare has been named UTA’s first chief sustainability officer, Green Source DFW reported.

Tuition guarantee

UTA was one of several colleges listed by Edmit that offer a tuition guarantee.

Speech impact
