Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, told KLIF 570 AM that he doubts President Trump’s national speech to the American people will have any impact on the government shutdown.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, December 5, 2018
shortDescription: Opioid discussionThe Texas Tribune, in partnership with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas, is hosting a discussion on the opioid crisis and the stat
body:
Opioid discussion

The Texas Tribune, in partnership with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas, is hosting a discussion on the opioid crisis and the state's public policy solutions in the works to address them at 11:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. today at UTA’s SEIR Building, 655 W. Mitchell St., Hoodline.com reported. The free event will feature state representatives Garnet Coleman and J.D. Sheffield, and Stephanie Jones, assistant professor of anesthesiology and pain management at UT Southwestern Medical Center. 

Proper balance

Troy Johnson, UTA’s vice president for enrollment management, was quoted in Inside Higher Ed about how universities are striving to find the proper balance between online and on-campus enrollment.

Bush accolades

Brent Sasley UTA associate professor of political science, said that President George H.W. Bush would be remembered for handling the crumbling Soviet Union well, KRLD 1080 AM reported. Bush died recently and is being remembered this week.

KInder, gentler

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said President George H.W. Bush promoted kinder, gentler policies and he was that kind of individual on Miami’s WIOD 610 AM. Saxe said Bush came from a political family legacy that stood up to the Kennedys and Roosevelts. Saxe also told WBAP 820 AM listeners that Bush lost the 1992 election because of H. Ross Perot, an independent candidate at the time, siphoned off votes from Bush. The former president died recently and is being remembered this week.

New mobility officer

Chad Edwards is the city of Fort Worth’s new mobility and innovation officer, FortWorthTexas.gov reported. Edwards received a master’s degree in planning from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, October 26, 2018
shortDescription: NIH grantTwo UTA social work professors are using an NIH grant to find ways to reduce stress of families caring for loved ones with Alzheimer’s diseas
body:
NIH grant

Two UTA social work professors are using an NIH grant to find ways to reduce stress of families caring for loved ones with Alzheimer’s disease, Dallas Innovates reported. Noelle Fields and Ling Xu, both assistant professors in The University of Texas at Arlington’s School of Social Work, were awarded a $459,994 National Institutes of Health grant for their research titled “The Senior Companion Program Plus (SCP Plus): A Psychoeducational Intervention for African American Dementia Caregivers.”

Football talk

SportsDay reports that UTA leadership is considering bringing back its football program. The university football team was disbanded after the 1985 season.

Crime victims grant

The University of Texas at Arlington has received a $500,000 grant from the Office of the Governor that fund two projects that aid crime victims and the services that help them, Targeted News Service reported.

Rapid adaptation

UTA researchers have found genomic evidence of rapid adaptation of invasive Burmese pythons to their new environment in Florida, Science and Technology Research News reported. Todd Castoe, UTA biology professor and director of the Castoe Lab, led the research.

Climate change

A UTA study was cited in a Daily Texan op-ed column about climate change. The mention stemmed from a story that The Dallas Morning News originally published. Arne Winguth, chair of UTA’s Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, was quoted in the DMN article about climate change in North Texas.

Special collections

The Discovery Channel show Expedition Unknown: Hunt for Extraterrestrials visited UTA Libraries Special Collection to inspect what’s known as the Ramey photo collection, which chronicles the Roswell UFO incident of 1947. Brenda McClurkin, department head of special collections, is in the video at about the 2:38:50 mark.

2002 paper

Thomas Hall, UTA accounting professor, is fighting to republish a 2002 paper he co-wrote after a co-author was found guilty of scientific misconduct, Sciencemag reported. Despite later research supporting the validity of the paper, Hall is just one example of how co-authors are impacted by their counterparts' misdeeds.

Power list

Muhammad Farooq Wahab, a UTA research engineering scientist in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, is on the 2018 Power List of analytical scientists, News International reported. This 2018 Power List has been published by The Analytical Scientist in its October 2018 edition.

UTA graduates

Incumbent Rodney Anderson, R-Grand Prairie, is facing Democratic challenger Terry Meza in the District 105 race for the Nov. 6 election, The Dallas Morning News reported. Both Anderson and Meza earned degrees from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, December 7, 2018
shortDescription: UTeach grantThe UTeach Arlington secondary math and science teacher preparation program at The University of Texas at Arlington has been selected for
body:
UTeach grant

The UTeach Arlington secondary math and science teacher preparation program at The University of Texas at Arlington has been selected for a grant by the Arlington Tomorrow Foundation. The grant benefits UTeach students and youth served by the Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Tarrant County, Medicine newsline and Targeted News Service reported.

Telemundo University

In an effort to help shape the next generation of bilingual broadcast and digital journalists and provide them the skills they need to succeed, the Telemundo Station Group has launched the Telemundo University training program for journalism students at UTA and the University of Florida, HispanicAd.com, B+C, International Broadcast News, TVNewsCheck, the Orlando Sentinel and Florida Trend reported.

Adult mental health

Philip Baiden, UTA assistant professor in the School of Social Work, was interviewed by Austin’s KUT 90.5 FM’s Texas Standard radio newsmagazine about adult mental health. “There’s a general perception that it is OK to seek services for general health functioning,” Baiden said. “But when it comes to mental health, there’s a huge stigma that they’re supposed to be resilient and deal with it.” He says if people would talk about mental health and support their older adult friends and family, it would help eliminate the stigma. The article also appeared on the KERA 91.7 FM website.

Opioid panel discussion

Marissa Evans, the Texas Tribune health and human services reporter, conducted a panel discussion on the opioid epidemic and what Texas is doing about it at UTA’s Science, Engineering & Innovation, Research Building on Wednesday, the Texas Tribune reported. State Rep. Garnet Coleman, D-Houston, state Rep. J.D. Sheffield, R-Gatesville, and Dr. Stephanie Jones, an assistant professor of anesthesiology and pain management at UT Southwestern Medical Center, were on the panel. KDFW Fox 4 interviewed Evans about the discussion earlier in the day.

Bendable concrete

Trans-SET, a collaborative partnership between nine major institutions and two community colleges, led by LSU, is close to perfecting engineered cementitious composites, or bendable concrete, on a marketable scale, Civil + Structural Engineer, Aggregate Research, Construction Equipment Guide, Phys.org and many other media outlets reported. UTA is a part of Trans-SET.

Bush triumphs

Thomas Marshall, UTA professor of political science, said even though George H.W. Bush only served one term, he accomplished many monumental things, like seeing the peaceful fall of communism in Russia. KDFW Fox 4 interviewed Marshall during the Houston funeral services for Bush.

Bush family legacy

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, equated the Bush family legacy to that of the Roosevelts, Kennedys and Adamses on KLIF 570 AM. Funeral services for George H. W. Bush, the 41st president of the United States, were held all week.

First look at park

Dallas residents got a “first look” of the Trinity River park Thursday, The Dallas Morning News reported in a Mark Lamster column. Brent Brown, a former UTA adjunct architecture professor, is the chief executive and president of the Trinity Park Conservancy, the nonprofit authority commissioned last May by the city to build the park. Lamster is the architecture critic for The Dallas Morning News and an associate professor in practice in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

Alumnus appointed

Gov. Greg Abbott has appointed Ademola “Peter” Adejokun of Arlington to the Texas Board of Professional Engineers, Houston Style Magazine reported. Adejokun sits on UTA’s Department of Computer Science and Engineering industry advisory board. He also received bachelor’s degrees in computer science and engineering, and physics from UTA.

Electrical engineering partnership

UTA’s Electrical Engineering Department is partnering with Liaison International’s EngineeringCAS™, University Business and several other media outlets reported. The system is aimed at streamlining the graduate engineering admissions process.

New president, CEO

The BionorthTX Board of Directors has appointed Jorge Varela—a Dallas entrepreneur, executive and angel investor—as the organization’s new president and chief executive officer, Dallas Innovates reported. The article mentioned that the BionorthTX fourth annual Life Science Summit recently was held at UTA.

Alumna named nurse practitioner

DJ Gross has been hired as nurse practitioner at Ozarks Medical Center in Winona, Mo., the Ozark Radio News reported. Gross earned her bachelor’s degree in nursing from UTA.

New mobility officer

Chad Edwards is the city of Fort Worth’s new mobility and innovation officer, the Fort Worth Business Press reported. Edwards received a master’s degree in planning from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, October 15, 2018
shortDescription: National committeeUTA physics professor Yue Deng has been named to the National Academy of Sciences Committee on Solar and Space Physics, Targeted New
body:
National committee

UTA physics professor Yue Deng has been named to the National Academy of Sciences Committee on Solar and Space Physics, Targeted News Service reported. The committee focuses on national issues important to the solar and space physics community.

Strengthening highways

Sahadat Hossain, UTA civil engineering professor, and his team are using a $1.37 million proof-of-concept contract with the Texas Department of Transportation to show that recycled plastic pins can strengthen mechanically stabilized earth walls on highways in North Texas, Dallas Innovates reported. 

Forum participation

George Siemen’s, executive director of UTA’s Learning Innovation and Networked Knowledge, or LINK, lab, participated in a forum celebrating the fifth anniversary of XuetangX, the Massive Open Online Courses platform launched by China's prestigious Tsinghua University, China.org.cn reported.

SEIR hosts conference

UTA hosted its first large conference at the new state-of-the-art Science & Engineering Innovation & Research building on the south side of campus, Targeted News Service reported. This year's event focused on freshwater and wastewater management concerning responsible shale energy extraction.

Minimum wage impact

Todd Gabel, a UTA clinical assistant professor of economics and senior fellow with the Fraser Institute, said minimum-wage hikes like the one passed recently in Michigan harms workers instead of helping them, The Heartland Institute reported. Gabel is also a policy advisor for The Heartland Institute, which publishes Budget & Tax News.

Downtown resurgence

Downtown Arlington, which is sandwiched between a booming UTA and an expanding entertainment district that recently opened Texas Live! and at which the Texas Rangers are busily constructing a new indoor ballpark, is undergoing a resurgence, the Fort Worth Business Press reported.

Track athlete honored

UTA student Alexus Henry was honored at her alma mater’s football game last Friday, KOGT 1600 AM in Orange, Texas, reported. Henry, a two-time state champion in the high jump at Bridge City High School, recently won gold in the NCAA Championships in the high jump. She’s the first female athlete at UTA to win a national title.

PhD student featured

UTA doctoral student Imelda Trejo was featured in a Forbes article about Hispanic and Latinx mathematicians featured on the Lathisms website, which celebrates Hispanic and Latinx mathematicians. Trejo’s dissertation research focuses on the interactions between immune and bone cells that occur as fractures heal. 

Teacher of the week

UTA alumna Brandi Stearman was the featured teacher of the week, the Corsicana Daily Sun reported. She earned her bachelor’s degree in political science degree from UTA.

Reporter awarded

UTA student Kyle Cotton received an award from the Dallas Bar Association for his Shorthorn article, “Firefighters file civil service lawsuit against the city,” Focus Daily News reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, December 21, 2018
shortDescription: The city of Rhome agreed to a memorandum of understanding to hire UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning, and Public Affairs to prepare a master plan
body:
The city of Rhome agreed to a memorandum of understanding to hire UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning, and Public Affairs to prepare a master plan for the city, the Wise County Messenger reported. The article quoted Alan Klein, assistant director for the Institute of Urban Studies, about graduate students creating a community-based plan.

UTA researcher Yu Zhang, an assistant professor in the Civil Engineering Department, has earned a $515,565 grant from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, according to newsedge.com. The grant will be used to apply inputs from the joint polar satellite system to create a paradigm that could be applied to the National Water Model and allow both services to be considered in predictions and warnings for snow melt, runoff, flooding, and similar events.

Research on finding comets by UTA astrobiologist Manfred Cuntz and colleagues was featured in Forbes magazine. The team showed how exocomets in 47 UMa, a sunlike star, interacted with the system's three Jupiter-like planets.

A UTA team has named a new species of snake discovered in the stomach of another snake. The tropical reptile Cenaspis aenigma—Latin for "enigmatic dinner snake"—was profiled in National Geographic and reported in BoingBoing. Jonathan Campbell, herpetologist and biology professor, led the research team.

Diane Jones Allen, director of landscape architecture in the College of Architecture, Planning, and Public Affairs, and her views on increasing diversity in landscapes were named a top 10 story for February 2018 by Total Landscape Care.

Peace Ossom Williamson, director of Research Data Services for UTA Libraries, was quoted in an article about the Agency for Healthcare Quality and Research's shutdown of its National Guideline Clearinghouse, Sunlight Foundation reported. Williamson noted the replacement database was good, but not as robust as its predecessor.

A government shutdown will not be as bad as some people expect, says Alan Saxe, associate professor of political science. Saxe told KLIF-AM and WBAP-AM radio that federal employees will not be paid during the shutdown, but will be when the government is working again.

Alumnus Trey Hillman was profiled in The Ringer article, "The World’s Most Successful Manager Will Coach First Base for the Marlins." The former Maverick infielder returns to Major League Baseball after two years of winning titles in South Korea.

Stanton Independent School District has hired alumnus Cody Hogan as the full-time athletic director/football coach, the Midland Reporter-Telegram and KOSA-CBS7 reported. He graduated this month with a master’s degree in educational leadership and policy studies from UTA's College of Education.

Joe Gumm is a new anchor at KXXV-25 in Waco, the station reported. He earned a bachelor's degree in broadcast communication at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, November 26, 2018
shortDescription: NSF grantRobert Magnusson, UTA’s Texas Instruments Distinguished University Chair in Nanoelectronics and an electrical engineering professor, will use
body:
NSF grant

Robert Magnusson, UTA’s Texas Instruments Distinguished University Chair in Nanoelectronics and an electrical engineering professor, will use a $360,000 National Science Foundation grant for his research into band flips and bound states in leaky-mode resonant photonic lattices, Photonics.com reported.

New pathway

UTA researchers have found a new pathway to regulate immune response and potentially control inflammatory diseases of the central nervous system, such as meningitis and sepsis, Science and Technology Research News reported. Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry, led the research.

UTA study

A study by UTA researchers was cited in a Lancaster (Pa.) Online editorial about proposed changes to Title IX. The study found that 34 percent of students who had been sexually victimized dropped out of college.

Israeli elections

An editorial by UTA's Brent E. Sasley about the upcoming Israeli elections appeared in the Nov. 21 edition of The Washington Post. Sasley is an associate professor of political science.

General delivers address

Retired Gen. Benjamin Griffin spoke at Fort Hood’s 22nd Annual Consolidated Graduation ceremony Nov. 15, the Fort Hood Sentinel reported. Griffin is a special adviser to UTA President Vistasp Karbhari in matters related to veteran success.

Housing inequities

Myriam Igoufe, a UTA doctoral graduate in urban planning, discussed North Texas' lingering housing inequities on KERA News. She is the project manager of a comprehensive new study for the North Texas Regional Housing Assessment.

Alumni joins firm

Maher Maso joined Ryan, a Dallas-based global tax services and software provider, as a principal in the firms credits and incentives practice, newsedge.com reported. The former mayor of Frisco, Texas, Maso earned a Bachelor of Science in business management and a Master of Business Administration from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 21, 2018
shortDescription: Esports eventUTA has one of the top collegiate esports programs in the country and will have its own team room at the new 100,000-square-foot arena, t
body:
Esports event

UTA has one of the top collegiate esports programs in the country and will have its own team room at the new 100,000-square-foot arena, the Star-Telegram and KRLD 1080 AM reported in a preview of the Arlington Esports Stadium at the city’s Convention Center. The new stadium’s grand opening is Saturday, when it hosts the Esports Championship Series Season 6 Finals. Eight teams will be competing, playing Counter Strike, over two days for a $750,000 prize pool.

Test subject

When graduate students at The University of Texas at Arlington need help in their research, Bill McNeill is one of the most frequently participating test subjects, The Dallas Morning News reported in a story about how graduate students draft those test subjects.

Biotech industry

Frank Grassler, vice president for Technology Development at UT Southwestern Medical Center and Board Chairman for bionorthTX, said even though North Texas didn’t win the Amazon second headquarters sweepstakes, the biotech industry could become the region’s next big play, D CEO Healthcare reported in a column Grassler authored that mentioned UTA as one of the universities contributing to that optimism.

Student earns scholarship

Lorenzo Novoa, a UTA student, was one of the recipients of the Vertical Flight Foundation scholarships, PRWeb.com reported. Scholarships totaling $90,000 were awarded this year to 25 of the world's most talented engineering students interested in vertical flight. AHS International, The Vertical Flight Society, sponsors the scholarships.

Travel Channel

The Travel Channel show Expedition Unknown: Hunt for Extraterrestrials visited the UTA Libraries Special Collection to inspect what’s known as the Ramey photo collection, which chronicles the Roswell UFO incident of 1947. Brenda McClurkin, department head of UTA Special Collections, is in the video at about the 19:38 mark. The story originally aired on The Discovery Channel.

Distinguished alumni

The University of Texas at Arlington recently recognized Mike Dolabi, who studied at UTA and is now the president and owner of National Autobody Parts Warehouse, as a Distinguished Alumni at the 2018 Distinguished Alumni Awards, FenderBender reported.

Alumna recognized

Evelyn Torres, CEO of Solaris Technologies, was recognized in D CEO's Dallas 500 for the fourth year in a row. The Dallas 500 celebrates the most influential business leaders in North Texas. Torres is on the advisory board for UTA’s College of Engineering.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, October 22, 2018
shortDescription: Rapid adaptationUTA researchers have found genomic evidence of rapid adaptation of invasive Burmese pythons to their new environment in Florida, Scien
body:
Rapid adaptation

UTA researchers have found genomic evidence of rapid adaptation of invasive Burmese pythons to their new environment in Florida, Science Daily,  I4U News, (e) Science News, Science Codex, 24SunNews, Infosur News, Brexit News of Germany, Europa Press of Spain and Bioengineer.org of the United Kingdom reported. Todd Castoe, UTA biology professor and director of the Castoe Lab, led the research.

Genomics pact

Texas A&M University and UTA have established The Texas Genomics Core Alliance to increase access to and decrease costs of cutting-edge, high-throughput genomics sequencing technologies, Phys.org, Medicalnewser.com, Bioengineer.org, The Medical News and Targeted News Service reported. “By reducing costs and speeding up the process we can make genomics into a commodity and enhance innovation across the biotech, biomedical and industrial sectors,” said Jon Weidanz, UTA associate vice president for research and founding director of UTA’s North Texas Genome Center.

Helping moms, babies

Priscila Caçola, a UTA associate professor of kinesiology at the College of Nursing and Health Innovation, and Cheryl Anderson, a UTA associate professor emeritus of nursing, are working on a pilot intervention with 40 new mothers of premature infants that looks at ways to boost infant development, strengthen relationships between mom and infant, and reduce depression and post-traumatic stress disorder in the mother of pre-term babies, Dallas Innovates reported.

Arbuckle Award

UTA’s Disability Programs have been awarded the Martha Arbuckle Award, one of the Lex Frieden Employment Awards, by The Office of the Governor's Committee on People with Disabilities, Targeted News Service reported. Named for Texas disability rights champion Lex Frieden, the awards are bestowed upon Texans who have displayed a commitment to empowering their employees, co-workers, and fellow Texans with disabilities.

Book promotion

UTA alumnus Marion Brooks was featured on KDFW FOX 4 promoting his new book, “What you don’t know is hurting you.” Brooks received his marketing degree from UTA.

Alumna joins medical team

UTA alumna Corrine del Perugia-Stoddart, an advanced practice registered nurse, recently joined the family medicine team of Keene hospital, The Hub reported. Del Perugia-Stoddart holds a master's degree in nursing from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, November 5, 2018
shortDescription: Quantum communications UTA engineers received a $750,000 National Science Foundation grant to explore how to develop better quantum communications, Da
body:
Quantum communications

UTA engineers received a $750,000 National Science Foundation grant to explore how to develop better quantum communications, Dallas Innovates reported. Michael Vasilyev, a professor of electrical engineering, and his research partner, Yuping Huang of the Stevens Institute of Technology, are the chief researchers on the project.

Endowed chair awarded

Bob Woods, longtime UTA mechanical engineering professor and Formula SAE adviser, is the first recipient of an endowed chair established in his honor in 2017 through a gift from Paul E. Andrews Jr., an entrepreneur and businessman, Targeted News Service reported.

Logo revenue

UTA is bringing in licensing cash for its sale of university swag, the Dallas Business Journal reported in a story about sales of items with university logos from top North Texas colleges.

Regulation needed

It’s time for Texas to regulate oil and gas drilling at a safe distance from homes, two UTA researchers wrote in an op-ed column for The Dallas Morning News. Zacariah Hildenbrand, a researcher with UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, and Kevin Schug, a UTA professor of analytical chemistry and director of the CLEAR lab, wrote the column.

Film winner

Elias Moreno, UTA film and criminal justice major, has won awards for his film, Unarmed, about police brutality, KDFW Fox 4 and Fox4News.com reported.

Split control

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said on KLIF 570 AM that if polls are to be believed, the Democrats will take the U.S. House and the Republicans will keep control of the U.S. Senate following Tuesday’s election.

Basketball season starting

Anticipation is building for first-year coach Chris Ogden as UTA men’s basketball tips off in less than a week, the Star-Telegram reported. Ogden said it is exciting but also nerve-wracking at the same time. Ogden, a former Texas Tech and UT Austin assistant coach, started his job at UTA in April.

Online learning

UTA recently began a learning management system transition from Blackboard to Canvas, Inside Higher Ed reported. Erin Morgan, UTA’s assistant vice president of IT administration, was quoted in the article.

Politics on Think

KERAnews.org reported that the Think radio show on Wednesday will feature Rebecca Deen, chair of the UTA Political Science Department.

Voter turnout

Brent Boyea, a UTA associate professor of political science, said it is logical for people to assume the high voter turnout is a “blue wave,” but it is difficult to tell solely from numbers, The Dallas Morning News reported in a story about the record voter turnout for Tuesday’s election.

Lamster book released

Mark Lamster, UTA professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, explores the life of the iconic architect, Philip Johnson, and the release of his book The Man in the Glass House in a DADA story. DADA is the Dallas Art Dealers’ Association.

Materials standard

A UTA researcher is leading a $1 million U.S. Air Force Research Laboratory grant looking at establishing fatigue and durability standards for materials used in aircraft, Targeted News Service reported. Endel Iarve, a UTA professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering, is leading the project.

Military Times ranking

Military Times ranked The University of Texas at Arlington the No. 1 four-year institution in Texas for veterans and their families to earn a college degree, Targeted News Service reported.

College of Education ranking

College Choice named UTA’s College of Education online master of education in curriculum and instruction one of the best in the country, Targeted News Service reported.

Movie debuts

The Star-Telegram published an op-ed column on a new movie titled The Iron Orchard. The movie is based on Fort Worth’s prominent Van Zandt family of oil fortunes fame. Two photographs from the Fort Worth Star-Telegram’s archives, which are housed in UTA’s Special Collections, were featured in the column.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, October 29, 2018
shortDescription: Reducing stressTwo UTA social work professors are using an NIH grant to find ways to reduce stress of families caring for loved ones with Alzheimer's
body:
Reducing stress

Two UTA social work professors are using an NIH grant to find ways to reduce stress of families caring for loved ones with Alzheimer's disease, Dallas Innovates and Targeted News Service reported. Noelle Fields and Ling Xu, both assistant professors in UTA’s School of Social Work, were awarded a $459,994 National Institutes of Health grant for their research titled "The Senior Companion Program Plus (SCP Plus): A Psychoeducational Intervention for African American Dementia Caregivers."

UTA disability-focused programs honored

Four disability-focused programs at UTA have been awarded the Martha Arbuckle Award, a statewide award recognizing the most innovative local committee project, Targeted News Service reported. The award is given by the Texas Governor's Committee on People with Disabilities each year.

Stand up to political polls

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said people should stand up to deceptive political polls that try to push information, The Dallas Morning News and Denton Record-Chronicle reported. The watchdog article warned consumers about ethically questionable partisan polls.

Alum on 40 under 40 list

Muhammad Farooq Wahab, research engineering scientist in UTA's Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, has won a place in the Analytical Chemists 2018 Top 40 Under 40 Power List of young analytical scientists, published by the prestigious British magazine The Analytical Scientist in the October 2018 edition, Pakistan Press International reported.

Climate change

UTA researchers found that between 2041 and 2050, Dallas-Fort Worth could see high temperatures in excess of 120 degrees on a yearly basis, The Daily Texan reported in an op-ed by Sam Groves on how climate change will change our lives.

Football talk

UTA is considering reviving its football program more than 30 years after it was disbanded, KXAS NBC 5 reported. The Dallas Morning News published the original story.

Early voting

Tarrant County is splitting up its early voting between several universities and colleges, offering three days of early voting at both UTA and Texas Christian University, The Texas Tribune, The Gilmer Mirror and KUT 90.5 AM in Austin reported.

New property financed

HFF has arranged debt financing for 101 Center, a mixed-use property located adjacent to UTA, Rebusiness Online reported. The property, which was completed earlier this year, features 244 conventional apartments and student housing units totaling 493 beds, as well as 18,400 square feet of retail space.

New VP of World Bank

UTA alumnus Jingdong Hua has been named vice president and treasurer of the World Bank, thedayaftergr and Fast Mail reported. He holds an UTA MBA in finance.

Builder of the year

Lynn Motheral, UTA alumnus and construction research advisory board executive committee member, has been named builder of the year, the Fort Worth Business Press reported.

Gubernatorial appointee

Texas Gov. Greg Abbott has reappointed UTA alumna Karen Pickard to the Advisory Council on Emergency Medical Services, Al Bawaba Business reported. Pickard received a nursing degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, September 28, 2018
shortDescription: Not so affordableUTA researchers determined in a new study that subsidized housing is not affordable in the Dallas-Fort Worth region because its locat
body:
Not so affordable

UTA researchers determined in a new study that subsidized housing is not affordable in the Dallas-Fort Worth region because its location does not make it transportation-friendly, Informed Infrastructure and Targeted News Service reported. Shima Hamidi, assistant professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, and two of her doctoral students, Jinat Jahan and Somayeh Moazzeni, published “Does Location Matter? Performance Analysis of the Affordable Housing Programs with Respect to Transportation Affordability in Dallas Fort Worth (DFW) Metropolis” in the Transportation Research Record journal.

Festival of Ideas

"Migration, Immigration and the Art of Survival" is the theme of The University of Texas at Arlington College of Liberal Arts' Fall 2018 Festival of Ideas, Targeted News Service reported. The event is 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 4, in the E.H. Hereford University Center, 300 W. First St.

Jumping genes

Esther Betran, UTA professor of biology, will be using the high-tech tools provided by the North Texas Genome Center to shed light on the role of  "jumping genes," NewsRX Health reported. She recently won a $570,197 National Science Foundation grant for her work on functional and comparative genomics research.

Career fair

Students converged on the UTA All-Majors Career Fair Wednesday, Arlington-Tx.gov reported. The job fair provided students and alumni the opportunity to mingle with several local companies. Melanie McGee, corporate relations director for the College of Business, said the fair is important because it allows outstanding student talent the opportunity to stay local.

Kavanaugh hearing

UTA’s Allan Saxe, an associate professor of political science, said the highlight of yesterday’s Brett Kavanaugh hearing testimony came from Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-South Carolina, who said the hearing was a well-organized attempt to slander someone, KLIF 570 AM and WBAP 820 AM reported. A Senate committee is hearing sexual harassment allegations against the Supreme Court nominee.

Alumna appointed

Texas Gov. Greg Abbott appointed Karen Pickard of Ovilla to the Advisory Council on Emergency Medical Services, Guidry News reported. Pickard has a UTA nursing degree.

Arts enhance community

A new Miami program can make art collectors of everyone, the Miami Herald and Fire News Feed reported. The story cited a UTA study that found that locating arts facilities and nonprofits in disadvantaged areas has a positive effect on the community.

Community leader

Texas Trust will honor long-time community leader Terry Bertrand with the 2018 Dream Builder Award, BizWire Express reported. Bertrand has been associate pastor of administration at First Baptist Church Arlington and was cited for working with all communities in downtown Arlington, including UTA.

Award recipient

The bionorthTX Board of Directors named Darlene Boudreaux as this year’s recipient of the 2018 Dennis K. Stone Award, Dallas Innovates reported. Last year’s recipient, Lyda Hill, will present the award at the fourth annual iC3 Life Science Summit at UTA on Oct. 10. Boudreaux works at TechFW, a business coaching nonprofit that partners with UTA.

Alumna appointed

Debbie Messemer has been appointed to the Allogene Therapeutics Board of Directors, Pharmacy Choice reported. Messemer has a UTA bachelor’s degree in accounting.

Professor on jury

David Grogan, UTA associate professor of music, served as a juror on the board awarding The Arts Community Alliance awards, Theater Jones reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 28, 2018
shortDescription: GM layoffsFernando Jaramillo, professor of economics at UTA, believes supply and demand are the reasons for the latest General Motors layoffs and plan
body:
GM layoffs

Fernando Jaramillo, professor of economics at UTA, believes supply and demand are the reasons for the latest General Motors layoffs and plant shutdowns, Telemundo 39 reported.

Environmental study

A heat and drought study by UTA’s Arne Winguth was noted in Robert Wilonsky’s column about water supply in The Dallas Morning News. Winguth is an associate professor of earth and environmental sciences.

Heat impact

A 2015 study by UTA researchers on heat damage related to transportation was mentioned in a republished article in The Dallas Morning News. The study showed heat affects roads, bridges, railroads and vehicles, which in turn affect humans and wildlife.

Esports facility

UTA’s esports team has its own room at the new Esports Stadium Arlington, the largest esports facility in North America, MoneyMakers.com reported.

Alumni exhibit

Kapil Mani Dixit, a well-known artist in Kathmandu, Nepal, has an exhibit at Afactory Studio Museum of Arts in Irving, The Dallas Morning News reported. "Facing Reality" features 30 large-scale paintings of the human body. Dixit earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree at UTA.

New plantings

UTA’s Ecology Club helped seed more than three acres of Texas native wildflowers at Timbercreek Park and the entrance of Lake Park at Sandy Beach Road, the Lewisville Leader reported. The project was an effort to increase native pollinator habitats across the city.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, October 12, 2018
shortDescription: Nursing deanElizabeth Merwin, professor and executive vice dean of the School of Nursing at Duke University, has been named dean of the College of Nur
body:
Nursing dean

Elizabeth Merwin, professor and executive vice dean of the School of Nursing at Duke University, has been named dean of the College of Nursing and Health Innovation at the University of Texas at Arlington, The Chronicle of Higher Education reported.

NSF grant

Robert Magnusson, UTA’s Texas Instruments Distinguished University Chair in Nanoelectronics and an electrical engineering professor, will use a $360,000 National Science Foundation grant for his research into band flips and bound states in leaky-mode resonant photonic lattices, Phys.org and Techsite reported.

Strengthening infrastructure

Sahadat Hossain, a UTA civil engineering professor, is using a $1.37 million proof-of-concept contract from the Texas Department of Transportation to utilize recycled plastic pins to strengthen mechanically stabilized earth on North Texas highways, Scienmag reported.

Smart seat cushion

Researchers at the University of Texas at Arlington have patented a smart seat cushion that uses changes in air pressure to redistribute body weight to help prevent pressure ulcers, Germany’s der-querschnitt.de reported. Muthu Wijesundara, co-inventor of the technology, is chief research scientist at UTA's Research Institute.

UTA-Navy agreement

UTA and the Naval Surface Warfare Center Philadelphia signed an education partnership agreement, Techsite reported. The pact allows UTA faculty and students to collaborate in U.S. Navy research projects, loan equipment to the university for educational purposes, and, perhaps, developing and teaching science and engineering courses at the university.

FAA award

Shivam Arora, a dual-degree track graduate student in accounting and business analytics, has won the 2018-19 Airport Cooperative Research Program's Graduate Research Award, Targeted News Service reported. Arora plans to develop factor models for fixed-income securities issued by U.S. airport-affiliated entities.

Helping the elderly

Rupal Parekh, a UTA School of Social Work doctoral candidate, is working with the Elder Orphan Group to uncover preliminary data that brings clarity about the issues facing this elderly segment of the population, NextAvenue reported.

Life science summit

UTA hosted the fourth annual IC3 Life Science Summit this week, Targeted News Service reported.

Alumnus featured

Christopher Boone, vice president at Pfizer, was profiled in PharmExec.com in a story featuring several pharmaceutical leaders in the industry. Boone earned a master’s degree in health care administration from UTA.

New UNC System VP

Kimberly van Noort, a former UTA associate dean in the College of Liberal Arts, was appointed senior vice president for academic affairs and chief academic officer of the University of North Carolina System, The University of North Carolina System website reported.

Alumna named reporter

Renee Yan is the new reporter for Grapevine, Colleyville and Southlake, Community Impact reported. Yan is a UTA alumna.

Alumnus finalist for job

Mike Holguin, a former UTA assistant chief of police, is a finalist for the city of Pharr police chief, the Brownsville Herald reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, December 14, 2018
shortDescription: UTA Provost Teik C. Lim, also a professor of mechanical engineering, and L.K. Mestha, an affiliated adjunct professor in the Department of Electrical
body:
UTA Provost Teik C. Lim, also a professor of mechanical engineering, and L.K. Mestha, an affiliated adjunct professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering, have been named fellows of the National Academy of Inventors, MarketScreener.com and Targeted News Service reported. Lim and Mestha bring the total number of UTA fellows to 14, the highest number for a Texas university.

Adrian Parr, UTA dean of the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, and Michael Zaretsky, associate professor of civil engineering, received a UT System STARs grant that will help further research into water and planning conditions in North Texas, Dallas Innovates reported.

Approximately 5,400 students are participating in commencement ceremonies this week at College Park Center on the UTA campus, Targeted News Service reported. The newest graduates will join the ranks of more than 230,000 UTA alumni around the globe.

The UTeach Arlington secondary math and science teacher preparation program at The University of Texas at Arlington has been selected for a grant by the Arlington Tomorrow Foundation to benefit UTeach students and youth served by the Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Tarrant County, NewsRX Heath & Science reported.

The Environmental Protection Agency awarded UTA its Leadership Award in the narrative award category in EPA’s Food Recovery Challenge, Targeted News Service reported.

Mark Lamster’s book about famous architect Philip Johnson, The Man in the Glass House, was reviewed in The New Yorker magazine. Lamster is a professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs and the architecture critic for The Dallas Morning News. The New Yorker called the book a brisk, clear-eyed new biography of Johnson.

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, told WIBX AM 850 in Utica, N.Y., and WJAS 1320 AM in Pittsburgh that it’s an insult for members of the Central American caravan trying to gain access to this country to ask for $50,000 each to go home. Saxe also talked about the political legacy of George H. W. Bush.

Dallas’ approach to infrastructure is to invest in the future, American Infrastructure reported in an article naming Dallas as Municipality of the Year. However, a UTA study said that even after making drastic infrastructure improvements, Dallas is still susceptible to the effects of climate and natural disaster.

SportTechie reported about Arlington’s new esports arena. The article said UTA has one of the top collegiate esports programs in the country and has its own team room inside the stadium to use as training space.

Rachel Cardwell joined Faegre Baker Daniels to practice with the firm's business litigation group, Targeted News Service reported. She earned both her master's and bachelor’s degrees from UTA.

Steven Morris has been named permanent executive director of Theatre Arlington, BroadwayWorld.com reported. Morris earned his bachelor’s degree from UTA.

UTA student Jeremy Averyt of Burleson was initiated into The Honor Society of Phi Kappa Phi, the nation’s oldest and most selective all-discipline collegiate honor society, the Burleson Star reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, December 12, 2018
shortDescription: Fall commencementApproximately 5,400 students are participating in commencement ceremonies Dec. 13-15 at College Park Center on the UTA campus, Arling
body:
Fall commencement

Approximately 5,400 students are participating in commencement ceremonies Dec. 13-15 at College Park Center on the UTA campus, Arlington-tx.gov reported. The newest graduates will join the ranks of more than 230,000 UTA alumni around the globe.

Ride share service

City officials say that Via, Arlington’s on-demand ride share company, is providing its residents with transportation answers, the Star-Telegram reported. Via services the UTA area, as well as other spots in Arlington.

EPA award

The Environmental Protection Agency awarded UTA its Leadership Award in the narrative award category in EPA’s Food Recovery Challenge, Waste Today Magazine reported.

Stargazing

Levent Gurdemir, director of the UTA Planetarium, told The Dallas Morning News that Dallas has one of the brightest skies in the United States because of the size of the city in an article about the best places in North Texas to stargaze. Starting in January, UTA will open a new observatory on its campus that will host public events in conjunction with shows at its planetarium. Watch for announcements on the UTA planetarium website.

Social work professor in choir

Karla Arenas-Itotia, UTA School of Social Work assistant professor in practice, performed with the Dallas Police choir for some holiday songs on KDFW Fox 4’s Good Day show. “I love it. I think it’s a great way to bridge the gap between community and police.” Arenas-Itotia won a contest to perform in some of the choir’s performances.

Ethiopia landfills

Sahadat Hossain, a UTA civil engineering professor and researcher, told Ethiopia’s The Reporter that the city government is working closely with the U.S. embassy to revitalize the Sendafa Landfill Plant. A garbage slide at the Repi Landfill claimed the lives of 72 people and victimized hundreds more nearly a year ago.

Lecturer at LitNight

Laura Kopchick, UTA senior lecturer of English, brought humor to the tale of a suicidal bowling-alley pinsetter at LitNight, a fiction reading event, The Dallas Morning News reported. Kopchick was one of a half-dozen fiction authors each given 15 minutes to read part of their works.

Recycled plastic

Sahadat Hossain, UTA civil engineering professor, said using recycled plastic in roads could become a staple, Impact Lab reported. Hossain leads a test project that uses recycled plastic to shore up raised highway roadbeds in Texas.

Pitcher profiled

NBCSports.com wrote a profile on Zach Thompson, a Chicago White Sox pitcher, who was drafted in the fifth round in 2014 out of UTA.

Alumnus named senior project manager

Spiezle Architectural Group Inc. has hired Michael Thurston as senior project manager, HC+O News reported. Thursday earned his master’s degree in architecture from UTA.

Student in honor society

Melissa Pantalone of Orange, Conn., was initiated into The Honor Society of Phi Kappa Phi, the nation's oldest and most selective all-discipline collegiate honor society, Patch.com reported. Pantalone is pursuing a degree in Nursing at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, October 10, 2018
shortDescription: Photonics researchRobert Magnusson, UTA’s Texas Instruments Distinguished University Chair in Nanoelectronics and an electrical engineering professor,
body:
Photonics research

Robert Magnusson, UTA’s Texas Instruments Distinguished University Chair in Nanoelectronics and an electrical engineering professor, will use a $360,000 National Science Foundation grant for his research into band flips and bound states in leaky-mode resonant photonic lattices, Science & Technology Research News reported.

Dallas VideoFest

Bart Weiss, UTA associate professor of film in the Art and Art History Department, told WFAA ABC 8 that this year’s Dallas VideoFest will feature many award-winning documentaries. Weiss is director and founder of Dallas VideoFest.

Help for first-generation students

UTA’s Carla Amaro-Jiménez, an associate professor in the College of Education, helps first-generation and Hispanic students overcome obstacles in their higher education journeys, reported The Hechinger Report, an independent, nonprofit newsroom covering in-depth education topics. Amaro-Jiménez runs the IDEAS. Center, a hub of services to students transitioning to a four-year university. IDEAS – innovation, diversity, excellence, access and success – is on the second floor of the Central Library. UTA is one of the few universities that includes its faculty in working to meet these academic challenges. “A person can make a change,” Amaro-Jiménez said, “just by asking questions and showing that they care.” The Hechinger Report story originally ran in The Washington Post.

ClaimBuster

Germany’s idw-online.de published a story about social media platforms, including ClaimBuster, a fact-checking tool designed by Chengkai Li, a UTA computer science and engineering associate professor. Mark Tremayne, UTA associate professor of communication, also works on the project.

Libraries Special Collection

The Travel Channel show Expedition Unknown: Hunt for Extraterrestrials visited UTA Libraries Special Collection to inspect what’s known as the Ramey photo collection, which chronicles the Roswell UFO incident of 1947. Brenda McClurkin, department head of special collections, is in the video at about the 17:30 mark.

Fundraising gala

"Money Doctor" Neil Gallagher, founder, president, and CEO of Gallagher Financial Group Inc., will be the guest of honor at the Sixth Annual Fundraising Gala Dinner for the Malaika Orphanage Children Foundation at UTA on Oct. 27, SeattlePI.com reported.

UTA listed in blog

UTA was mentioned in New York City blog as one of the 10 things to know about the Dallas-Fort Worth metro area.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, September 24, 2018
shortDescription: National stageEnrollment growth and the opening of the Science and Engineering Innovation and Research, or SEIR, building are helping place UTA on nat
body:
National stage

Enrollment growth and the opening of the Science and Engineering Innovation and Research, or SEIR, building are helping place UTA on national stage, an op-ed article in the Star-Telegram said. Former Arlington mayor Richard Greene wrote the op-ed. Greene also is a professor in practice in UTA's College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

Responsible extraction

Kevin Schug, UTA's Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of the Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation or CLEAR lab, cowrote an op-ed in The Dallas Morning News about responsible shale extraction and CLEAR’s focus on studying the environmental implications from a neutral, objective and agnostic perspective.

Smart seat cushion

New Atlas, Dallas Innovates, MedicalNewser, ArlingtonTx.gov, Infosur, Techojas, Iranian Students News Agency, Smart Huangiu of China, Sina of Hong Kong, Udaipur Kiran, Devdiscourse, Daily News and Analysis and Gadgets Now of India and TD News of Tunisia, all featured UTA’s recently patented smart seat cushion that can help ward off ulcers caused by long periods of sitting in wheelchairs. Muthu Wijesundara, chief research scientist at UTA’s Research Institute, was co-inventor of the technology, which also can be used to create prosthetic liners that accommodate changes in body volume to maintain a comfortable fit.

Special education summit

Nearly 150 public school superintendents and special education administrators discussed Texas' changing views on how to serve children with disabilities at the Texas Special Education Policy and Resource Summit this week at College Park Center, Targeted News Service reported. The summit, hosted by UTA’s College of Education, provided an opportunity for leaders in the education sector to determine the policies and educational needs of children with disabilities. 

Kavanaugh hearing

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by Cincinnati's 700 WLW AM about the possibility that Christine Blasey Ford will testify against Judge Brett Kavanaugh this week in Washington, D.C. He said that it was likely Kavanaugh would testify on Monday while Dr. Ford would speak on Thursday.

Alumna joins Dallas Housing Authority

UTA alumna Myriam Igoufe has joined the Dallas Housing Authority as director of Housing Services for DHA’s Housing Choice Voucher program, Dallas Business Journal reported. Igoufe is a recent UTA doctoral graduate in urban planning and public policy.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, October 24, 2018
shortDescription: NSF EAGER grantFrank Lewis, the Moncrief-O'Donnell Professor of Electrical Engineering, Yan Wan and Ali Davoudi, associate professors of electrical en
body:
NSF EAGER grant

Frank Lewis, the Moncrief-O'Donnell Professor of Electrical Engineering, Yan Wan and Ali Davoudi, associate professors of electrical engineering, are using a $220,000 Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research, or EAGER, from the National Science Foundation to use real-time learning to create a unified theory on how to optimize microgrid capacity through DC distribution, Phys.org, TechSite and Targeted News Service reported.

Design-Build Award

Sharareh Kermanshachi, UTA assistant professor of civil engineering, is receiving a 2018 National Design-Build Award at the 2018 Design-Build Conference and Expo from the Design-Build Institute of America, Waco's KTTV ABC 25 reported. In addition to serving as the director of UTA’s Construction Research Lab, supervising multiple doctoral and master’s students, Kermanshachi founded UTA’s Design-Build Institute of America student chapter and currently serves as its faculty adviser.

Rapid adaptation

The Miami Herald and Spiceworks featured a UTA study that shows how Burmese pythons in Florida have rapidly adapted to become hardier and more resistant to cold than their Asian cousins. UTA Biology Professor Todd Castoe led the research.

Staff reductions study

A Harvard Business School case study on whether it is necessary to fire employees to improve toxic work environments cited a 2012 study by Deepak Datta, UTA distinguished professor and Eunice and James L. West Endowed Chair of Private Enterprise and Entrepreneurship, that found that staff reductions had a neutral to negative effect on stock prices in the days after the announcement.

Patents awarded

UTA has been awarded U.S. and international patents on a nanoparticle material that can be activated by light, microwave, X-ray or ultrasound to kill multiple kinds of cancers, Science & Technology Research News reported. “This new nanoparticle material has many properties that improve upon traditional photodynamic cancer therapies, where light is used to activate a particle that kills cancer cells,” said Wei Chen, UTA physics professor and inventor.

High voter turnout

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, cited the convenience factor and the intense U.S. Senate race as the reasons behind the high levels of turnout for early voting, KXAS NBC 5 reported. Saxe also discussed President Trump’s support for Sen. Ted Cruz on KTRH 740 AM in Houston.

Guest director

Anne Healy, UTA assistant professor of theatre arts, is in the guest director’s chair for Theatre UNI’s musical, “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee,” at the Gallagher Bluedorn Performing Arts Center, The Courier in Cedar Falls, Iowa, reported. Healy is a University of Northern Iowa alumna.

Packaging funding

UTA is receiving three years of new funding, equipment and design software from The International Corrugated Packaging Foundation, RISI Technology Channels and Flexoglobal reported. ICPF works with students from more than 40 universities annually and has over 25 university partners that are currently teaching corrugated curricula.

Top transfer practices

Research from the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board determined that UTA has some of the best dual credit transfer practices, Waco's KXXV ABC 25 reported. Students taking dual credit courses has increased in Texas and the state is estimated to have one of the highest number of students enrolled in those courses with more than 150,000.

In-depth study

An in-depth study of “Patient Examination Devices – Medical Devices Pipeline Assessment, 2018” with future industry trends, projections of global growth and major key players includes an overview of UTA alongside higher education giants like Johns Hopkins and California Institute of Technology, Tactical Business and The Aerospace News reported.

Tops at rental investment

UTA is helping Arlington become one of the best places in Texas to invest in rental real estate, FirenewsFeed reported. Arlington’s population has grown impressively over the years. From an Arlingtoni population of 332,969 in 2010 to its current 390,000-plus — a growth rate of 18 percent over eight years.

Alum in USAF band

UTA alumnus James Layfield is touring the country with the U.S. Air Force Concert Band, the McKinney Courier-Gazette reported. Since being chosen from more than 70 trombone candidates for the band, Layfield has performed in the Inaugural Parade, Arlington Cemetery ceremonies, Macy's Thanksgiving Parade and various events in the nation's capital.

Market president named

First National Bank announced that UTA alumna Ashley Vannoy has joined the company as market president of the Destin market, The Post-Searchlight reported.

Alumna helping undocumented immigrants

UTA alumna Maria Garcia dedicates her time to helping undocumented immigrants, The Et Cetera reported. Garcia is a former undocumented immigrant and current president of the North Texas Dream Team. She graduated from UTA with a bachelor’s degree in public relations.

Alumna joining Sheehan Lab

UTA alumna Heather Reynolds, a nonprofit leader with extensive expertise in poverty alleviation, will join the Wilson Sheehan Lab for Economic Opportunities at the University of Notre Dame as its inaugural managing director in January, USAgNet.com reported. Reynolds has served as president and CEO at Catholic Charities Fort Worth for the past 14 years.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, October 17, 2018
shortDescription: New nanoparticle materialUTA has been awarded U.S. and international patents on a nanoparticle material that can be activated by light, microwave, X-r
body:
New nanoparticle material

UTA has been awarded U.S. and international patents on a nanoparticle material that can be activated by light, microwave, X-ray or ultrasound to kill multiple kinds of cancers, Phys.org and Techsite reported. “This new nanoparticle material has many properties that improve upon traditional photodynamic cancer therapies, where light is used to activate a particle that kills cancer cells,” said Wei Chen, UTA physics professor and inventor.

Increasing PhDs

A UTA computer science professor has received a $1.2 million grant from the U.S. Department of Education, supplemented with $300,000 in UTA matching funds, that will significantly increase the number of doctoral students, especially among women and minorities, Scienmag reported. UTA Professor Ishfaq Ahmad will lead the project.

Debate preview

Rebecca Deen, UTA chair of political science, previewed last night’s debate between U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz and U.S. Rep. Beto O’Rourke, KERAnews.org and Austin’s KUT 90.5 AM reported. Deen said that the issue for both candidates going forward focuses on voter turnout for the election.

Validation studies

Kevin Schug, UTA’s Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry, was described as “instrumental in the early validation studies” for VUV Analytics’ vacuum ultraviolet technologies, WICZ Fox 40 in Binghamton, N.Y., and many other media reported. VUV Analytics and Shimadzu have announced a Global Solutions Distribution agreement for the technology.

Crews' wife interviewed

Rebecca Crews, wife of actor and activist Terry Crews, mentioned during a Tuesday morning interview that she would be at UTA for her husband’s speech last night at the Maverick Speaker Series, WFAA ABC 8 reported.

ASME award

Jimil Shah, who recently received a doctorate in mechanical enginering from UTA, is the recipient of the 2018 ASME Electronic and Photonic Packaging Division Student Engineer of the Year Award, Scienmag reported. He received the award at the recent American Society of Mechanical Engineers' InterPACK Conference in San Francisco.

UTA pianist to play

Stefan Karlsson, UTA music specialist/jazz artist-in-residence pianist, percussionist Zach Harmon, jazz bassist Bob Bowman and Ryan Matzinger, director of jazz bands in the Montana State University School of Music, will perform at 7:30 p.m. Nov. 1, at the Rialto in downtown Bozeman, Mont., U.S. Fed News reported. 

Student exhibits

UTA students are participating in the Cross Connections 2018 International Exhibit of Design & Illustration at the University of South Alabama, which opens on Thursday, Oct. 18, and will continue through Oct. 31, U.S. Fed News reported.

Generational friction

Millennials and Generation Z’ers compose the majority of the Jordanian population, according to an op-ed in Jordan Vista by UTA alumna Lynn Malkawi. She added that a lot of the friction caused in workplaces stems from processes and procedures designed for Generation X but implemented by Generation Z'ers and Millennials. The article originally appeared in The Jordan Times.

Alumnus featured

UTA alumnus E. Ramon Cavazos was featured as a rising star by Healthcare Design. Cavazos is vice president, senior designer and business development practice leader at HKS Inc. in Dallas.

New managing director

UTA alumna Sandy Martin has joined Dennard Lascar Investor Relations as managing director of the company’s new Fort Worth office, where the firm already has a strong client presence, Morningstar reported. Martin earned an undergraduate accounting degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, September 26, 2018
shortDescription: SEIR buildingUTA will host a ribbon-cutting for its new $125 million Science & Engineering Innovation & Research building on Friday, Sept. 28, The Dal
body:
SEIR building

UTA will host a ribbon-cutting for its new $125 million Science & Engineering Innovation & Research building on Friday, Sept. 28, The Dallas Morning News reported. The ceremony will be followed by lab tours with VIPs, students, community members and researchers who will work in the building.

Subsidized housing study

UTA researchers determined in a new study that subsidized housing is not affordable in the Dallas-Fort Worth region because its location does not make it transportation friendly, Health Medicine Network and Phys.org reported. Shima Hamidi, assistant professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, and two of her doctoral students, Jinat Jahan and Somayeh Moazzeni, published “Does Location Matter? Performance Analysis of the Affordable Housing Programs with Respect to Transportation Affordability in Dallas Fort Worth (DFW) Metropolis” in the Transportation Research Record journal.

Short story dispenser

The UTA Library has installed a short story dispenser that delivers literature, both classic and contemporary works of art, in a vending machine style, Dallas Innovates reported. “This machine allows our community to take printed literature on the go,” said Rebecca Bichel, UTA dean of libraries. “We want to encourage literacy and the short story dispenser allows us to present great writing easily packaged for instant gratification. This is a way for the library to support and encourage literacy in a new way.”

TBI research

Paul Fadel, professor of kinesiology and associate dean for research and director of clinical translational science at UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation, is part of research team led by the University of Missouri School of Medicine that has been awarded a four-year, nearly $4 million grant from the U.S. Department of Defense to study the cardiovascular consequences of traumatic brain injury, PressReleasePoint reported. 

Differing polls

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by KRLD 1080 AM about the huge differences in the political polls, some of which say that the Republicans are leading heading into November and some of which say that the Democrats are way ahead. 

UTA science camp inspired

NASA administrator Jim Bridenstine was featured on C-SPAN discussing his experiences at a fifth-grade summer science camp at UTA, which convinced him that he wanted to become a pilot. 

New senior VP

UTA alumnus Steve Prochnow has been promoted to senior vice president of property management of Mill Creek Residential, PR Newswire reported. Prochnow earned a UTA master's degree in real estate.

Alumna featured

UTA alumna Froswa’​ Booker-Drew was featured in IdeaMensch as a leader and entrepreneur. She was awarded the 2012 Outstanding African American Alumni Award from UTA.

Solo show

Politechnika Krakowska presents Daunting Transitions, an interdisciplinary solo show by artist Kathryn Hart,  Artdaily.org reported. The show is on view through Oct. 17 in Kotlownia Exhibition Hall in Krakow, Poland, She holds a UTA master's degree in business administration.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, December 10, 2018
shortDescription: Detecting malwareJiang Ming, an assistant professor in the UTA Computer Science and Engineering Department, co-authored a paper detailing a new, highl
body:
Detecting malware

Jiang Ming, an assistant professor in the UTA Computer Science and Engineering Department, co-authored a paper detailing a new, highly effective way to detect malware on Windows-based computers using a common obfuscation technique known as binary packing, Targeted News Service reported.

UTeach grant

The UTeach Arlington secondary math and science teacher preparation program at The University of Texas at Arlington has been selected for a grant by the Arlington Tomorrow Foundation to benefit UTeach students and youth served by the Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Tarrant County, Arlington-TX.gov and U.S. Fed News reported.

DOE project

UTA researchers have won a $1 million grant from the U.S. Department of Energy to build a detector that may offer a key insight into the lingering mystery of the universe's matter-antimatter imbalance, Targeted News Service reported. UTA Presidential Distinguished Professor of Physics David Nygren is leading the research.

Engineering partners

UTA’s Electrical Engineering Department is partnering with Liaison International’s EngineeringCAS™, SFGate.com and several other media outlets reported. The system is aimed at streamlining the graduate engineering admissions process.

Political issues discussed

Rebecca Deen, UTA associate professor and chair of the Department of Political Science, told KUT 90.5 FM and the Texas Standard listeners that GOP leaders in Tarrant County are set to vote on whether to remove Shahid Shafi, a sitting Southlake council member, because of his religion, but not everyone is on board with that. Deen touched on a number of other issues on the radio broadcast.

ADA history

Former Shorthorn adviser John Dycus was quoted in a story about one of former President George H. W. Bush's biggest accomplishments, the Americans with Disabilities Act, published in the Corpus Christi Caller-Times and Abilene Reporter News. Dycus, who grew up with cerebral palsy and is an Arlington freelance writer and editor, remembers what life was like before the landmark act became law. "It brought people into the mainstream," Dycus said of the ADA. "People who deserved to be there. When I think of the ADA, I think of curb cuts that allow people in wheelchairs to get from one side of the street to the other — and get there safely." The story was orginally published by the USA Today Network.

Special Collections photo

A Dallas Morning News opinion column said a South Dallas neighborhood wrecked by a freeway could become whole again. The article featured a UTA Special Collections picture of the neighborhood as construction of the South Central Expressway was taking place in 1995.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, December 19, 2018
shortDescription: UTA Provost Teik C. Lim, also a professor of mechanical engineering, and L.K. Mestha, an affiliated adjunct professor in the Department of Electrical
body:
UTA Provost Teik C. Lim, also a professor of mechanical engineering, and L.K. Mestha, an affiliated adjunct professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering, have been named fellows of the National Academy of Inventors, EurekaAlert! and Scienmag reported. Lim and Mestha bring the total number of UTA fellows to 14, the highest number for a Texas university.

Anand Puppala, associate dean for research in UTA’s College of Engineering and a professor of civil engineering, has been named a fellow of the United Kingdom's Institution of Civil Engineer, EurekaAlert! and Targeted News Service reported. The institution is the world’s oldest civil engineering society.

Alumnus Mike Foreman has been appointed as interim town manager of Monument, Colo., The Tribune reported. Foreman earned a bachelor’s degree in business administration and a master’s in public administration from UTA.

UTA students Anju Adhikari and Molly Struna were initiated into The Honor Society of Phi Kappa Phi. Adhikari's honor was reported in the Greensboro (N.C.) News & Record. Struna's appeared in the Waco Tribune-Herald.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, December 3, 2018
shortDescription: Sensitive skinA UTA research team may one day cover robots and prosthetic devices with skin equipped with nanotechnology to provide them with a sense
body:
Sensitive skin

A UTA research team may one day cover robots and prosthetic devices with skin equipped with nanotechnology to provide them with a sense of touch far superior to humans, SIGNAL Magazine reported. Zeynep Çelik-Butler, UTA electrical engineering professor, is leading the research. SIGNAL is a product of the Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association.

Bush legacy

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said that George H.W. Bush, the 41st president of the United States, will be remembered for leaving a family political legacy, Cincinnati’s WLW 700 AM and Houston’s KTRH 740 AM reported. Saxe said the media coverage following the recent death of Bush will be positive, but historians will delve into the former president’s life more intimately.

Award winner

Colby Allen earned the Crescent Real Estate Chair for Teaching Excellence in Career and Technology Education presented at a Fort Worth Independent School District award luncheon recently, EIN Presswire reported. Allen is chairman of the Graphic Design and Engineering Pathway Department at Fort Worth ISD's Young Women’s Leadership Academy. He earned a UTA bachelor’s degree in film and video.

Nurse recognized

Melissa Nielsen has been recognized by Continental Who's Who as a Pinnacle Professional in the field of nursing for her role as a registered nurse at Porter Adventist Hospital, One News Page, Missouri’s KOAM CBS 7 and many other media outlets reported. Nielsen earned a bachelor’s degree in nursing from UTA.

Student profiled

Jackie Spencer was profiled in Odessa American Online about her career in the beauty industry. Spencer will graduate in May 2019 with a degree in advertising and business administration.

Weber State finalist

Frank Lamas, vice president of student affairs and enrollment management at California State University, Fresno, is a finalist for the Weber State University president’s position, the Salt Lake Tribune, Utah’s Standard-Examiner, Utah’s KSL.com and many other media outlets reported. Lamas is a former UTA vice president for student affairs.

UTA in exhibition

UTA was one of the many institutions of higher education that participated in the UIC International Graduate Education Exhibition, China’s xuehua.us reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, November 30, 2018
shortDescription: Conference speakerPaige Wicker, a graduate student and research assistant in chemistry, spoke at the International Conference on Packed Column Supercr
body:
Conference speaker

Paige Wicker, a graduate student and research assistant in chemistry, spoke at the International Conference on Packed Column Supercritical Fluid Chromatography (SFC) in Strasbourg, France, Chromatography Today reported. Wicker described on-line supercritical fluid extraction (SFE) with SFC.

UTA leads sustainable growth

UTA is leading the way in ensuring the region’s healthy, sustainable growth toward megacity status, Dallas Innovates reported.

Artists exhibit

Alumni artists Kerry Butcher and Fabiola Valenzuela have work in the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth’s Modern Billings exhibit, GlassTire reported. The outdoor art is displayed on billboards along Jacksboro Highway in and west of Fort Worth. Butcher earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in studio art and photography. Valenzuela earned a BFA in painting.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, January 7, 2019
shortDescription: UTA degrees awardedAbout 5,400 degrees were awarded at UTA in December, East Texas Matters reported in a story that said the UT System institutions gr
body:
UTA degrees awarded

About 5,400 degrees were awarded at UTA in December, East Texas Matters reported in a story that said the UT System institutions granted more than 22,000 new degrees last month. UTA led all UT System institutions with the number of degrees awarded.

Gas leak research

Kathleen Smits, a UTA associate professor in the Civil Engineering Department, received a $414,000 grant from the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration to develop a method to predict the conditions under which gas leaks may occur and establish best practices to improve response to gas migration incidents and find and fix leaks, Dallas Innovates reported.

Church differences

Jason Shelton, UTA associate professor of sociology, was featured in a Christianity Today story about his research focusing on differences between black and white American Christians and within the black church itself. Ryon Cobb, UTA assistant professor in the School of Social Work, assisted Shelton with the research.

read a news excerpt

UTA international influence

India’s Telangana Today featured a story about The University of Texas at Arlington and one of its most illustrious graduates, former astronaut Kalpana Chawla. She was the first Indian woman to travel to space and one of the crew members who died in the 2003 Columbia space shuttle accident.

Media tech scholarship

The National Association of Broadcasters’ pilot technology initiative has awarded its first media technology and innovation scholarships to nine students, including UTA’s Tonia Vu, AllAccess.com reported. Each winner will receive a $5,000 scholarship for broadcast engineering, media technology and innovation studies.

COE grad student partner

UTA's College of Engineering is partnering with Liaison International's EngineeringCAS™, University Business reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, October 3, 2018
shortDescription: SEIR dedicationUTA is taking big strides toward becoming a health research powerhouse in the North Texas area with the opening of its new research bui
body:
SEIR dedication

UTA is taking big strides toward becoming a health research powerhouse in the North Texas area with the opening of its new research building, D CEO Healthcare, Fort Worth Magazine, KXAS NBC 5 and NBCDFW.com reported. UTA officially dedicated its new Science & Engineering Innovation & Research, or SEIR, building last week. Research projects that focus on brain health, cancer, cardiovascular health, aging and genomics will be housed at SEIR.

Smart seat

Researchers at The University of Texas at Arlington have patented a smart seat cushion that uses changes in air pressure to redistribute body weight to help prevent pressure ulcers, Today’s WoundClinic reported. Muthu Wijesundara, co-inventor of the technology, is chief research scientist at UTA's Research Institute.

Programmable hydrogels

The London Institute of Medical Sciences featured Kyungsuk Yum’s research in its Biomedical Picture of the Day. Yum, a UTA assistant professor in the Materials Science and Engineering Department, creates programmable hydrogels that replicate the movement of humans’ soft tissues. His teams’ work was featured in Nature Communications recently.

Komodo-UTA collaboration

Komodo Platform, the blockchain service ecosystem, announced a collaboration with The University of Texas at Arlington, CryptoNinjas reported. Komodo will provide funding for two senior design projects as well as scholarships for two undergraduate students and two graduate students for one academic year.

Festival of Ideas

“Migration, Immigration and the Art of Survival” is the theme of The University of Texas at Arlington College of Liberal Arts’ Fall 2018 Festival of Ideas, which starts Thursday, Oct. 4, NewsEdge.com and Arlington-tx.gov reported.

Tax questions

William Seeger, UTA clinical professor in economics in the College of Business, clarified industry questions about how the base erosion and anti-abuse tax interacts with tax treaties, Law360 reported. Seeger is a panelist at an American Bar Association tax section meeting in Atlanta this week.

Gender diversity

Kevin Schug, UTA Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry, said the scientific associations need to highlight and feature gender diversity at their conferences and symposiums in a ChromatographyOnline.com column.

History book debuts

Stephen Maizlish’s book, “A Strife of Tongues: The Compromise of 1850 and the Ideological Foundations of the American Civil War,” discusses a time much like our own, when radicals in Congress hurled insults while moderates bemoaned a lack of civility, according to a review in Pacific Standard Magazine. Maizlish is a UTA associate professor of history.

NACUBO honor

UTA received the National Association of College and University Business Officers 2018 Excellence in Sustainability award recently, Global Newswire reported in an article about Jaggaer, a company that helps education entities with business automation solutions.

Gas pump impact

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said as long as the economy stays strong, gas prices shouldn’t have an impact on the midterm elections next month, Houston’s Sunny99.iheart.com reported.

Former player honored

Bruce Collie, a former UTA football player and graduate who played for two San Francisco 49ers Super Bowl title teams, was inducted into the 2019 San Antonio Sports Hall of Fame class, San Antonio's KENS CBS 5 reported. Collie was a San Antonio Lee High School 1980 graduate.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, October 31, 2018
shortDescription: Recycled roadsFuture highways might be made of a recycled plastic slurry, a UTA civil engineering professor told The Washington Post in a story explor
body:
Recycled roads

Future highways might be made of a recycled plastic slurry, a UTA civil engineering professor told The Washington Post in a story exploring some of the uses for recycled plastic. Sahadat Hossain, the civil engineering professor and the director of UTA's Solid Waste Institute for Sustainability, has projects using recycled plastic to shore up failing highway slopes and highway walls. The Post story also ran in the Chicago Tribune, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, the Northwest Arkansas Democrat-Gazette and The Malone Telegram in Franklin County, N.Y.

Woods profiled

Bob Woods, the longtime UTA mechanical engineering professor and Formula SAE advisor, was profiled in Southern Automotive Alliance magazine for his mentoring and teaching career at The University of Texas at Arlington.

Increasing PhDs
