The University of Texas at Arlington has announced that a $1.2 million grant from the U.S. Department of Education, supplemented with $300,000 in UTA matching funds, will help increase the number of doctoral students, especially among women and minorities, Hispanic Engineer reported.

Phrase meaning

Laurel Smith Stvan, UTA associate professor and chair of linguistics, talked about how the phrase "sleeping giants" is used when referencing Latino voters in this year’s election in a story about that voting bloc, Austin’s KUT 90.5 FM reported.

Grad finds job

Akina Brodeak, a UTA administrative assistant and recent UTA graduate, found a job with the University after standing on an Arlington street corner handing out resumes, WFAA ABC 8, Austin’s KVUE ABC 24 , Tyler’s KYTX CBS 19 and Temple’s KCEN NBC 6 reported. Lolin Martins-Crane, director of the Lockheed Martin Career Development Center at UTA, also was interviewed for the story.

Texas Mobility Summit

Texas Innovation Alliance, in conjunction with the city of Arlington, UTA, North Central Texas Council of Governments and the Texas Department of Transportation, sponsored the Texas Mobility Summit Oct. 28-30, Arlington-tx.gov reported. The summit investigated transportation strategies for the future.

Bill Blair Day

The fifth annual Bill Blair Day is being held Nov. 3 at Dallas’ Southwest Center Mall, 3662 W. Camp Wisdom Road, The Dallas Morning News reported. Blair was a Dallas-born Negro Leagues pitcher who influenced others through sports, publishing and behind-the-scenes political involvement. Many of his historical papers were donated to UTA.

Alexus Henry Day

UTA track and field star Alexus Henry was honored by Bridge City council members recently as they retroactively declared June 9, 2018, “Alexus Henry Day,” the Beaumont Enterprise reported. The honor recognized Henry earning the gold medal in the women’s high jump at the NCAA Division I National Outdoor Track and Field Championship. Henry also made made school history by bringing UTA its first individual women’s national championship.

Packaging funding

UTA is receiving three years of new funding, equipment and design software from the International Corrugated Packaging Foundation, People’s Daily reported. ICPF works with students from more than 40 universities annually and has over 25 university partners that teach corrugated curricula.

Alumna profiled

D Magazine profiled Ricochet Fuel Distributors founder Kelly Brett Roberts, a UTA alumna.

Teacher of the Year

Alejandra Ortega received the Houston school district Teacher of the Year award, The Daily Texan reported. Ortega is working on her master’s degree at UTA.

Millenials poll

A poll of American millennials found that most did not know the candidates running in their congressional districts, Newsweek reported. A picture accompanying the story of a Beto O’Rourke rally in Plano showed Kelvin Mote and Ashlynn Long, both UTA freshmen.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, November 2, 2018
shortDescription: Recycled roadsA UTA civil engineering professor said future highways might be made of a recycled plastic slurry, ASEE’s First Bell reported in linking
body:
Recycled roads

A UTA civil engineering professor said future highways might be made of a recycled plastic slurry, ASEE’s First Bell reported in linking to a story originally published in The Washington Post. Sahadat Hossain, a civil engineering professor and the director of UTA's Solid Waste Institute for Sustainability, has projects using recycled plastic to shore up failing highway slopes and highway walls. Steel Guru magazine also ran the Post article. ASEE is the American Society for Engineering Education.

Teachers election role

Teachers play a vital role in elections as a very important voting bloc, and they always have, said Allan Saxe, a UTA associate professor of political science, in a Dallas Morning News story about the impact educators might have on next week’s election.

Quantum communication

Michael Vasilyev, a UTA professor of electrical engineering, and his research partner, Professor Yuping Huang of the Stevens Institute of Technology, received a three-year, $750,000 National Science Foundation grant to address the challenges of large-scale deployment of quantum communication systems, Phys.org reported.

UAVs to inspect

Anand Puppala, UTA Distinguished Teaching Professor of civil engineering, and Surya Congress, a graduate research assistant, authored a Roads & Bridges article about the use of unmanned aerial vehicles in managing and evaluating infrastructure.

New book

Mark Lamster, UTA professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, explores the life of the iconic architect Philip Johnson in a Dallas Morning News column about his new book The Man in the Glass House. Lamster also is The Dallas Morning News architecture critic. D Magazine also reported on Lamster’s book and about how the collaboration between UTA and The Dallas Morning News placed the critic in North Texas.

Day of the Dead

Isabel Montemayor, UTA assistant professor and research associate for the Center of Mexican American Studies, said Mexico’s Day of the Dead is a celebration of life, England’s DailyMail.com reported. “It’s a celebration of the individuals who lived,” she said. A similar story ran in The Dallas Morning News.

Eye movement technology

UTA has been awarded a patent for a revolutionary new technology that is able to scan a user's eye movements and enable him or her to navigate mobile platforms, such as electric wheelchairs, without the use of hands, Greece’s Palo reported. Inventor Christopher McMurrough, now a UTA computer science and engineering lecturer, said his interest in this technology grew out of seeing how his mother-in-law struggled with eye-tracking devices as an ALS patient.

Genomics alliance

Texas A&M University and The University of Texas at Arlington have established the Texas Genomics Core Alliance to increase access to and decrease costs of cutting-edge, high-throughput genomics sequencing technologies, Biotech Week reported.

Rapid adaptation

UTA researchers have found genomic evidence of rapid adaptation of invasive Burmese pythons to their new environment in Florida, NewsRX Health reported. Todd Castoe, UTA biology professor and director of the Castoe Lab, led the research.

Compelled to contribute

UTA student Amber Roberson felt compelled to come to a Congregation Ahavath Sholom event in Fort Worth following the mass shooting at a Pittsburgh synagogue that left 11 dead, WFAA ABC 8 reported. “I knew we needed to get involved. And we couldn't just sit and look at it on Facebook and be glad it wasn't us," Roberson said.

Brazilian national team

Daiane Machado, a 6-1 senior forward for the Lady Mavs women’s basketball team was listed as one of Brazil’s current Division 1 NCAA basketball players, Globe Sports reported. The story focused on Brazil’s national team's future promise.

New job for alumnus

Linah Mohammad has joined The Washington Post as an assistant producer for Post Reports, the paper’s daily podcast. Mohammad is a UTA graduate.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, November 9, 2018
shortDescription: Election analysisRebecca Deen, UTA political science chair and associate professor, analyzed the results of Tuesday’s mid-term elections on KERA 90.1’
body:
Election analysis

Rebecca Deen, UTA political science chair and associate professor, analyzed the results of Tuesday’s mid-term elections on KERA 90.1’s Think radio show. Deen said President Trump has nationalized this most recent election. She also said a split Congress probably translates to more political gridlock in the future.

Teachers' impact

Teachers and school administrators likely voted for Beverly Powell in state Senate District 10 for fear of losing some control of their authority had Konni Burton retained that seat, said Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, in a Star-Telegram story about local control of tax dollars.

Fair housing assessment

While UTA’s affordable fair housing assessment study reflects an unflattering image of segregation in Dallas, the city had the courage to initiate the research and is learning from this study, a UTA alumna wrote in an op-ed piece in The Dallas Morning News. Myriam Igoufe, who earned her doctorate at UTA in urban planning, wrote that the Dallas City Council expressed a commitment to finding bold ways to tackle these complex issues.

Efficient quantum communications

Michael Vasilyev, UTA professor of electrical engineering, will work to build an efficient and robust integrated quantum system on a chip, photonics.com and Targeted News Service reported.

NSF partnerships grant

Weidong Zhou, a Distinguished Professor at UTA in electrical engineering, received a $200,000 Partnerships for Innovation grant from the National Science Foundation to apply fundamental research derived from his work with John Rogers, a world leader in the field of bioresorbable or biodegradable electronics at Northwestern University, Targeted News Service reported.

MavMover setting records

More students are taking the MavMover and associated shuttles than at any time in UTA’s history, Targeted News Service reported.

ClaimBuster cited

An article about the accuracy of medical news and reports could use a tool like ClaimBuster, a UTA-invented fact-checking system that reporters and news organizations use to check facts, Germany’s 360 MFA reported.

Alumnus listed

Kelcy Warren, chief executive of Energy Transfer LP, graduated from UTA, the Dallas Business Journal reported in a list it published on where Texas Fortune 500 CEOs studied.

New VP

Mark Schwartz, a 25-year veteran of cardiovascular device development, has joined BioCardia as vice president of clinical affairs, The Associated Press, MarketScreener, Crossroads Today and many other media outlets reported. Schwartz holds a master’s degree in biomedical engineering from UTA.

Alumnus featured

The Houston Chronicle conducted a question-and-answer column with Mark Henry, superintendent of the Cypress-Fairbanks Independent School District, about the state of the district after Hurricane Harvey, the growth of the district and other K-12 topics. Henry received his bachelor’s degree in secondary education from UTA.

Safety programs

Karen Puckett, director of the UTA Center for Environmental Excellence Division of Enterprise Development, said safety programs shouldn’t end when employees walk out the door and get into a vehicle to drive, LexBlog reported in a presentation that Puckett made at the 2018 National Safety Council Congress last month.

Language symposium

The third annual Symposium on Language Access is being held 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Friday, Nov. 9, at UTA’s E.H. Hereford University Center, Business Insurance reported.

Alumna profiled

Debra Goulding, site coordinator of the Cleburne Christian Women’s Job Corps, was profiled in the Baptist Standard. Goulding has a dual bachelor’s degree in English and education from UTA. She also has her lifetime English as a Second Language certification from UTA.

Arlington election

Former Arlington Mayor Richard Greene wrote in a Star-Telegram op-ed column that Tuesday’s election in Arlington approving term limits doesn't mean the current council is doing a poor job. Greene also is a UTA lecturer in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

Education degree ranked

OnlineMasters.com ranked UTA among 50 universities nationwide as being the best for attaining online master’s degree in educational leadership programs, Ohio’s WLIO NBC/Fox 8, New York’s WICZ Fox 40 and many other websites reported. Only programs from accredited nonprofit institutions were eligible for the ranking.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, January 4, 2019
shortDescription: Gas leak researchKathleen Smits, a UTA associate professor in the Civil Engineering Department, received a $414,000 grant from the Pipeline and Hazard
body:
Gas leak research

Kathleen Smits, a UTA associate professor in the Civil Engineering Department, received a $414,000 grant from the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration to develop a gas-leak prevention method and establish best practices to improve response to gas migration incidents, and find and fix leaks, Phys.org and Techsite reported. 

Differences in church study

Jason Shelton, UTA associate professor of sociology, was featured in a Christianity Today story about his research focusing on differences between black and white American Christians, and within the black church itself. Ryon Cobb, UTA assistant professor in the School of Social Work, assisted Shelton with the research.

Closing the gap

To close the gap between DFW and Austin in attracting technology companies, North Texas needs to tout how workforce ready it is, said an opinion column in The Dallas Morning News. The article noted that UTA and UT Dallas graduates more than doubled between 2000 and 2016, and engineering and computer science were among the top majors.

Positive effects

Transit and walking amenities have a positive effect on attracting knowledge-intensive businesses, Science Trends reported in a column written by Shima Hamidi and Ahoura Zandiatashbar. Hamidi is a UTA assistant professor of planning and Zandiatashbar is a graduate research assistant, both in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs. The two wrote a paper on the subject.

Pain strategies

Robert Gatchel, the UTA Nancy P. and John G. Penson Endowed Professor of Clinical Health Psychology, wrote a 2018 update on the federal pain research strategy for Practical Pain Management. Gatchel, who also is the director for the UTA Center of Excellence for the Study of Health and Chronic Illnesses, led a working group last year that tackled the challenges of managing pain, big data and opioid use.

New snake species

A UTA team has named a new species of snake discovered in the stomach of another snake. The tropical reptile Cenaspis aenigma—Latin for “enigmatic dinner snake”—was profiled in CGTN.com. The article originally appeared in National Geographic. Jonathan Campbell, herpetologist and biology professor, led the research team.

Price formidable

Fort Worth Mayor Betsy Price announced her intention to run for a fourth term this week, KRLD 1080 AM reported. Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said anyone challenging Price will face an uphill battle.

Small impact

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said the government shutdown would have little impact on the American people or federal workers, WIOD 610 AM in Miami reported. He said the workers will eventually get paid, unlike private sector workers when they are laid off.
